#2 "Said" was originally written as "state"; emended from the *Wenyuan Ge* edition.
#3 "Master" was originally missing; supplemented from the *Wenyuan Ge* edition.
#4 "Langye’s elder nephew Ziming" in the *Wenyuan Ge* edition reads "Langye’s nephew Ziming."

*—Scroll Four of *Yi Lin*—*
Compiled by Ma Zong of Fufeng during the Yuanhui era

*Fengsu Tong* in thirty-one scrolls by Ying Shao

The preface states: "Feng" refers to the qi of Heaven, which brings cold and warmth; the forms of Earth, which vary in peril and ease; the waters and springs, which differ in purity and foulness; and the grasses and trees, which range from hard to soft. "Su" refers to the blood-bearing kinds, born in imitation of these patterns. Within a hundred *li*, the winds differ; within a thousand *li*, the customs diverge.

During the Zhou and Qin dynasties, envoys were dispatched in the eighth month in light carriages to gather the finest words of distant ages, storing them in the imperial archives. By the fall of the Ying house, these were nearly all lost or discarded. The Shu scholar Yan Junping left over a thousand words, while Lin Weng Ruicai’s *Gengzhu* and Yang Xiong’s commentary note: "Continuing for twenty-seven years, totaling nine thousand characters."

Zhang Lian remarked: "A work to hang alongside the sun and moon, an indelible book." Though I am unworthy, I dare to compare myself in esteem to such men.

The Divine Farmer is "divine trust." "Farmer" means "abundant"—his virtue is as rich and profound as the divine. The Five Emperors are the Yellow Emperor, Zhuanxu, Emperor Ku, Yao, and Shun. "Yellow" signifies radiance; "Zhuan" means "focused"; "Xu" denotes "trust"; "Ku" implies "examination"; "Yao" stands for "loftiness"; "Shun" suggests "advancement" and "cultivation," meaning he advanced virtue and carried forward Yao’s legacy.

The Three Kings, named by ritual, are Yu of the Xia under the cloud-wrapped sky, Tang of Yin, and King Wu of Zhou. "Yu" means "assistance"; "Tang" signifies "prosperity"; "King" denotes "going forth," meaning all under heaven turn toward him. The Five Hegemons, as recorded in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, are Duke Huan of Qi, Duke Wen of Jin, Duke Mu of Qin, Duke Xiang of Song, and King Zhuang of Chu. "Hegemon" means "bright" and "chief," indicating they all established themselves as leaders, their merits and achievements made manifest. "Hegemon" also means "to grasp," signifying their grasp of the governance of all under heaven.

According to the *Records of Qin*: When Queen Dowager Xuan of King Zhao first held court, regional governors and prefects should not be frequently replaced. According to the *Book of Documents*, there is the practice of evaluating merits.

Confucius said: "If one were to employ me, in a year’s time there would be results, and in three years, success would be complete." When Zichan of Zheng governed for three years, the people composed songs in his praise. Even the worthy and sagacious must proceed gradually—how much more so for those of middling talent? Frequent replacements only lead to confusion and missteps on the path.

In ancient times, there were originally no slaves or bondservants. Slaves and bondservants were all those who had committed offenses. "Slave" (*nu*) means "inferior," while "bondservant" (*bi*) means "base and lowly."

A local saying goes: "To take office is a boundless expanse—half of those who resent it die." Even in an era of clarity and peace, when enlightened and compassionate gentlemen adjudicated cases with pity and restraint, there were still resentful words—how much more so in the present age? Ying Shao was a man of the Three Kingdoms period; this was a saying of his time.

When Emperor Guangwu of Han moved his capital to Luoyang, he transported plain bamboo slips and paper, with a total of two thousand cartloads of classics. When Dong Zhuo overturned the royal house and the Son of Heaven was forced west, in the haste and chaos, seventy carts of books were carried along the road. Caught in the rain, half were discarded, and Dong Zhuo later burned the Bright Hall and its pavilions, reducing all the classics to ashes. What little remained was sometimes used to make sacks and curtains. The Dao of the former kings nearly vanished entirely.

Popular belief holds that those granted gold as a reward received yellow gold. According to *Sunzi’s Art of War*, "daily expenses amount to a thousand gold." A thousand gold means a million coins. When Chen Ping advised the Chu, he sent a thousand gold to the two Shu brothers. Fifty *jin* of gold—all of it yellow gold. Some say "one gold" refers to ten thousand coins.

It is said that one should not raise three children born at the same time. The common belief is that it resembles the breeding of livestock and harms the parents. Yet according to the *Spring and Autumn Annals* and the *Discourses of the States*, in the time of the King of Yue, the people were given surplus grain if they bore two children, and a wet nurse if they bore three. Thus Yue destroyed the mighty Wu—what harm was there in it?

One should not raise a child born in the same month as one’s father. The common belief is that it harms the father. Yet according to the *Zuozhuan*, Duke Huan of Lu had a son born in the same month as himself, and so named the child "Born Together."

Emperor Ming of Han was also born in the same month as Emperor Guangwu. It is improper to return a bride to her natal home after marriage. The common belief is that it brings misfortune. The reason is that a woman’s beauty might lead her to exchange her daughter for another man’s son, so such returns are forbidden.

As for the sealing of Mount Tai, popular belief holds that atop the Sacred Peak lies a golden basket and jade tally, which can reveal a person’s lifespan. Emperor Wu of Han retrieved one that read "eighteen," but upon reading it backward, declared it "eighty." In truth, when the Sacred Peak was sealed, a stone stele twelve feet high was erected, inscribed with the words: "Serve Heaven with ritual, establish oneself with righteousness, serve one’s father with filial piety, and achieve renown with benevolence. Within the four seas, none do not take him as their teacher and submit." The stele was carved to record his reign title and make his achievements known.

At that time, Emperor Wu was already thirty-seven years old—how could he then obtain "eighteen"? If one claims it was read backward, the divine would be without blessing.

I have humbly served at the Eastern Peak for six years, frequently performing prayers and sacrifices. Inquiring of the elders and those who have ascended Mount Tai, none have spoken of a golden basket or jade tally for divining lifespan.

Dongfang Shuo was said to be the essence of Venus, serving as Feng Hou in the time of the Yellow Emperor, as Wu Chengzi in the time of Yao, and later being reborn in Yue as Fan Li, then in Qi as Zhe Yi Zi—such tales speak of his ceaseless transformations. Yet, Shuo was merely a master of wit and humor; common folk ascribed strange words to him, but how could he be a deity?

When the Governor of Pengcheng, Biao, came of age, his father, Bo Chu, was serving as Guanglu Qing. During the mourning period, Bo Chu fathered a child and, deeming it the greatest filial failing to leave no heir, raised the boy himself. A gentleman does not conceal his faults, so he named the child *Fu* ("Mourning Garment").

Now, Biao’s courtesy name was *Yuanshu* ("First Garment"). His mother was from Runan, and his grandfather, named Jing, served as Palace Attendant. During Emperor An’s reign, Biao was born, and the hundred officials came to congratulate the elderly grandfather on the birth of his grandson. Delighted by this auspicious occasion, they named the child *He* ("Congratulation") and gave him the courtesy name *Yuanshu*. His father, Bo Chu, governed three commanderies and, after his wife’s early death, refused to remarry. On his deathbed, he instructed his son: "Simply bury me here; do not retrieve your mother’s coffin. If the dead have awareness, coming and going will not be difficult; if they have none, it would only be a burden." Such was his lofty integrity—how could he have fathered a child during mourning and named him *He*?

Wang Shu of Runan and his son Fang once set out on a journey and did not return for over twenty years. Shu served as a Gentleman of the Imperial Secretariat. When someone reported that his son Fang had died in Runan, Shu immediately dispatched his elder brother, Bo San, to retrieve the coffin. He then donned mourning garments and issued an edict, sending twenty thousand coins in condolence. Later, Fang returned from Cangwu, and Shu petitioned the court to return the condolence money, accepting the charge of falsehood.

Emperor Ling summoned the ministers and grandees to deliberate the matter. The Academician Ren Min argued: "The average lifespan is seventy years; when a father sees his son as his peer, the son’s death may warrant mourning. But Fang was far away, and the report of his death could not be verified—no punishment should be imposed."

The imperial edict returned the money and restored Shu to his original office.

In Runan, Zhang Miao attended a gathering at Du Shi’s home. During the feast, in jest, Zhang Miao bound Du Shi and struck him twenty times, then suspended him by his toes until Du Shi died. Bao Yu ruled on the case, stating: "They were jesting while drunk; his original intent held no malice. He should be absolved of the death penalty."

In Runan, Zhou Wengzhong’s wife gave birth to a daughter, while the wife of a butcher bore a son. Wengzhong’s wife secretly exchanged money to take the butcher’s son as her own. Later, Wengzhong became the governor of Beihai. He sent his clerk, Zhou Guang, to accompany the boy in offering sacrifices at the ancestral tomb. Upon returning, the clerk said to Wengzhong: "At the sacrificial site, I saw only the butcher’s son, dressed in tattered clothes, wielding a knife to carve the meat. Another figure, wearing a green sash, stood in the eastern chamber, hesitant and unwilling to approach. Why was this?" Wengzhong drew his sword and questioned his wife, who confessed the truth. Wengzhong declared: "Those who have sons do so to continue their ancestors’ line. If the ancestors refuse to accept the offering, what use is it?" He then sent the boy back to the butcher’s family by carriage and horse, and retrieved his daughter. The daughter had already been married to a pastry seller, but he brought her home and betrothed her to Li Wensi of Anping. Wensi later rose to the position of governor of Nanyang. The spirits do not partake of offerings from those not of their kind—how could one raise another’s child?

In Chenliu, a wealthy elder of ninety had no sons. He married a peasant girl, but died after a single night. Later, she bore a son. When the child grew older, the elder’s eldest daughter said: "Our father married her and died after one night—this child is not his." They contested the inheritance for years without resolution. The Chancellor, You Ji, ruled: "An old man’s child casts no shadow and cannot endure the cold." It was the eighth month, so he gathered children of the same age and had them all undress for testing. The elder’s child alone cried from the cold, and at midday, indeed cast no shadow. The inheritance was thus awarded to the daughter.

In Yingchuan, two brothers lived together, and both their wives were pregnant. The elder wife’s fetus was injured in the third month, but she did not speak of it. When the time came for the younger wife to give birth, both women lay in the birthing chamber. The younger wife bore a son, but the elder wife stole him in the night. They disputed the matter for three years without resolution. The Chancellor, Huang Ba, ordered the child placed ten paces from each mother and commanded them to retrieve him. The elder wife clutched the child tightly, and he wailed loudly. The younger wife, fearing harm, released him, while the elder wife’s face lit with joy. The younger wife wept in sorrow. Huang Ba declared: "This is the younger wife’s son." He then indicted the elder wife, who confessed her guilt.

In Linhuai, a man took a bolt of silk to the market to sell it. Caught in the rain, he draped it over himself. Another man sought shelter beneath it, claiming space for his head. When the rain ceased, they quarreled over the silk. The Chancellor, Xue Xuan, intervened: "The silk is worth only a few hundred coins—why this dispute?" He cut it in half and gave each a portion. Upon closer inspection, the silk’s owner cried out in injustice, while the other man showed satisfaction. Xue Xuan discerned the truth and, upon interrogation, forced a confession.

The Duke of Zhou’s music was called *Shao*, meaning "to pour and deliberate the Way of the ancestors." King Wu’s music was called *Wu*, signifying the pacification of the realm. Shun’s music was called *Shao*, meaning "to continue," as he continued Yao’s legacy. Yao’s music was called *Dazhang*, meaning "to manifest." Emperor Yu’s music was called *Wuying*, meaning "flourishing." Liu Xiang said: "The *shang* note represents completion, for things reach fulfillment and can be measured. The *jiao* note represents sprouting, for things break through the earth with sharp points. The *gong* note represents the center; the *zhi* note represents prosperity, for things flourish and abound. The *yu* note represents shelter, for things gather and are covered."

Hearing the *gong* note makes one warm and expansive; hearing the *shang* note makes one upright and fond of righteousness; hearing the *jiao* note makes one orderly and fond of ritual; hearing the *zhi* note makes one compassionate and broadly loving; hearing the *yu* note makes one nurturing and fond of learning.

The pipa was created by musicians of recent generations, though its maker is unknown. Its name derives from the motion of the hands (*pi* and *pa*). It is three feet and five inches long, corresponding to Heaven, Earth, Man, and the Five Phases. Its four strings represent the four seasons.

The *Book of Changes* states: "It is beneficial to see the great person." The great person and the sage share the same meaning.

The *Analects* states: "The noble person ascends." Zang Sunhe said: "The next one to ascend will surely be Kong Qiu." The term *ru* (Confucian) means "to distinguish," separating the worthy from the foolish across past and present. The Zhang family of the time called Jia Kui a "comprehensive Confucian," and people would say: "Ask Jia Longtou about anything, and he will never tire."

The *Rites* state: "When five people live in a thatched hut, the eldest must have a separate mat." Today, calling the powerful "elders" is incorrect.

Guanzi said: "The teacher imparts instruction, and the disciple follows—this is not knowledge of the ancient Way, but the title of the teacher." The term *disciples* refers to many students. Thus it is said: "Among the teachers, one must be sober; among the students, all are drunk. When all are drunk, only the sober one presides over the libation." The *Rites* state: "When drinking wine, one must offer a libation to honor one’s ancestors." When Xun Qing was in Qi, he was the most senior teacher, hence he was thrice called the "libation officer." The *Book of Songs* states: "The men of Yin are keen and swift; the eminent scholars are outstanding; the refined scholars are broadly learned; the ranked scholars have unchanging duties; the reclusive scholars speak freely." The *Book of Changes* states: "In leading the army, steadfastness in the elder brings good fortune." This does not merely honor age, but requires virtue and conduct surpassing others. The *Commentary* states: "To rely on virtue, nothing is better than trustworthiness—such virtue can be trusted and relied upon."

The *Rites* state: "Ten feet is called a *zhang*, the height of a grown man." The term *fu* (husband) means "skin," signifying that his wisdom is keen and his teaching expansive. Thus, he is called a *zhangfu* (husband).

The *Analects* states: "The common man and common woman." The *Commentary* states: "One day and one night make a day; one man and one woman make a household." According to the ancients, two bolts of cloth were used to make clothes for a man and woman. Today, people wear single-layer garments, hence the term *pi* (bolt).

When a man undergoes the dragon transformation and rises, he does not strike at his village. If he merely conforms to customs and, upon seeing goodness, does not emulate it, he is called a "common person."

The *Rites* states: "To dismiss the unworthy." According to the annotation: If a child is coarse and unrefined, bearing no resemblance to his parents, he is called *buxiao* (unworthy). Today, people also use *buxiao* as a humble term.

Fang states: One who neglects affairs and behaves dissolutely is called *wulai* (shiftless). It means one cannot be relied upon. This is akin to the High Ancestor’s words to the Supreme Emperor: "Father, I am shiftless."

The Minister of Education, Zhongshan Zhu Tian, styled Boren, was summoned by imperial carriage. En route, he contracted a fever. Passing by his friend Xie Zhuo’s home, Zhuo refused him entry. When he reached Ji Commandery, he lodged at an inn. After six or seven days, his disciples saw his condition worsening and wished to inform the magistrate of Ji. Tian said: "Even a friend would not take me in—why trouble the magistrate, who does not know me? What good would it do? Life and death are fated; no medicine is needed." The disciples secretly informed the magistrate of Ji, who was none other than Ying Rong of Runan. Upon hearing this, Rong was greatly alarmed. He rushed to Tian’s sickbed and wept, saying: "Boren is a once-in-an-era talent, destined to be the state’s pillar and support. How could he silently perish in an inn without sending word?" Rong then personally drove him home and attended to his illness himself. Gradually, Tian’s condition improved. Rong said to Boren:

The inauspicious and the auspicious were spoken without taboo; sorrow and fear intertwined in the heart. Funeral preparations were already made, yet joy and grief faced one another. Boren remained in the post station for several tens of days before departing. He was appointed Palace Attendant and President of the Imperial Secretariat, then promoted to Inspector of the Capital Region. He recommended Ying Rong to succeed him, and Rong subsequently governed five commanderies. Xie Zhuo was not deemed worthy of recruitment by the imperial court.

In high antiquity, people dwelt among the grasses and lodged beneath the frost. In winter, they resided on the southern slopes of mountains; in summer, on the northern slopes.

The Filial and Incorrupt Candidate from Pengcheng, Zhang Zijiao, argued: "If rulers and ministers could not share the same given names, then King Mu of Zhou, whose name was Man, would not have had a descendant named Sun Man in the time of King Ding."

King Li’s name was Hu, and King Zhuang’s son was also named Hu.

A common saying goes: "Those who take office in the fifth month will be dismissed without promotion." This year, a candidate of exceptional talent was appointed magistrate of Xiao. He took office in the fifth month, and on an inauspicious day, he entered his residence. After five months in office, he was recommended by the Four Ministries and promoted to magistrate of Wuling. When I served as magistrate of Yingling, I directly opposed the Grand Year Star. My chief clerk urged me to proceed northeast, but I refused. After five months in office, I was promoted to governor of Taishan.

The *Chu Ci* states: "The Wind Earl is Feilian." According to the *Rites of Zhou*, the Wind Master is the star *Ji* (Winnowing Basket), which governs winnowing and can summon the winds. The spirit of the *wuxu* day governs the Wind Earl, hence on the *bingxu* day, sacrifices are made in the northwest.

According to the *Rites of Zhou*, the Rain Master is the star *Bi* (Net). Among the masses of the central land, none surpass water, hence rain is called a "master." The spirit of the *chou* day governs the Rain Master, hence on the *jichou* day, sacrifices are made to it.

During the *Yuankang* era of Emperor Huan, the women of the capital fashioned "sorrowful brows," "weeping grains," "falling-horse chignons," "broken-waist gaits," and "rotten-tooth smiles." "Sorrowful brows" were thin and sharply angled; "weeping grains" involved lightly wiping beneath the eyes to resemble tear stains; "falling-horse chignons" were tilted to one side; "broken-waist gaits" made the feet appear detached from the body; and "rotten-tooth smiles" mimicked the grimace of a toothache. These fashions all originated with Liang Ji.

The *Traditions* states: "When the King of Zhao favored broad eyebrows, the people all drew them halfway up their foreheads. When the King of Chu favored wide collars, the people of his state all bared their necks. When the King of Qi favored slender waists, there were those in his harem who starved to death." In the capital, there were Hu-style robes, Hu-style tents, Hu-style forests, Hu-style harps, Hu-style flutes, and Hu-style dances. This was due to the influx of troops during Dong Zhuo’s time.

Emperor Ling roamed the Western Park, driving a chariot pulled by four white camels and personally holding the reins. The court officials imitated him, and the price of camels rose to equal that of horses.

During the reign of Emperor Huan, a popular rhyme went: "Straight as a bowstring, dead by the roadside; crooked as a hook, enfeoffed as a lord." Liang Ji wished to enthrone a young ruler, while Li Gu sought to establish the Prince of Qinghe. Liang Ji then memorialized the throne, and Li Gu died in prison, his corpse exposed by the roadside. Liang Ji was "crooked as a hook," and Li Gu "straight as a bowstring."

The song went: "The thousand-league grass, how lush and green! In the tenth month, the divination yields not a single day of life." This referred to Dong Zhuo. "Lush and green" described his violent and flourishing power.

Since the Qin and Han dynasties, the exalted have named their palaces and halls, whereas previously, the noble and base made no such distinctions.

According to the *Genealogical Origins*, Xian invented city walls. *Cheng* (city) means "to contain," and *guo* (outer wall) means "great."

According to the rites, the Son of Heaven has an outer screen to make his ministers hold their breath in reverence.

*Sousou* means "accumulated." It refers to the gathering of firewood and kindling.

Sunzi said: "A city with walls of metal and moats of boiling water, yet lacking grain, cannot be defended even by Taigong or Mo Di." *Jun* (commandery) means "extensive." The *Zuozhuan* states: "Senior ministers receive counties, while junior ministers receive commanderies." Only under the First Emperor of Qin were commanderies established to oversee counties. *Xian* (county) means "level."

A *post station* is where envoys, having transmitted their messages, are permitted to lodge.

North-south roads are called *qian*; east-west roads are called *mo*.

According to the *Commentary on the Book of Changes*, in high antiquity there was a man named Yang You who was skilled at bringing misfortune upon others. Hence, when people inquire after one another in ordinary times, they ask, "Are you well?"

When a city gate catches fire, disaster befalls the fish in the moat. The common explanation is that the moat and the fish are the names of a man who lived near the city gate. In truth, when a city gate burns, water is drawn from the moat, and thus the fish all die.

Prisons originated with the Three Kings. After the establishment of corporal punishments, prisons were created. In the Xia dynasty, they were called *xiatai*; in the Zhou, *tuyu*. They serve to make people reflect and reform their evil ways. The character for "prison" (*yu*) consists of two dogs guarding it, implying that even dogs would imprison those without human sentiment. Criminals are placed in round enclosures, hence the character for "prisoner" (*qiu*) is a person within a mouth. The character for "crime" (*zui*) originally consisted of "self" (*zi*) and "bitterness" (*xin*), signifying suffering and sorrow. The First Emperor of Qin believed the character *gao* (a component of *zui*) resembled *huang* (emperor), so he altered it to *zui*.

In Kuaiji, there were many licentious sacrifices. Poor families unable to sacrifice an ox would, after death, transform into bellowing oxen. The governor, Diwu Lun, enforced strict prohibitions to eradicate this practice.

When Li Shujian of Guiyang was young and served as an attendant in the provincial administration, a dog in his household stood on its hind legs. Shujian said: "This dog is mimicking a human—what harm is there in a person’s conduct?" Later, when Shujian was a county magistrate and removed his cap to rest on his couch, the dog took it and ran off. Shujian said: "This dog has mistakenly caught its collar on its ears." The dog then gathered fire in front of a turtle-shaped censer, and the neighbors reported it. Shujian said: "If a dog can gather fire, it is fortunate that no humans are needed." The dog soon died violently, and Shujian rose to high office.

*The Book of Lord Shang* in four scrolls:
Those with conduct surpassing others are condemned by the world; those with unique insight are resented by the people. The mole cricket and the locust are born in spring and die in autumn, yet a single emergence causes the people to suffer food shortages for years. Now, if one person farms while a hundred consume, it is worse than the mole cricket and the locust.

When those who wander and consume outnumber the farmers, agriculture languishes, and when agriculture languishes, governance decays. The weak who remove the strong become strong; the strong who remove the weak become weak.

The scholars of antiquity wore clothes that did not warm their skin and ate food that did not fill their bellies. They tormented their minds and labored their limbs.

In ancient times, the people thrived in the wilds, and chaos led to the establishment of rulers.

When woodworms multiply, the wood breaks; when cracks widen, the wall collapses. To perish without defeat or survive without victory—from antiquity to the present, such a thing has never existed.

---

When soldiers view battle as starving wolves view meat, they may be put to use.

The sage governs the people as high and low govern water, as dry and damp govern fire.

*Ruanzi, Four Scrolls*
The fisherman casts his net in the deep to catch the whale-swallowing fish;
The enlightened ruler enacts law throughout the land to restrain the violent and overbearing.

Establishing laws is to dam the people—then the common folk cannot breach them;
Erecting barriers is to dam the waters—then the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers cannot overrun them.
If barriers can be overrun, the rivers become disasters;
If laws can be breached, the common folk become harms.

Those who do not plant trees die without coffins;
Those who do not raise silkworms have no silk for their bodies;
Those who do not spin meet misfortune without hempen cloth.
The nobleman, at leisure, ponders righteousness;
The petty man, at leisure, schemes wickedness.

High birds gather on towering trees;
The wise choose their ground and soar.

If even one thief is left unpursued, harm spreads to burglars and robbers;
If flatterers are left unpunished, harm reaches those who sway the ruler.

*Zhengbu, Scroll Ten*
All people begin in ignorance and darkness.
Through study, they awaken their aspirations;
Through conduct, they order their lives.
Advancing in the Dao, they become noblemen;
Deviating from ritual, they are called petty men.
The nobleman’s every act treads the path of virtue and radiates glory;
The petty man’s every move plunges into evil and invites punishment.

Bright and pure,
With indigo, it becomes blue;
With cinnabar, it becomes red;
With the bark of the cork tree, it becomes yellow;
With black dye, it becomes black.

Uncarved jade remains but a round stone from Nanshan.

Thieves who break through windows do not shrink from severing waists and necks;
Soldiers who flee battle do not fear axes and blades.

The Han realm spans the ends of the earth, exhausts the limits of the land:
To the left, the Tang Valley;
To the right, the Yu Abyss;
Before, the scorching lands of Chu;
Behind, the frontier gates.
North of Qilian, south of Yellow Mountain,
East of Jieshi, west of Heli—
None fail to bear tribute and submit.

Confucius and Shu Guang:
Above, they spoke the discourse of heaven;
Below, the language of the people.
They encompassed both men and women,
Probing the outer and inner.

*The Huainanzi* is frivolous and overly expansive;
*The Great Mystery* is abstruse and yields little effect;
*The Model Sayings* is jumbled and lacks a guiding principle;
*The New Book* is verbose and of scant use.

The Jade Token states:
Red as a parrot’s crest,
Yellow as steamed chestnut,
White as fat,
Black as pure lacquer—
Such are the signs of jade.
Refined speech and elegant instruction,
Words that become classics and counsels—
These are the signs of a person.

Mountain spirits are called *li*;
The essence of creatures is called *mei*;
The essence of earth is called *jiyang*;
The essence of water is called *wangshe*;
The essence of wood is called *bifang*;
The essence of fire is called *youguang*;
The essence of metal is called *qingming*.
When the world follows the Dao, all such essences withdraw and hide.

Heaven calls the immortal *Child*;
The masses, *straw dogs*.
It cherishes its Child, favoring long life;
It scorns straw dogs, leaving them to early death.
Without study, it is as though one tries to see without eyes,
To run without legs,
To fly without wings,
To speak without a mouth—
It cannot be done.

Jie and Zhou, though they held the throne of the Son of Heaven, had not a single man’s praise.
They were like rotten stumps and withered trees—when the wind came, they toppled.

Enforce punishments with clarity, administer laws with care,
Show compassion for the people, bestow kindness upon those below.
Then the living will bear no grudge,
And the dead will hold no resentment.
As the saying goes:
“Governance like frost and ice—
Deceit and excess vanish.
Authority like thunder and lightning—
Bandits and thieves do not arise.”

*Shiwei, Scroll Ten* by Yao Xin
Kong Wenju’s metal nature was too strong, his wood nature insufficient.
Turning from shade toward sunlight, he stood alone and mourned his solitude.

Silk all comes from silkworms;
Bronze equally from stone.
Woven into plain cloth, it is cheap;
Woven into brocade, it is precious.
Cast as a bell, it is small;
Cast as a bell, it is large.

The *Classic* is like water flowing beneath a carriage;
The *Calendar* is like sand clinging to a wheel.
The tracks of feet, high and low, cannot be reckoned.
Water, when warm, becomes hot liquid;
When cold, it becomes ice.
Though ice and hot liquid differ in *qi*, the nature of water remains the same.
Silkworms can spin thread, but without boiling water, it does not become silk.
Human nature shifts and changes—
This is the comparison.

When zithers and lutes are strung, the music of Zheng and Wei arises;
When the five colors are combined, embroidered silks are born.

Mengzi drove worldly affairs into the realm of benevolence and righteousness;
Those who followed walked the path of uprightness.
If the South Seas had no pearl-gatherers,
If Kunlun had no jade-cutters,
Then bright pearls would not adorn the pepper chambers,
And fine jade would not hang in the cassia palaces.

*Tongyu, Scroll Eight*
The wheel’s track is the carriage’s path;
The oar is the boat’s wing.
The body’s need for the Dao is like these two things.
Those who slander others clamor in unison like thunder;
Those who praise them spread like wildfire and stir waves.
Someone asked: Was Chen Fan loyal?
The reply: Riding alone to wield the axe against rebels,
Ascending the steps straight and unyielding—
This was no resource for a disordered age.
To know his loyalty is not as good as knowing his wisdom.
Talent values precision;
Learning values discourse.
Substance over form—like Shi Jian;
Form over substance—like Cai Yong.
When form and substance are in perfect balance,
Xu Gan comes close.

*The Master Embracing Simplicity*, Forty Scrolls
Outer Chapters, Twenty Scrolls;
Inner Chapters, Twenty Scrolls.
By Ge Hong, styled Zhichuan.

Fine wine and fragrant liqueurs confuse the nature;
Red blossoms and plain silk cut short the lifespan.

Ban Di could not carve stone into a needle’s point;
Ou Leng could not cast lead and tin into a *Ganjiang* sword.

The *Han Court Daily Records* state:
Li Shaojun wished to depart.
Emperor Wu dreamed of ascending Songgao Mountain with him.
Halfway, a messenger riding a dragon arrived from the clouds, bearing a tally, and said:
“The Great One summons Shaojun.”
The Emperor said: “Shaojun will leave me.”
A few days later, Shaojun died.
After some time, his coffin was opened—
Only his clothes and cap remained.

To discard a flaw the size of an ant’s nose
And lose a priceless piece of pure jade;
To cast aside a speck of imperfection the width of a hook
And abandon a foot-long night-shining pearl—
This is why Zhuangzi grieved,
Why Xue Zhuo sighed endlessly—
Like those who do not study immortality.

The Daoist arts enable one to change form and alter appearance,
To swallow swords and spit fire,
To sit and vanish, to stand and disappear,
To summon clouds and raise mists,
To call forth snakes and insects,
To gather fish and turtles,
To enter the depths without drowning,
To tread blades without injury.

The *Records of Strange Tales* by Chen Zhonggong states: A man of the same commandery, Zhang Guang, met with chaos and abandoned his four-year-old daughter, who could not walk, in a tomb, leaving her with several months’ worth of provisions. Three years later, he returned to retrieve her for burial, yet the girl still sat in the tomb. When asked why, she said: “After the food ran out, I saw something at the corner of the tomb stretching its neck to swallow qi, so I imitated it and was no longer hungry.” Upon closer inspection, it was a large tortoise. When the girl was brought home and fed, her stomach ached at first, but in time she grew accustomed to it.

The spider taught by the Tang Master weaves its web; Jintian relied on the Nine Crows to set the seasons; Tang Yao observed the mojia plant to know the months.

The Dao enables one to ascend the void, tread upon shadows, and drink jade nectar, to feast on azure mushrooms.

Peng Zu said: “In heaven there are many exalted offices; newly ascended immortals hold lowly ranks and serve in many capacities. Like a farmer who obtains a vermilion bow only to scare crows, or a man of Nancheng who receives a tattered robe only to gather firewood—so too do worldly men obtain the elixir of immortality yet fail to value it.”

Yuanjun was the teacher of Lord Lao.

Worldly people vie only for fleeting glory, chasing after the gray hawk and the yellow hare, clinging to honor and pursuing profit.

The superior adept who attains the Dao becomes a celestial official; the middling adept dwells upon Kunlun; the lesser adept achieves longevity in the world.

The vermilion herb has stems like coral; when cut, its sap flows like blood. If jade is cast into the sap, it dissolves like mud, and over time turns to liquid. Gold cast into it becomes “golden nectar,” jade cast into it becomes “jade wine”—ingesting it grants longevity.

Master Shi’s cinnabar method: Take a fledgling crow before its feathers grow, feed it a mixture of true cinnabar and beef, and its plumage will turn crimson. Kill it, dry it in the shade, and consume it to live five hundred years.

A face of unadorned fairness, skin of rosy hue, eyes that pierce the unseen—clear notes of shang and zhi mingling to confound the ear: such is the virtue of true principle.

The Dragon Abyss remains ever fresh through constant dredging; the axe and adze wear swiftly with daily use.

---

A span-long dragonfly skims the surface of a puddle and claims the world holds no seas so vast; a mite writhes within a fruit pit and declares the world holds no realms so boundless. Dried meat may stave off hunger for a moment, and poisoned wine may quench thirst for an instant—yet death follows swiftly after. One prizes luminous pearls but scorns the deep pools that yield them, cherishes flawless jade but despises the Jing Mountains that bear it, unaware that the pools are the source of pearls, the mountains the birthplace of jade.

In this age, scholars languish in waiting, while no office remains vacant even briefly. When the balmy breeze rises, fur robes and braziers are set aside; when the world’s path levels, extraordinary men retreat.

The fleshly zhi is the ten-thousand-year toad, its head inscribed with eight vermilion characters. Harvested at noon on the fifth day of the fifth month, it can trace lines on the earth to summon flowing water or be worn on the left hand to repel weapons. Encountering in the mountains a child seven or eight inches tall, riding a carriage or horse—this is the fleshly zhi. Consuming it grants transcendence.

The thousand-year bat is white as snow, roosting upside down, its brain too heavy to hold upright. The thousand-year swallow’s nest faces north.

Cloud essence, cloud pearls, cloud liquid, cloud mother, and cloud sand are ingested with jade water.

Emperor Cheng hunted on Mount Zhongnan when he saw a naked figure, its body covered in black fur. Surrounding and capturing it, they found it could leap chasms and scale cliffs like a bird. The captive was a woman who claimed to be a palace attendant from the Qin. When rebels from east of the pass approached, the Qin king surrendered, and she fled into the mountains, nearly starving until an old man taught her to eat pine nuts, which banished hunger. She was a palace woman of King Ziying of Qin, living over two hundred years by Emperor Cheng’s time. When people later fed her grains, her fur gradually shed, and she aged rapidly before dying.

To attain long life, consume mountain essence—mountain essence is a tree.

Master Lingyang Zhong took *far-reaching ambition* for twenty years, fathered thirty-seven sons, and never forgot what he read.

The true sages are the Yellow Emperor and Laozi; the worldly sages are Zhou and Confucius.

Those skilled in the game of *mu* are called *mu* sages—thus Yan Ziqing and Ma Suiming earned the name of *mu* sages.

Peng Zu boasted of serving Yao, living through the Xia and into the Yin. The Yin king sent palace women to learn his bedchamber arts; when they proved effective, he sought to kill Peng Zu to suppress his teachings. Forewarned, Peng Zu fled, and seventy years later, someone saw him in the shifting sands.

To achieve long life, keep the belly free of desires; to attain deathlessness, keep the belly free of filth.

A village saying goes: A person in the world loses a day with each passing day, like driving oxen or sheep to the butcher—each step forward brings death nearer.

Lord Lao’s surname was Li, given name Pin, courtesy name Boyang. He stood nine feet tall, with a yellow complexion, a beak-like mouth, a prominent nose, and eyebrows five inches long. He dwelled in the Hall of Golden Towers and Jade Chambers.

Clove tongue incense and the milk of coptis root cure all eye ailments.

A proverb says: No fat immortals, no rich Daoists. Though Daoists can make gold and silver, they remain poor.

Another saying: "Three copies turn fish into *lu*, emperor into tiger." Even divine talismans, now rarely effective, are like this. White stone resembles jade, and treacherous flatterers resemble the worthy. The *luan* bird does not tangle in nets; the *lin* beast does not fall into traps.

An inch of glue cannot clarify the Yellow River’s turbidity; a foot of water cannot cool the heat of Xiaoqiu. Plugging a leak with a bored boat or quenching a raging fire with fierce flames—such efforts are futile.

If a plain scholar plows by day to feed his mouth and gathers firewood by night to pursue learning, then even You and Xia would not be deemed exceptional.

Once a great mansion burns, drawing water from the vast sea is too late; when torrents surge through the skies, launching boats on long rivers is futile.

Ministers are like hands and feet—they cannot refuse treading on ice or grasping fire.

When a lofty ridge is about to collapse, fine threads cannot stitch it together. When the Dragon Gate’s waters boil, a handful of earth cannot dam them. Swords and halberds, though unsuited for sewing, can butcher oxen and horses; awls and drills, though useless for slaughter, excel at stitching. Materials have their great and small uses—none should be discarded.

An army may stand thick as a forest, yet not all its soldiers are brave.

---

Virtue is the rouge and powder of governance; punishment is the bridle and whip of the age. When one ought to kill but does not, great banditry arises.

A spark from a drill’s tip may be quenched with a mouthful of water; a magpie’s egg, unhatched, may be crushed in the palm. Yet once it soars atop the clouds, scorching the vast wilds, beating six wings to pierce the dawn’s glow—even the wise and brave cannot restrain it. Releasing the reins and whip to ride a galloping steed on perilous paths, or casting aside the oar to drift a light boat on rivers and seas—how could this not be dangerous? A golden boat cannot dredge the waves of the Sun Marquis; a jade horse cannot gallop a thousand *li*.

Some offer treasures to sell themselves; some peddle letters to influential men. Some, with fathers or elder brothers noble and eminent, are summoned merely by the sight of their gates; others, through long habit of bowing and scraping, are at last taken in.

As the saying goes: “They recommend ‘Outstanding Talent’ who know not books; they examine ‘Filial and Incorrupt’ whose fathers live apart.” The poor and pure, white as snow, are muddied like sludge; the high-ranking generals, fine as they seem, are timid as flies.

The proverb says: “The ancients sought advancement through diligent study of the classics; today’s men seek office by shunning worldly affairs.” I say: the bonds of friendship should not be shallow or insincere—outward smiles masking hollow hearts. As Yang Xiong mocked: “A bright mirror, when raised, reveals a crooked cap; the sun’s charioteer, when shining, exposes a warped shadow.”

Zhou Bo, a minister of the altars of soil and grain, could not answer questions on money and grain.

Those who recognize treasures must gather the luminous pearls washed in clear waters; those who prize *qi* must seek the fragrant orchids amid foul marshes. Without a suspended mirror, who can sift jade from mud or retrieve sunken pearls from the river’s depths? The greatly wise stand firm as mountains; the petty drift like tumbleweeds and floating duckweed.

The straight plumb line is detested by crooked wood; purity and impartiality are loathed by the treacherous and wicked.

When King Wen met Lü Wang, before the mulberry’s shade had shifted, he knew this was his teacher. When Xuande beheld Kongming, before the sun’s shadow had changed, he entrusted him with his heart and mind. Yet a grand appearance does not guarantee worthiness, nor does a feeble demeanor denote foolishness.

Bo Jie discerned a vessel of unmatched sound amid the ashes of a burnt-out hearth; Zhang Heng distinguished bamboo of rare resonance before it was ever used. Dignity moves like dragons and tigers, circling in perfect order.

After wine, the body lightens and the ears grow hot; caps slip, belts loosen. The sluggish tumble like tumbleweeds in the wind; the composed leap like deer and fish. The tongue-tied wave their hands to keep rhythm; the unassertive grow bold and speak with vigor. They compare nine bends to an anthill, Lüliang’s rapids to an ox’s hoofprint—no matter how sternly forbidden, they cannot be stopped.

If a lord fears wine as he fears illness, loathes drunkenness as he loathes grave sickness, then he will avoid the fault of dissipation.

When people dig cellars to brew wine and carry it in their sleeves, the law is light and profit heavy—how can one make them abstain? Guan Xiangru, with three *dou* of wine, grew eloquent and refined; Yang Xiong never parted from his cup, yet the *Tai Xuan* was completed.

Those who love evil are like moths drawn to a bright flame; those who shun learning are like dust swept up by a whirlwind.

With an axe but no handle, what can be done?

To praise the supple and yielding as graceful while scorning the upright and solemn as rustic—is this not delusion?

Scholars in impoverished alleys chant by withered scrolls, cling to yellowed volumes, bow their heads and bend their knees, hastening to serve the powerful. Once their feathers grow and wings form, once they shed their earthen shells like cicadas, they strut with arrogance—these are the ones who shatter steles.

Long ago, Xishi lay by the roadside clutching her chest in pain; her fragrance, like orchid and musk, made all who saw her admire her. A neighboring girl imitated her, and all who saw her loathed her—just as the world mimics Dai Shuluan and Ruan Sizong.

When the age values something, even a lame donkey fetches the price of a dragon steed.

Fox-fur robes cannot ward off summer’s heat; dragon-prowed boats cannot traverse dry land.

A fine general, when firm, is like heaven—visible but untouchable; when yielding, like an abyss—observable but impenetrable. Departing, he vanishes like lightning—seen but unreachable; standing, he is immovable as a mountain—gazed upon but unshaken.

In spring, long spears lead the way; in summer, great halberds; in autumn, bows and crossbows; in winter, blades and shields. This is the way of marching with the seasons, aligning with heaven’s law.

Tai Gong said: “Strike the solitary and weak, and ten thousand men will be no match; a single woman can withstand a hundred men.”

When the wind rustles leaves, the enemy is ten *li* away; when it whistles through the branches, a hundred *li*; when it shakes the boughs, four hundred *li*. If metal vessels ring on their own, or scorched vessels sound, the army is exhausted. *Qi* like startled deer signals a defeated force.

Rain and dew soaking garments is called “moistening the army”; when they do not, it is called “weeping troops.” When the army’s *qi* resides in the Great One’s jade tent, it cannot be assailed.

Where crabs appear on the battlefield, the army should move swiftly.

I once heard Ji Sheng say: “Can Zuo Taichong and Zhang Maoxian be called *tongren*?” The Way of the ruler replied: “*Tongren* stand next to the sages—there is no room between.”

I asked Ban— Ban said: “Lü Wang saw clouds and knew where the High Ancestor was. Did heaven open only Lü’s eyes while blinding all others?” A eunuch without desire cannot be called chaste; a courtesan who does not drink cannot be called upright.

King Wen ate the soup of his son yet feigned ignorance—not because he savored it.

Dong Zhongshu’s learning was profound, but his natural talent dull. To mistake clams and wasps for divine dragons is not only to fail to recognize dragons, but also clams and wasps.

Wang Chong patted Ban Gu’s back and said: “This child will surely be known throughout the world.”

The Five Ridges know no trees that shed in winter; in the Southern Sea and Jin’an, rice ripens nine times a year.

The *Jade Register of Lord Lao* states: “Pine resin buried in the earth for a thousand years becomes *fuling*; *fuling* for a thousand years becomes amber; amber for a thousand years becomes chalcanthite; chalcanthite for a thousand years becomes *weixi*.”

Roast the drum to make it sound; tighten the strings to make them mournful.

Should the drum be scorched to hasten its rupture or the strings tightened until they snap, the proof lies in the swiftness of the blade that slays the horse. ○ When clams and wasps build their nests, they produce beeswax and water; their froth becomes pumice. ○ The Falling Star Hollow is said to be where a star descended in the time of King Wu. ○ The *Book of Ji Tomb* states: “After the Yellow Emperor ascended as an immortal, his minister Fu Che carved wood into an effigy of the Yellow Emperor and led the feudal lords in its veneration.” ○ Consuming magpie embryos enables one to write in the dark. ○ He Bo was a man of Huayin who drowned while crossing the river on the geng day of the eighth month; the Heavenly Emperor appointed him as the River Lord. ○ The Goose Ghost. Emperor Jing of Wu suffered an illness and summoned the shaman Xian. The emperor tested her by slaughtering a goose and burying it in the palace gardens, then erecting a small hut with a curtained bed and placing a woman’s shoes before it. The shaman declared, “I see only a white goose—no woman at all.” The emperor thus held her in high regard. ○ The Gibbon Ghost. My friend Jiao Yongshu once kept a large gibbon, chaining it by the ankle in the rafters. A dog gnawed it to death, and after a hundred days, its ghost appeared to onlookers, saying, “On the ceiling beam sits a gibbon, its wounds still dripping blood.” ○ My great-uncle attained the Dao and could divide his form at will. Once, as he sat in conversation with a certain Master Ge, another Master Ge arrived to see him off. ○ I have seen some hundred fascicles of the writings of the Two Lu brothers, though it seems their works are not yet complete.

Compared to others, they are as the Yangtze and Han rivers to a stagnant puddle.

Ji Sheng remarked: “Whenever I read the works of the Two Lu brothers, I cannot help but lay down the scroll in admiration, fearing their writings may one day be exhausted.” The *Master Lu’s Ten Essays* are indeed masterful works—where their language is rich, even the most refined thought cannot subtract from it; where their principles are concise, even the most eloquent brush cannot add to it. Observing these two, how could they be mere scholars of refined elegance or men of letters?

○ The *Baopuzi* states: In Qin times, people did not notice the ugliness of noseless faces; in Yangdi, they despised those without goiters. Master Lu possessed profound insight into the unbridled nature of literature, yet he never indulged in empty or exaggerated speech—not because he could not, but because he chose not to. The writings of Master Lu are like jade from the Dark Garden, every piece a luminous treasure. Even centuries later, if there should arise men of talent comparable to the Two Lu brothers, they would still stand shoulder to shoulder. To call them sparse would be a grave misjudgment.

○ At the gates of Confucius and Zengzi, those who learned by ear and mouth alone have long since vanished; only those who entrusted their teachings to bamboo and silk may be called treasures of the age. Restraint is the saddle and bridle of benevolence and righteousness; bonds and locks are the trappings of ritual and music.

○ My friend, Master Xuanbo, built his walls with Confucianism and Mohism, wielded his weapons with wit and spirit—truly a man of antiquity. ○ Ice forms yet does not chill; provisions run out yet hunger does not come. ○ Where otters multiply, fish are disturbed; where hawks gather, crows are thrown into chaos. ○ A tail spanning a full zhang cannot belong to a body of a mere foot; tusks reaching several ren cannot fit in a mouth of a few inches. Mi Heng once said: “Only Kong Rong and Xun Qiang are worth speaking to—the rest are but wine jars and rice sacks.”

Hong, styled Zhichuan, was a native of Jurong in Danyang. His ancestors traced back to the clan of Ge Tian. After his family’s library was repeatedly destroyed by fire, Hong carried his books on his back and traveled on foot, borrowing texts to copy by hand. He sold firewood to buy paper, and by lamplight, he pored over his writings—what he transcribed was often written in reverse, few could read it. His nature was unassuming; his hat cords were frayed and soiled. Sometimes he wore flowing robes with wide sashes, sometimes tight sleeves and a short jacket; at times his robes dragged on the ground, at others they barely covered his knees. The people of his time called him a “Baopu scholar,” and thus he came to be known by his writings.

Hong was too poor to keep servants, and his fences were left untended. He often pushed through brambles to leave his home and parted the weeds to enter. By nature, he avoided offending officials or troubling his relatives.

○ When Ji Jun was appointed Governor of Guangzhou, he recommended Hong as his adjutant. Hong saw this not as a path to profit or pleasure, but as a means to retreat to the southern lands.

○ Hong never gambled at dusk with dice or tiles; when he saw others playing, he paid no attention.

○ At fifteen, Hong composed grand poems and rhapsodies, believing they would endure through the ages. By the time he reached twenty, he reviewed his earlier works and found them unsatisfactory, destroying them all at once.
