*Yilin*, Volume Five
Compiled by Ma Zong of Fufeng during the Yuanhui era.

**Zhou Shengliezi, Five Scrolls**
Preface states: Among the six deluded fools, there was Zhou Shenglie of Dunhuang, styled Wenyì. After the fall of Zhang Jiao, the realm descended into chaos. Within the span of a single sigh, he composed this work, taking Yao and Shun as its pillars and Confucius as its teacher and admonisher.

○ A charioteer who loses control shatters his own carriage. One who loses control of the realm causes the Four Seas to collapse. Jie and Zhou served as the stepping stones for Tang and Wu; Qin and Xiang became the ladder for the Great Han. If the four rebellions do not arise, the four submissions will not ascend.

○ The worthy and wise cannot be lured by appearances, just as one does not set snares for phoenixes or lay traps for qilin. Bo Le chose horses from the lean; the sage selects men from the unrefined. Settling disputes is not as good as preventing them; excelling at quelling chaos is not as good as preventing it.

○ To govern the celestial net, wield the eight handles, move the primordial signs, and gather the multitudes—this is the role of the Son of Heaven. To nurture the people and align with the will of Heaven—this is the duty of the Three Dukes. To uphold public integrity and cultivate order—this is the way of the scholar. To cultivate goodness only at death is too late; to turn back when matters press is too feeble. Those with a foundation build easily; those without struggle to succeed.

○ The turtledove lends its wings to the fledgling; the lamb dons leopard skin—outward semblance belies inner truth, the surface conceals the core. Man is the tongue of Heaven; things are the mouth of the spirits. Heaven is high, Earth is deep—retribution comes late. Words are the sovereign’s bow and crossbow; teachings are the ruler’s mechanism.

○ Bestow rewards as generously as spring; mete out punishments as severely as autumn. Perform rites with the fervor of fire; disseminate teachings with the flow of water. Yield one, gain a hundred; contend for ten, lose nine.

**Xun Yue’s *Shenjian*, Five Scrolls**
Preface states: The Dao is rooted in benevolence and righteousness. The Five Classics serve as its warp; the myriad texts serve as its weft. With past mirrors now clear, this work further expounds them—hence the title *Shenjian* (*Extended Mirror*).

○ When ruler and minister are close yet observe propriety, when the hundred officials harmonize without uniformity—this is the wind of a well-governed state.

○ When customs and rites vary, when the common folk voice their opinions—this is the wind of a declining state. When ruler and minister vie in oaths, when great officers contend for fame—this is the wind of a fractured state. When the ruler is full of desires, when the people are full of schemes, when laws are unstable and governance is scattered—this is the wind of a chaotic state. When exploiting the people is called ability, when flattering superiors is called loyalty—this is the wind of a rebellious state. When petty officials vie for favor, when great ministers vie for power—this is the wind of a harmed state. When the ruler does not consult, when the ministers do not remonstrate, when a woman’s words are heeded and inner politics prevail—this is the wind of a doomed state.

○ The skilled at prohibition first restrain themselves before others; the unskilled first restrain others before themselves. Third: to achieve martial affairs. Fourth: to forbid frequent pardons.

○ When the Qin destroyed learning, books rotted in the walls, and righteousness vanished from court and countryside. To study sageliness without attaining it is still to fulfill one’s life; to study longevity without attaining it is still to fulfill one’s fate.

○ The noble person has three mirrors: the mirror of the past, the mirror of others, and the mirror of reflection.

○ If the subordinate does not seal his mouth, if the superior does not stop his ears, then there is something to be heard.

○ Reflecting on Yao and Shun in high antiquity, gazing upon Confucius in the middle ages—one knows that petty ways are shameful. Thinking of Boyi on Shouyang, imagining the Four Elders on Mount Shang—one knows that filth and falsehood are disgraceful. Recalling Zhang Qian at the western frontier, remembering Su Wu in the northern wastes—one knows that clinging to comfort is contemptible.

**Zhongchang Tong’s *Changyan*, Ten Scrolls**
Teachings take ritual and righteousness as their foundation; ritual and righteousness take the classics as their root. The constant Dao endures for a hundred generations; expedient measures are used for a single moment. Before Gaoxin, we hear of the men but do not see their books. From the Tang, Yu, Xia, and Yin, we see their books but not their full affairs. From the Zhou onward, records are complete.

○ When a foolish heir sees none in the realm dare oppose him, he indulges his private passions and pursues his perverse desires. Ruler and minister revel in debauchery, high and low share in wickedness. Their eyes feast on extravagant spectacles, their ears exhaust the sounds of Zheng and Wei. Indoors, they gallop among women without restraint; outdoors, they race through the hunt without return. They trust and favor their kin, cherish and exalt their empresses and consorts—yet when fate shifts and fortune departs, they do not perceive it.

○ Raising banners and beating drums, lighting beacons and keeping watch—these are the fierce generals who guard the frontiers, not the good officials of the Central States. Jade-belled carriages, cleared roads, deferential courtesies—these are the majestic rites of the Xia, not the customs of the Yi and Di.

○ Dong Xian shared no kinship with Emperor Ai, not even a thread of blood. Nor could he transmit his lineage or secure his succession. Yet through the fleeting pleasures of a man’s embrace, he became as inseparable as lacquer and glue.

○ When Emperor Jing ascended the throne, the regional inspectors were all sons of eunuchs—like jackals guarding meat, like demons awaiting illness. They said: "Within Heaven’s bounds, beyond man’s reach."

○ If others love me, I love them; if others hate me, I hate them.

○ The scholars of the realm have three vulgarities: selecting men by clan and pedigree is the first; flocking to the gates of the rich and powerful is the second; fearing and submitting to the noble and exalted is the third.

○ The scholars of the realm have three despicable traits: craving fame without knowing truth is the first; not daring to judge right and wrong before the rich and powerful is the second; turning toward the prosperous and away from the declining is the third.

○ The scholars of the realm harbor three deceptions: feigning ignorance when they truly do not know is the first; plagiarizing others’ records to craft their own theories is the second; accepting anonymity to claim another’s knowledge is the third.

○ To know the words but not act upon them is called an affliction. This affliction, though treated by the physicians of Heaven, cannot be cured. Why must those who spy on me be lovable? Why must those who differ from me be hateful?

○ Wisdom suffices to establish difficult undertakings; ability suffices to achieve arduous feats. Those near are not favored; those distant are not abandoned.

○ A woman may weep for her good husband at dawn, yet by dusk wed another in a distant land, traversing a hundred courts without a blush of shame. Now, in the palaces of princes and marquises, hundreds of beauties reside; in the households of high ministers, dozens of concubines attend. By day, they drench their bones and marrow in fine wine; by night, they exhaust their blood and qi in the bedchamber.

○ Human nature presents these tendencies: those steadfast as mountains or still as deep pools suffer from obstruction; those stern and unyielding risk alienating others; those vast and unbounded risk lack of restraint; those harmonious and cautious risk indecision; those upright and pure risk narrow-mindedness; those eloquent and persuasive risk garrulity; those composed and deliberate risk tardiness; those who cherish antiquity and uphold tradition risk inflexibility; those bold and resolute risk peril.

Scour the breast and cleanse the heart, making them fragrant and resplendently white, impervious to stain. Dao, virtue, benevolence, and righteousness are of Heavenly nature. Weave them to shape their substance, refine them to attain their essence, polish them to reveal their radiance. In obscurity, even the skilled reveal their shortcomings; in assembly, they recount others’ strengths.

Those who oppose me, I treat with greater generosity; those who doubt me, I trust all the more. In adversity, we must aid one another; in gain, we must yield to others.

○ To serve a lord without earning his recognition is to fall short of true loyalty. To befriend others without winning their trust is to fall short of true righteousness. If parents disdain learning, yet despise their descendants for neglecting study—how can one not defy them to pursue it? If parents scorn the virtuous, yet despise their descendants for befriending them—how can one not defy them to associate with them?

○ Brilliant phrases gather like rain; sublime lines arrive like clouds. Affection and conflict are the nature of fate. Delight and satisfaction in one’s aspirations are what all desire.

○ Drawing the spring from beneath the tongue and swallowing it is called *embryonic nourishment*. Those who attain the Dao grow six wings upon their arms and feathers upon their bellies, soaring through the boundless azure, traversing the endless world. The north is cold, and its people long-lived; the south is hot, and its people short-lived. Like silkworms, when cold and hungry, they draw out more thread; when warm and sated, they draw out less.

After Tang’s Jie, Qin’s Yirang succeeded—Yirang being Gaoyao’s son. *Dian Lun* in five scrolls, by Emperor Wen of Wei.

When Yao passed, Shun avoided Yao’s son south of the Southern River. When Shun passed, Yu avoided Shun’s son at Yangcheng. When Yu passed, Yi avoided Yu’s son on the northern slope of Mount Ji—these events are recorded in the *Records of the Grand Historian*.

Like one ascending a mountain, they strive for greater heights; like one crossing a river, they strive for distant shores.

Should the heart grow idle, even timely efforts may fail.
○ *Ying Chang* states: "Human life inherently possesses a human heart."
   Reply: "Toward kin, it is called filial piety; toward others, it is called benevolence."
   Benevolence is the true name of engaged action, not the emptiness of inaction.
   Praising goodness is the mother of the Dao, the master of one’s conduct.

○ The *Preface* says: "Flattery and corruption pollute governance; favoritism and hatred corrupt customs."
   When a state harbors these two ills, its peril becomes inevitable.

○ During the reigns of Emperors Huan and Ling, eunuchs wielded power at court while commoners clamored in dissent below.
   Those seeking office bribed the mighty with gifts; those chasing fame groveled before the influential.
   Rank was secured through private patronage, reputation forged in alleyway factions.
   Thus, households held divergent views, individuals espoused conflicting theories—debates lacked fixed standards, affairs had no set value.
   Love and hatred grew unchecked, cliques flourished.

○ Guan Yi was extravagant while Bao Shu was frugal—such were their differing aspirations.
   Zhang Lian was pure while Chen Zun was depraved—such were their unequal conduct.

○ Rulers and people share three desires:
   To be deemed diligent, to be deemed loyal unto death, to be deemed life-giving.

○ Law is the ruler’s handle, officials the people’s lifeline.
   Laws should be simple and clear; officials should be impartial and just.

○ The *Book of Songs* satirizes seductive wives; the *Book of Documents* warns against scheming concubines.
   Feng Fang’s daughter, a woman of peerless beauty, fled chaos to Yangzhou.
   Yuan Shu, gazing from the city walls, was smitten and took her as his own, showering her with favor.
   His other wives instructed her: "The general esteems those of noble resolve—you should often weep to feign sorrow."
   Thereafter, whenever she met Yuan Shu, she would dissolve into tears, and he, believing her heartfelt, doted on her even more.
   The wives then strangled her and hung her in the privy, claiming she had hanged herself in despair.
   Yuan Shu, convinced she had died of unfulfilled longing, gave her a lavish burial.
   Yuan Shao’s wife, Lady Liu, was fiercely jealous. Before his funeral rites were complete, she murdered five of his concubines, fearing that in death he might still favor them. She shaved their heads and blackened their faces to disfigure them.

○ Wang Mei, the Prefect of Shangluo, was enfeoffed for his merits. His wife wept in their chambers, dreading that wealth and rank would lead him to take new wives.

○ Liu Biao, Governor of Jingzhou, ruled the southern lands. His sons and nephews grew arrogant and decadent, crafting three ceremonial goblets named for their ranks:
   The eldest, *Bo Ya*, held seven measures; the middle, *Zhong Ya*, six; the youngest, *Ji Ya*, five.
   They also affixed a sharp blade to the end of a staff, using it to slash any guest who drank too deeply, testing their sobriety.
   Yet human form and nature differ little from common creatures: toil hastens early death, ease delays it.

○ I once delighted in playing the *tanbo* at dusk, exhausting all its artistry, and in my youth composed a rhapsody.
   Long ago in the capital, there was a gentleman from the Eastern Lands, Master Zhang of the Fang family, who lamented never having faced those few masters in competition.

○ The *Preface to "The Crown Prince"* states:
   "I have been graced with profound favor, unworthily named heir apparent. Overwhelmed by anxiety, I submitted a memorial to the throne.
   To elaborate with florid prose would dishonor the father-son bond; to speak plainly and directly would fail to convey my joy and fear."
   A village saying goes: *"Do not praise yourself—let others read your family letters."* Such is the difficulty.

*Wei Zi* in ten scrolls:
When the source is still, the stream runs clear; when the root is upright, the branches flourish.
Inner cultivation brings outer order; a straight form casts a true shadow.
Heaven births the noble to govern the base; Heaven births the base to serve the noble.
Without the noble, the base cannot be nurtured; without the base, the noble cannot be sustained.
Record one good deed in a person, and none are worthless; employ one talent in a material, and none are wasted.
People all belittle Mount Hua as small, so they climb it and injure themselves; they revere Heaven as vast, so they never ascend and avoid harm.

○ A tripod is prized for its rarity, while a cauldron is scorned for its common use.

○ In ancient times, a disciple fell ill, and his master visited him repeatedly. Each time the master arrived, the disciple would rise, exhausting himself until he died.
   The master was not unkind, nor was the disciple discourteous—the harm lay in excess.
   Thin ice under a white sun, a tuft of fur in a raging fire: though one may wish to escape harm, the circumstances forbid it.
   The silkworm thrives in the mulberry but perishes in the mustard—not because the mulberry is kind or the mustard cruel, but because it has lost its proper place.

○ The proverb says:
*"If you are right and they are wrong, do not contend with the wrong.
If they are right and you are wrong, do not contend with the right."*

○ The noble person’s outward conduct does not conceal their inner nature; their clarity and obscurity follow the same measure.

○ Bitter toil is the ladder to wealth and honor.

○ Confucius left no contracts with the world, yet his virtue shone forth.

The good and evil of past and present are clear. A mirror reflects ugliness and beauty without reproach; the law distinguishes good and evil without resentment.

*Records of Human Abilities* in three fascicles by Liu Shao:
The finest essence of plants is called *ying*; the mightiest of beasts is called *xiong*.
Zhang Liang is *ying*; Han Xin is *xiong*.

*Renzi* in ten fascicles by Ming Yi:
Learning is for cultivating oneself; teaching is for cultivating others.

○ Joy can inspire song and dance; anger can drive battle.

○ The wisdom of one person does not surpass the folly of the many; the scrutiny of one eye does not surpass the clarity of many eyes.

○ Born in order, raised in order, one who understands the causes of order—this is a noble person.
Born in chaos, raised in chaos, one who understands the causes of chaos—this is a noble person.
One who does not know the reasons for order and chaos is a common person.

○ The embrace of the Dao and virtue among the people is like the spring sun softening the heavens’ roundness—though it does not fit the compass, or the earth’s squareness—though it does not match the carpenter’s square.

○ Mountains must have foothills; rivers must have bends.
The Yangtze and Han rivers flow eastward, yet they must curve and return.

○ A straight tree casts no shade; a forthright scholar has no followers. Thus, the worthy and the upright are seldom tolerated by the world.

○ Ascending Mount Tai, one sees the vastness of the world—this is because those who do not examine the small can see the distant.
Occupying high office, one knows the nobility of the ruler—this is because those who do not pity the lowly are full of self-satisfaction.

○ If one governs oneself with care, one can govern others; if one governs others with care, one can govern the world.

Generations of sages follow one after another; a thousand *li* apart, the worthy stand shoulder to shoulder.

○ Water may dry, but its wetness cannot be taken away; fire may be extinguished, but its heat cannot be taken away. Metal may be softened, but its weight cannot be taken away; stone may be shattered, but its hardness cannot be taken away.

○ The proverb says:
The rich do not learn extravagance yet become extravagant; the poor do not learn frugality yet become frugal.
Human nature is capable of both, but only the sage can regulate it.

Wood-*qi* makes one brave; metal-*qi* makes one steadfast; fire-*qi* makes one strong yet restless; earth-*qi* makes one wise yet broad-minded; water-*qi* makes one swift yet treacherous.

○ The divine dragon does not dwell in waters tangled with nets; the phoenix does not soar over lands trapped by snares.
The worthy do not enter perilous states; the wise do not assist chaotic rulers.

○ Xiao He upheld the written law; Cao Shen avoided harshness. As successive chancellors, the world found peace.
Emperor Wu轻视d human life, prized military merit, adorned palaces, and imposed heavy taxes. Though his territory expanded, his virtue and benevolence narrowed.

○ Huan Tan said: A true king is easy to assist; a hegemon is difficult to aid.

*Profound Discussions* in four fascicles by Du Shu:
Water’s nature overcomes fire, yet when divided by a cooking pot, fire grows strong and water weak.
Human nature overcomes will, yet when divided by profit and desire, will grows strong and nature weak.

○ To examine character and conduct, nothing surpasses local reputation; to assess talent and select ability, nothing is better than direct examination.

The Du clan originated with Emperor Yao. One branch became the Tang-Du clan in Zhou; in the Han dynasty, there were Du Zhou, Du Qin, and Du Du.

○ Du Ji, styled Bohou, has a biography in the *Book of Wei*.
His eldest son, Li, styled Wuzhong, was perceptive from youth, hence his name *Li* (Understanding).
His youngest son, Shu, styled Wubai.

○ Your Majesty says: "In this age, there are no worthy talents; the court lacks sagely advisors. How can we hope to emulate the ancient ministers Hou Ji and Xie, or await the rise of future worthies, and still govern effectively?"

Shu in Hedong would sit and lie down, always avoiding his father’s dwelling.

Shu’s son, Yu, styled Yuankai, has a biography in the *Book of Jin*.

*On Substance* in four fascicles by Du Shu:
Immovable as a mountain, inscrutable as shadow.
One of profound virtue is not questioned on minor faults; one of great deeds is not criticized for small errors.
Even the Pearl of Marquis Sui cannot be without flaws.

○ The minister is like the earth: it bears all things without shirking its burden, receives filth and defilement without rejecting its lowliness, and nurtures plants and trees without claiming their merit.
Conduct is the black and white of honor and disgrace.

○ The noble person chooses their neighborhood when dwelling and selects their companions when traveling.

The governance of the perfected person:
Establishes the state in an unshakable place, accumulates policies in a flawless region, carries virtue in an unceasing chariot, issues decrees from an inexhaustible granary, guides the people along a path of no contention, and enacts laws in a manner that ensures success.
The common people are water; the noble person is the boat. Water both carries and overturns the boat.

○ Shu was careless and indolent, content merely to eat his fill. Though his family had books and records, he barely engaged with them. During his father’s mourning, his conduct often strayed from ritual, and his reputation for filial piety was not heard.
Later, he was appointed Gentleman of the Palace and then Gentleman of the Yellow Gate.
A colleague asked about his aspirations, and he replied: "When great ministers debate, some side with Party A to criticize Party B’s allies, or side with Party B to slander Party A’s allies.
I stand between A and B, fortunate to avoid both praise and blame."

*Master Fu’s Writings* in one hundred twenty fascicles:
Great trees flourish; small trees spread.
Earth is humanity’s mother, so people cherish their homeland.

One may pay a high price for a neighbor, for the house can be bought, but the neighbor cannot.

○ Wearing Yao’s cap while behaving like Jie—one is still Jie.
Wearing Jie’s clothes while behaving like Yao—one is still Yao.
Standing in the marketplace’s shops, dressed in a noble person’s robes, performing the deeds of the wise among petty men—this is like walking at night adorned with pearls and jade, yet still shining brightly.
The spider weaves its web, the bee builds its hive—how exquisite their craft! How much more so for humans.

A thousand taels of gold are not worth one worthy person.
A person without integrity is like clothing without seams or food without flavor.

○ Guo Linzong asked Qiu Zhiji: "Have you ever made a mistake?"
Zhiji replied: "At dusk, I was feeding the ox, and when it would not eat, I struck it once."

It is said: "A scholar is not a jade." Those who praise him speak only of his value, yet the mouths of those who praise are like hearts of love and hate.

○ Excessive wisdom drains the blood and qi, like a lamp’s flame to its tallow—if the wick is large, the light is bright, but the tallow is consumed; if the wick is small, the light is dim, but the tallow endures, and thus may last long.

○ One who speaks boldly but gazes timidly is a hypocrite. One whose breath is urgent and voice heavy is a steadfast person.

○ When Meng Tian built the Great Wall, the people could not bear their suffering, and white bones piled like mountains. Then a song arose:
*"Bear a son—take care not to raise him;
Bear a daughter—swaddle her to serve.
Have you not seen beneath the Great Wall,
Where white bones stand as pillars?"*
Those who forge gold are alchemists who take plant ash and smelt it with metal. Thus, as the plant ash burns, the gold falls away.

*The Supreme Mystery Classic* in fourteen scrolls, by Yang Quan of Liang, styled Deyuan:
Anger is like the fierce winter; joy, like the gentle spring.

○ The luan, the crane, and the phoenix—noble birds of lofty lineage—conceal their brilliance in the forest and do not feed on filth.

○ Inwardly pure yet outwardly tarnished, clad in tattered robes yet bearing jade within.

○ For every ten *li*, nine are pits—oxen and horses rise and fall.

○ Heaven’s qi turns left, the stars move right; yin and yang revolve in cycles, returning to meet one another.

○ The overbearing perish; the obstinate break; the fiercely strong stumble; the greatly sharp dulls.

○ Rushing qi becomes wind; surging qi becomes rain; turbid mist becomes snow; clear dew becomes frost.

*The Scripture of Transformation and Purity* in ten scrolls:
The turbid do not trust the clarity born of the deep but willingly bathe in filth.

○ In action, swift as a tiger’s pounce; in stillness, hidden as a scale-clad creature.

Like that, resplendent; like this, vast and boundless.

○ Those about to take flight fold their wings; those about to surge crouch low; those about to strike retract their claws; those about to speak close their mouths; those about to refine first return to simplicity.

*Zouzi* in one scroll:
To know a person, observe their friends.
Luxuriant weeds in the field leave no place for good seedlings to set their roots;
Flatterers in the court leave no room for the loyal and upright to stand.

○ Do not enter a house with few doors at night; do not brush dust from your meal—these are ways to avoid suspicion.

*On Success and Failure* in three scrolls, by Sun Yu, styled Zhongshu:
Water’s nature is to flow, yet without guidance, it does not course; human nature is to be wise, yet without teaching, it does not flourish.
Learning is like planting—without it, one withers.

○ Secrecy is the juncture of heaven and earth, the pivot of success and failure. Thus, if yin and yang are not kept secret, the summer cannot complete the year; if a house’s eaves are not sealed, even nine stories cannot shelter a body.

*Comprehensive Discourse on Past and Present* in three scrolls, by Wang Ying:
Kunlun’s southeast spans five thousand *li*—this is called the Divine Continent, the dwelling of emperors and the birthplace of sages.

○ Cang Jie created writing: when form is established, it is called *wen*; when sound is complete, it is called *zi*. *Zi* derives from the blossoming and breeding of forms, and when inscribed on bamboo and silk, it is called *shu*.

*The Central Treatise* in six scrolls, by Xu Weichang, with annotations by Ren:
To stand and ponder the distant is not as good as hastening forward to reach it; to crane one’s neck after flying things is not as good as cultivating wings to surely seize them; to live alone and wish for wisdom is not as good as accumulating learning to surely attain it.
The noble person does not worry that his years are waning but that his resolve may falter.
The Dao in relation to humanity is most simple, yet when submerged, it is not spoken of—this is as different from Sima Qian as a leopard is from a horse.

○ One’s passage through the world is like playing chess: if one does not exhaust the Dao, who is without a fatal move? It is merely a matter of misfortune.

*Tangzi* in ten scrolls, by Tang Pang, styled Huijian, born in the second year of the Taiyuan era of Wu:
A boat following the river travels swiftly; a person following the road does not lose their way.

○ A great tree of a hundred *xun* has deep roots; the vast sea of ten thousand *ren* is formed by many streams; profound wisdom and penetrating insight are the work of accumulated learning.

The noble person crowns himself with the Dao and rides in a carriage of the Dao. Without the Dao as his crown, he does not dare to go forth; without the Dao as his carriage, he cannot take a step.

One who has a father yet cannot be filial, a brother yet cannot be respectful, yet lectures others on the duties of father and son, elder and younger—this is like bending a bow to shoot oneself.

○ If human nature possesses even one act of filial piety, then nothing is left unembraced, just as when a tree’s root is planted, a hundred branches grow.

Someone asked: "Between Duke Huan of Qi and Duke Wen of Jin, who was superior?"
Tangzi replied: "In terms of merit, Huan is the elder brother and Wen the younger; in terms of virtue, Wen is the elder brother and Huan the younger."

○ The Great Jin, responding to the mandate of the times, swept all before it like thunder crushing the withered, a thousand *jun* pressing upon an egg—nothing remained.

○ People often suffer from seeing a hundred paces ahead yet not knowing their own brows and cheeks; those who know their brows and cheeks cannot see a hundred paces.

The noble person guards authenticity and wields trust; when the times do not permit it, though he may endure the shame of slander and the filth of hidden defamation, it is but a scratch upon his body.

Eagles in their prime take flight; phoenixes roam afar. When petty men form ranks, the noble person retreats into seclusion.

A saying goes: "No matter how much rouge and powder, they cannot adorn an ugly face; no matter how radiant the ointment, it cannot moisten grass."

○ The ancients were short-sighted in seeing themselves, so they used mirrors to observe their forms; the heart is short-sighted in governing itself, so it uses ritual to guard against transgression.

The noble person does not alter his conduct because of darkness, nor change his countenance because of night.

○ One who possesses a name that towers above the world must bear the burden of defying convention; one who has integrity that transcends the ordinary must endure the calamity of slander and scorn.

White bones resemble ivory; fish eyes resemble pearls—from afar, none can distinguish them.

○ Fortune and misfortune turn into one another; benefit and harm give rise to each other, like a wheel rolling a ball—its signs are unseen, its beginnings unfelt.

○ A good general is like a mountain, like an abyss—people do not know his sorrow, nor do they know his joy.

○ A general must not leave the drums and banners, for they are the army’s ears and eyes.

○ Sudden glory is not dwelled in by the wise.

One who hoards wealth and does not give is called a "money slave."

○ Those who assist in strife are harmed; those who meddle in affairs perish.

*Qinzi* in two scrolls.

Seeking to make white stand out against snow or to race light beneath the sun—this cannot be done.

○ Yan Yanxian once asked: "There is a flavor as rich as wine yet does not intoxicate; its taste resembles millet, yet drinking it brings drunkenness—why is this?" Master Qin replied: "Intoxication lies with the petty man, not with the noble one."

I desire splendor within though plain without, not embroidery outside with hemp within—just as a speaker would sooner exhaust words than道理.

○ What is distant and hard to know is Heaven; what is near and hard to know is man.

○ By means of the axe one obtains the handle; by means of the handle one achieves its use.

Plant a single grain, and a thousand myriad grains flourish; plant a single act of kindness, and the beauty of a hundred deeds is complete.

○ A needle, though small, sinks in water; a feather, though large, floats in water—such is their inherent nature.

*Meizi*, one scroll.

Yi Yin, Lü Wang, Fu Yue, Jizi, Boyi and Shuqi, Liu Hui, Yan Yuan, Zhuang Zhou, and Ruan Ji—had they exchanged places, they could have done what they could not do.

Ruan Ji fulfilled filial piety toward his parents, remained loyal without forgetting his lord, preserved clarity without neglecting himself, displayed wisdom without meddling in affairs, and feigned foolishness without disrupting governance.

Since the time of Zhuang Zhou, among the great worthies of the age, none has been his equal—such was Master Ruan.

According to his writings, he was a man of the Jin.

*Wulilun*, sixteen scrolls.

He who seeks to stabilize the world yet employs petty men is like one who hunts elk while setting snares for rabbits—it cannot be done.

○ Anger scorches like fire on clothing—its damage is great. When the rice in a pot of wrath boils over, one overturns and discards it—loss outweighs gain.

○ As the saying goes: "If those above are not upright, those below will be in disarray."

In ancient times, rulers did not deceive their people: they pared down the rich and powerful to nourish the poor and weak. How is this different from starving the plow-ox to ride the horse, or feeding the barking dog while whetting a lead blade instead of *Ganjiang*?

○ The *Analects* is the ultimate teaching of the sage and the great transformation of the king. The "Xiangdang" chapter contains the rituals of court and the ceremonies of diplomatic reception. The "Yaoyue" chapter records the affairs of abdication and succession.

The literary brilliance in a person is like the flowering splendor of grass.

○ The *Giving Court Gentleman* debated with Gao Tanglong and Qin Lang over the south-pointing carriage. The two claimed: "Such a carriage never existed in antiquity—it is but an empty record." The Master replied: "To dispute over empty words is not as good as testing their effect." He spoke of this to Emperor Ming. The emperor ordered the carriage made, and it was successfully completed.

○ Master Fan Che resided within the capital city, where he possessed land for a garden but suffered from lack of water for irrigation. He thus devised the *fan che* (chain-pump), which a child could operate, increasing efficiency a hundredfold.

Heaven and earth complete a year: spring precedes autumn. The governance of a ruler: ritual precedes punishment. To treat an infant’s illness yet refuse moxibustion, only to administer other remedies until death—this is no different than taking the wrong medicine. Today, those who abolish corporal punishment multiply, yet such abolition is like substituting one drug for another. Though corporal punishment severs a limb, the person may still live and bear children. When Zhang Cang abolished corporal punishment, tens of thousands were executed each year; when Zhong Xian restored it, two thousand lives were saved annually.

○ The term "corporal punishment" is akin to birds and beasts being placed upon the cutting board as meat.

○ If a beloved son were to face the death penalty, his compassionate father would surely beg to substitute it with corporal punishment—exchanging death for life if possible. Can a ruler of the Dao fail to extend this mercy to the people? When a snake bites one’s hand, a strong man severs his wrist, knowing that though the limb is lost, life remains.

○ Cao Yi said: "One tames a spirited colt with reins and binds a fierce horse with a frayed rope." Today, governing the people with lenient punishments is no different than killing them.

○ All know that Guanzi borrowed the ears of the realm, yet none realize that Yao first borrowed the hearts of the people before employing their eyes and ears.

○ Long ago, in the lands between Yan and Zhao, three brothers shared one wife, who bore four children. Later, they disputed in court. Minister Yan Shou memorialized: "Beasts bear young and follow their mothers; the children should be returned to her, while the three men should be executed in the marketplace."

○ Plugging an ant’s hole may stem the flow of a river; securing a chariot’s linchpin may prevent its overturning. Those who establish laws and decrees should likewise grasp the essentials.

○ The *Rites* states: "For a stepfather, one wears *qicui* mourning."

○ Master Fu said: "A mother who abandons her own father to remarry another man severs ties with her brother’s father more severely than if both had cut off all relations with Heaven."

○ Moreover, the *Regulations on Mourning* were likely not composed by Zhou or Kong but fabricated by vulgar scholars after the Qin’s burning of the books.

○ Those who recklessly advance are like eggs hurled at stone; those who flee punishment are like men rushing into a pit.

○ Clamorous as spring blossoms bursting forth, fragrant as autumn orchids flourishing together.

○ A gourd hanging from a tree is not the tree’s fruit; a fur coat worn on the back is not the skin’s own hair—these are resemblances, not realities.

○ The ninth precept speaks of nourishing one’s parents, saying, "Let them hunger." How can one claim they are well-fed if they are often starved? This is surely not filial. A horse fed grain for ten days and starved for one remains robust, with no harm to its well-being—yet one cannot equate this with starving a mother for a single day.

○ At the end of the Han, a man named Guan Qiuyang fled with his younger brother and a companion. When snow fell and their provisions ran out, he said to his brother: "If we do not eat now, the three of us will die together." They killed the companion, obtained food, and reached shelter. Later, an amnesty pardoned their crime.

Could this man be called a virtuous scholar? Kong Wenju said: "Guan Qiuyang cherished the body bequeathed by his ancestors; eating the companion incurred no blame." The Attendant-in-Ordinary Xun countered: "Qiuyang coveted life—how could killing not be a crime?" Wenju replied: "This companion was no sworn friend. Had Guan Zhong eaten Bao Shu or Gong Yu consumed Wang Yang, that would have been impermissible. The one they killed was but a talking beast. Now, if a dog bites a wildcat and the wildcat bites a parrot, what is there to marvel at? In former times, Chong'er clung to the Qi woman and wished to devour Hu Yan; Shu Ao raged at the Chu army and wished to eat Wu Can. Even the wrath of worthies and sages would drive them to consume men—how much more those reduced to extremity?"

○ Seeing but a single stripe, one does not know the tiger’s full pattern. Daoists mock the Confucians’ restraint; Confucians sneer at the Daoists’ abandon—neither perceives the root. Chasing echoes by sound, pursuing shadows by form, contention and dissipation surge without cease.

○ Master Fu said: "Had Meng Ke and Xun Qing been among Confucius’ disciples, they would not have been mere You and Xia, but rather the likes of Ran Min."

○ A pile of firewood stacked like a mountain, set alight at its base—before the flames rise, a single cup of water may yet extinguish them. But when fire rages and wind howls, even pouring forth rivers and seas cannot save it.

○ King Zhao of Qin was the stacked firewood; the First Emperor kindled the blaze; the Second Emperor fanned the gale. The people of Qin regarded the folk of Shandong as a tiger eyes a sheep in the grass—what barrier or fear could there be?

○ Fan Li, styled Shaobo, was a man of the Three Hu of Chu. After his role in the destruction of Wu, he boarded a light boat and roamed the Five Lakes. The king had his likeness painted and daily paid homage to it, ranking him among the immortals of Xuren.

○ The ancestors of the Fu clan descended from Fu Yue, minister to Emperor Yao of the Tang.

○ Xuan, styled Xiuyi, and his son Zai, styled Changyu, have biographies in *The History of the Jin*.

○ During the transition from Chu to Han, an enthusiast compiled the *Generational Origins*, tracing from the Yellow Emperor to the end of the Han. Ban Gu’s *History of the Han* was completed thanks to his father’s work.

○ The highest filial piety nourishes the will; the next nourishes the body. To nourish the will is to fulfill harmony; to nourish the body is not to lose reverence. Seizing land for oneself, the world stands in awe; extending one’s heart to others, the world returns to one. Treating others with sincerity, the world trusts one; without sincerity, even wife and children doubt. If wife and children doubt, how can one serve a lord? The noble person cultivates the self; holding office is not for profit or fame, but for benevolence and righteousness.

○ All know to cleanse their vessels, but none think to wash their hearts. The noble person examines the root before studying, clarifies the Way before acting.

○ Some say Xuan Heng rose to prime minister through fine poetry, and Zhang Yu became the emperor’s teacher through eloquent discourse—was this not the glory of Confucian learning?

○ Master Fu said: "Learning brings honor through the Way, not through rank. I observe Ban Gu’s *History of the Han*: in discussing statecraft, he adorns the ruler’s flaws and suppresses loyal ministers; in expounding degenerate teachings, he values conformity and scorns integrity; in addressing current affairs, he refines rhetoric and neglects facts—he is no true historian."

○ Mozi’s universal love is the abandonment of kinship; his doctrine of mourning is the forgetting of sorrow.

○ Emperor Taizong of Han abolished mutilating punishments—this was the benevolence of a common man, not the benevolence of the world. To endure maiming another’s body yet endure killing them is what is called the benevolence of a common man.

○ Yi Yin tilled the fields of Youxin—who knew he was not a rustic of Xia? Lü Shang did not treasure incense but fished by the Wei—who knew he was not a fisherman of Yin? Only upon meeting Tang, Wu, and King Wen did their true nature become known.

○ One standing at a forked road fears losing the way; one gazing at a high mountain harbors the ambition to soar to the heavens. Some ride horses or chariots to reach Qin—this is what is meant by differing forms but identical substance.

○ If one claims that boats and machines arose only after the Yellow Emperor, what did Fuxi use to cross the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers? Those who traverse vast seas may pass years without seeing their shores; those who plumb the depths of Yu Yuan may live lifetimes without knowing its bottom—thus the near cannot measure the far.

○ In the Han, linchpin carts were despised; now they are prized.

○ Blue and red are called *wen*; red and white, *zhang*; white and black, *ling*; black and blue, *bi*; the five colors together are called *embroidery*.

○ The First Emperor ordered artisans to install crossbow mechanisms in his tomb—anyone who tunneled in would be shot. He used human fat and fish oil to make candles.

○ A hound chasing a hare spends the whole day tracking it, never losing its scent; though it sees a deer, it has no time to glance.

○ Emperor Gaozu of Han was broad-minded and his governance loose, so later generations valued sincerity and simplicity; Emperor Guangwu of Han was meticulous and his governance tight, so later generations upheld convention and propriety; Cao Cao of Wei valued severity amid chaos, so the world refined laws and prized order.

○ When the body is upright, one does not seek the shadow’s straightness—yet the shadow is straight. When the sound is level, one does not seek the echo’s harmony—yet the echo is harmonious. When virtue is lofty, one does not seek fame’s reach—yet fame spreads far.

○ In the western lands, the Hu say: "Storax is an animal." In China, animal excrement stinks; suddenly hearing that western animal excrement is fragrant, one does not believe it.

○ If one insists on Kunshan jade before carving, then uncut jade will never reveal its night-shining beauty. If one demands southern pearls before valuing them, then the Marquis of Sui’s pearl will never earn its "bright moon" renown. The First Emperor’s distant travels along the sea did not spare him the disaster at Pingtai; his burial at Mount Li was soon followed by grave robbers.

○ Now, with lead and tin ore, even if Ou Ye smelts it a hundred times, it will not surpass a clay knife. With a horse of inferior stock, even if Zaofu drives it, it will never match the Flying Hare or the Swift Shadow—its nature is dull and slow. Earth cannot become iron but can become tile.

○ The physiognomist says: "The three pavilions and nine pulses are determined in a face of one foot; foolishness, wisdom, courage, and timidity are revealed in eyes of one inch."

The celestial granaries and golden treasuries distinguish poverty from wealth, lowliness from nobility.

○ Emperor Guangwu soared like a phoenix over Nanyang, while swallows and sparrows transformed into quails. The ministers of the two Han dynasties shone resplendent as the Three Luminaries adorning the vast sky; the soldiers of Changping stood as numerous as autumn grasses beneath heavy frost—such was the force of circumstance.

○ Some giants stand several *zhang* tall, their bodies spanning nine *mu*, two heads upon separate necks, four arms sharing the same bones. Old men growing horns, men and women transforming—what bearing do these have on wisdom or folly?

○ How could the Supreme Unity’s sovereign sit upon a commoner’s seat, or the majestic deity of the Dipper dwell in a humble woman’s chamber?

○ Master Fu said: "Zhuge Liang was truly a man of extraordinary talent in his time. In governing the state, he had his principles; in commanding the army, he had his methods. Through accumulating merit and advancing his cause, he seized the opportune moment. Entering enemy territory, no blade was left unused; departing, provisions remained in surplus. He knew Shu was inherently weak and precarious, thus he exercised restraint to stabilize it. Jiang Wei, however, sought to swiftly establish his achievements—bold yet reckless."

○ Master Ma’s drawloom—Master Ma, named Jun, styled Heng—was the most ingenious craftsman under heaven. The drawloom originally had fifty heddles and fifty treadles, or sixty heddles and sixty treadles. Master Ma reduced it to two treadles, producing intricate patterns and extraordinary variations. Inspired, he created designs that could generate endless yin-yang transformations. The south-pointing chariot is recorded in the *Rites of Zhou* and also appears in the *Guiguzi*. Master Ma refined its mechanism.

○ In governance, nothing corrects position like proper rank; nothing uplifts a state like its people; nothing unifies internal and external affairs like clear divisions; nothing clarifies moral instruction like learning. Grasp the warp, and the weft aligns itself; hold the root, and the branches naturally follow. A wise rewarder, by rewarding one good deed, encourages all good deeds under heaven; a wise punisher, by punishing one evil, eradicates all evil under heaven.

○ In simpler times, officials were few; in refined eras, clerks multiplied. The Youyu dynasty had fifty offices, the Xia a hundred, the Yin two hundred, and the Zhou three hundred. The decline of state canons is like the loss of rank; without rank established, the principles of names and reason collapse.

○ If one selects people by reputation, power shifts downward, and cliques thrive. If one promotes scholars by merit, the virtuous may go unappointed while the mediocre are entrusted with office.

○ The noble person inwardly purifies their heart to receive others with emptiness, while outwardly establishing laws and unchanging principles. Today, people praise antiquity for its many worthies, lamenting the lack of talent in the present age. Yet they do not reflect thrice before speaking of the world—how can this not be delusion?

○ Human nature is like water: placed in a round vessel, it becomes round; placed in a square vessel, it becomes square. When stilled, it clears; when stirred, it muddies. The former kings knew the midstream was easily disturbed, so they guided and instructed, setting fixed laws for those with partial preferences.

○ A dragon boat with its oars aligned—even Wang Liang could not steer it. A team of swift horses moving in unison—even a Yue man dare not rein them. Each has its own ability.

○ Those building a great hall first choose the craftsman, then select the materials; those governing a state first choose their aides, then settle the people.

○ Learning is like thirst driving one to drink from rivers and seas: drinking deeply, one is deeply filled; drinking lightly, one is lightly filled. Observing broadly, one sees broadly; observing narrowly, one sees narrowly.

○ Gold is used for its utility, coin for its light circulation—yet neither can be eaten in famine.

○ Granting official positions in exchange for grain is selling office; allowing criminals to redeem their crimes is indulging evil.

○ When wealth flows through the world, counterfeit coinage is forbidden; when poverty stagnates it, the destruction of coinage is forbidden.

○ No harm befalls the Son of Heaven greater than the adornments of women. A single headpiece may cost a thousand gold, while the garments of maidservants rival the rarest treasures of the four seas.

○ Dukes, ministers, and grandees carve stone into steles and engrave it into tigers. These steles and stone tigers, erected with false grandeur along the three thoroughfares, obstruct merit and corrupt virtue. Heterodoxies arise, the bells of Qin’s downfall are struck, and the licentious music of Zheng and Wei is played—how can governance possibly thrive?

○ Rewards do not avoid the distant and lowly; punishments do not spare the close and noble. The noble have their constant names, which the lowly cannot usurp; the exalted have their fixed positions, which the humble dare not overstep. Weave governance with the warp of Dao and virtue, the weft of benevolence and righteousness, interlacing with ritual and law. Only after completion is it put to use—hence the tribute of Filial and Incorrupt, of Cultivated Talent, where from a thousand *li* away, people gaze in admiration and respond to its reputation. Thus, those who rely on substance gradually diminish, while those who accumulate emptiness grow daily.

○ Hearing one good word or witnessing one good deed, one pursues it fearing they may fall short. Hearing one evil word or witnessing one evil deed, one distances themselves fearing they may not be far enough.

○ A thousand gold hung in the marketplace—no one dares take it, for its portion is fixed. A single coin left on the road—children scramble for it, for its portion is undetermined.

○ The Three Sovereigns valued the Dao and exalted virtue; the Five Emperors prioritized benevolence, then righteousness; the Three Kings prioritized righteousness, then order.

○ A single goose feather sinks in water because it lacks force; a million *jun* of gold floats in a boat because it relies on the boat’s force.

○ Inscribing the Golden Man’s admonition, one composes the *Mouth Inscription*:
The spirit communicates through resonance, the heart expresses through the mouth.
Fortune arises with omens, misfortune comes with signs.
The mind must not be deceitful, the mouth must not be loquacious.
An ant’s hole can breach a river; a trickle can topple a mountain.
Illness enters through the mouth; calamity emerges from it.
The mechanism of survival and ruin, the art of opening and closing—mouth and heart conspire.
The source of safety and danger, the trigger of the pivot—honor and disgrace follow.
With a public heart, there must be a public Dao.

○ Those who love themselves cannot help but love others; those who hate themselves cannot help but hate others.

○ When the people are wealthy, they settle in their villages and value their homes, respect their superiors, and follow instruction. When impoverished, they endanger their villages and scorn their homes, gathering to defy their rulers. Few are those who, pressed by hunger and cold, do not commit wrongdoing.

○ If I wish to fight but the enemy does not, when I drum and advance, it is like a mountain collapsing or a river flooding. Those in its path are crushed; those struck by its force are shattered. This is what is meant by "thunder too swift to cover one’s ears"—who then can resist it?

The Lord of Wu licked the pus from his soldiers’ wounds, accumulating kindness to move his subordinates. As the *Records of the Grand Historian* states: "The Lord of Wu sucked their sores; in daytime battles, they saw one another face to face, and in night battles, they heard one another’s voices. When victorious, they shared the spoils; when defeated, they rescued one another."

Dry-field farming depends on Heaven—though human effort is diligently applied, if floods or droughts come unseasonably, a year’s labor is lost. Wet-field farming is controlled by man; if human effort is properly applied, the land’s potential may be fully realized.

○ Master Fu said: "The Dao of the sage is like Heaven and Earth; the divergences of the various masters are like the four seasons. Though the four seasons oppose one another, Heaven and Earth harmonize and unite. Moreover, the *Changes* differ in approach—mining gold or carving jade requires enduring hardship. If a road is not perilous, one cannot know the excellence of a horse; if a task is not weighty, one cannot know a man’s talent."

When gentlemen meet, they do not merely encourage goodness—they also attack evil. If evil is not abolished, goodness cannot arise. To cure heat, nothing compares to drawing near water; to relieve cold, nothing compares to donning thick furs; to silence slander, nothing compares to cultivating oneself. A skilled angler does not change his deep pool to fish; a gentleman does not shift his seat to pursue the Dao.

○ The petty man feels shame if his face does not resemble Zidu’s; the gentleman feels shame if his conduct does not resemble Shun and Yu’s. Thus, the petty man values a clear mirror, while the gentleman esteems profound words.

○ Archery serves to steady the will; charioteering, to harmonize the heart; writing, to record events; calculation, to order complexity.

○ Profit arrives like a sudden gale or a violent downpour—indifferent to right or wrong, heedless of straight or crooked, it seeks only to avoid exhaustion, and in its impetuous release, victory is assured.

To be discerning is to distinguish—it means skillfully differentiating matters and categories, not merely outstripping others in glib speech.

○ The sage treads upon the loom’s shuttle and grasps its mechanism, comprehending the completion of Heaven and Earth, causing the myriad things to follow their course and human relations to be rectified. Raising a banner upon high makes its signal widely visible; shaking a bell in the wind makes its sound carry far—not because the banner’s colors grow brighter or the bell’s tone lengthens, but because their position is well-chosen. How much more so with the rich and noble issuing decrees!

○ A good farmer does not fret over an unkempt threshing ground but worries over untimely winds and rains; a gentleman does not fret over the failure to establish his virtue but worries over the untimeliness of his era.

○ In the age of the sages, there was no socializing; the Way of Zhou declined, and socializing flourished. In ancient times, associations were close; today, they are distant. In ancient times, associations sought worthies; today, they seek reputation. Appointments bypass the village and clan; conduct is not examined at the inner gate. Those with many supporters are called worthy talents; those with few admirers are deemed unworthy.

○ A horse must be ridden before it can travel far; a physician must be employed before he can cure illness; the worthy must be put to use before they can bring order. *Forest of Meanings*, Scroll Five, ends.

chunks.translated_text:
**Preface to *Yilin* by Dai Shulun, Prefect of Fuzhou**

The Three Sages transmitted their teachings in succession, and the *Great Change* shone forth in brilliance. Thus, the work of Heaven and Earth was established, and the labor of classics and commentaries arose, assisting in the perfection of singular virtue—this is called the Six Arts.

When the Han inherited the legacy of Qin, the Dao was just beginning to flourish. Offices for lecture, study, instruction, and transmission were established to clarify the proper relations between ruler and minister, father and son. Though rites and music were incomplete, this was sufficient to renew the great principles of loyalty, filial piety, benevolence, and righteousness.

As for the writings of Zengzi, Confucius, Xunzi, and Mencius, they number in the hundreds and thousands, all unfolding subtleties, aiding the cultivation of customs, venerating the Dao of the Ru, upholding the law and rectifying names, deploying strategies and establishing authority, adapting to essentials, exalting frugality while maintaining distinctions, aligning with agriculture to achieve order, and proceeding laterally without straying. Yet minor works, though freed from rigidity, vary greatly in length, and few are complete in the collections of scholar-officials.

During the Liang Dynasty, Yu Zhongrong of Yingchuan abridged their essentials into a compendium of thirty juan, intending to broaden the search for diverse teachings. However, the foundation of their doctrines was not always pursued in full.

Ma Zong of Fufeng, a Judicial Reviewer of the Court of Judicial Review, possessed a family collection of histories and philosophers from his youth. He gathered and recorded them, delving into their purport, certain that their meaning must have a destination. Thus, he expanded and refined Yu’s work, carefully selecting from earlier models, and distilled it into three scrolls, entitled *Yilin*. Its purpose is threefold: above, to guard against the loss of teaching; in the middle, to supplement omissions in comparative matters; and below, to aid in the composition of writings. It embodies the essentials of clarity, breadth, purity, and reliability, while avoiding the pitfalls of obscurity, waywardness, rigidity, pedantry, entanglement, obstruction, perversity, and dissipation.

A gentleman has said: *"That which is valued for its brevity—does this not describe it?"*

I, a longtime friend of Yuanhui, have thus composed this preface to record these matters. The twenty-first day of the fifth month in the second year of the Zhenyuan era.

The tradition of *zishu* (philosophical texts) began with Lü’s *Six Strategies* and flourished during the Spring and Autumn and Warring States periods. At that time, the Daoist teachings of Zhuangzi and Laozi arose, their achievements encompassing heaven and earth, their illumination rivaling the sun and moon. They loftily regarded the Six Classics as models for the world, and thus their words were beyond mere praise. Mo Di, a sage of great virtue, expounded doctrines of refined frugality, his teachings enduring for later generations, his renown second only to that of Confucius. The discourses of Guan [Zhong], Yan [Ying], Wen [Zhongzi], and Xun [Kuang] were grand and unbridled; the *Honglie* of Huainan was resplendent in its literary elegance—all these works, numbering tens of thousands of words, may be called abundant indeed. Yet their divisions and volumes were vast and sprawling, making them difficult to peruse.

During the Liang dynasty, Yu Zhongrong compiled an abridgment in three scrolls, sifting away the sand and winnowing the chaff, yet still, orchids and irises were mingled with mugwort and wormwood, and jade ornaments lay concealed within uncut stones. Ma Zong of Fufeng, with his refined devotion to earlier records and pursuit of concision, further distilled Yu Zhongrong’s abridgment, preserving its essence in six scrolls, which he titled *Yilin*. In it, the dregs of the sages and worthies are entirely discarded, while the essential brilliance of the broader tradition is wholly preserved—truly a masterful work.

During the Sui dynasty, Li Wenbo of Boling compiled the *Lidao Collection* in ten scrolls, gathering excerpts from the various philosophers. Yu Shinan, Duke of Yongxing, also drew from earlier histories to compose the *Imperial Survey* in five scrolls. During the reign of Empress Wu, the minister Zhu Yizu further wrote the *Treatise on the Rise and Fall of Ten Dynasties* in one scroll. Together with the *Yilin* of Fufeng, those who have exhaustively explored the broad outlines of *zishu* and histories number four in all.

While adrift in a small boat on the Tu River, detained in Luling, I heard from Fufeng [Ma Zong] of his fundamental aims. He said that in his compilation, he first prioritized matters of statecraft and governance, then preserved the intentions of the original authors, ensuring no chapter or title was lost, as though meeting the ancients face to face. I admired Ma’s work—its brevity of language and depth of meaning—truly one might carry the wisdom of a hundred schools in one’s sleeve or grasp a thousand scrolls in the palm of one’s hand. How far-reaching was his intent!

To commend his admirable achievement, I have set this account at the beginning, that it may be transmitted to those who cherish such endeavors. On the last day of summer in the *dingmao* year of the Zhenyuan era, Wen Fei of Yinghe, styled Boliu, Bosun, has recorded this anew.

**The *Records of Arts and Letters*** states: Master Xiong composed twenty-two *pian*, but today only one *juan* containing six *pian* remains.

To issue policies and decrees that bring blessings to all under heaven is called the Dao. When superiors and subordinates are harmoniously affectionate, it is called harmony. To obtain without seeking is called trust. To eliminate harm from the world is called benevolence. One who is trustworthy and harmonious possesses the capacity of an emperor or king.

When a sagely king holds the throne, even if there is one scholar within a hundred *li*, it is as if there were none. When the kingly Way declines, one scholar within a thousand *li* is like standing shoulder to shoulder.

To know the good yet not trust it is called madness. To know evil yet not correct it is called delusion.

○ Formerly, King Wen saw Master Zhai, who was ninety years old. King Wen exclaimed: "Alas! You are aged!" Master Zhai replied: "If you sent me to hunt tigers or chase deer, I would indeed be old. But if I were to sit and plan state affairs, my years would still be few."

**The Golden Casket of Tai Gong** – *Two Scrolls*

King Wu asked Tai Gong: "The Yin dynasty has already lost three of its men. May we now attack it?" Tai Gong replied: "I have heard that one who understands Heaven does not resent it, and one who understands himself does not resent others. Those who plan before acting prosper; those who act before planning perish. To refuse what Heaven offers is to invite blame; to fail to act when the time is right is to invite disaster. To achieve success at the wrong time is to attain it recklessly. Thus, summer branches may be tied in knots, and winter ice may be melted—opportunity is hard to gain but easy to lose."

○ After King Wu pacified Yin and returned, he asked Tai Gong: "Now the people and officials are unsettled, and the worthy are not yet secure. What should be done?" Tai Gong replied: "Do not alter the old without cause, nor introduce the new rashly—be like Heaven and Earth. Share the wealth of Yin with its people, so that merchants gain their profits and farmers their fields. To see with one eye is not clarity; to hear with one ear is not acuity; to walk with one foot is not mobility. Select the worthy to replace yourself, so that superiors and subordinates each find their proper place."

○ King Wu asked: "May I hear the admonitions of the Five Emperors?" Tai Gong replied: "The Yellow Emperor said: 'I stand above the people, trembling, fearing I may not last from evening to morning.' Thus, the golden man seals his mouth thrice—be cautious in speech. Yao stood above the people, quaking as if on the edge of an abyss. Shun stood above the people, vigilant as if treading thin ice. Yu stood above the people, trembling as if fearing insufficiency. Tang stood above the people, reverent and fearful, daring not to rest. The Dao arises from the subtle, and calamity forms from the subtle. Be prudent from beginning to end, and your integrity will be like a fortress of metal."

○ "Act only after considering rectitude; do not harbor hopes of luck in your sandals. Endure but a moment, and you preserve your body from the blade. Though the knife gleams coldly, do not let it open for you. Though the spring flows smoothly, it will dry up in prolonged drought. Govern affairs with constancy; levy taxes with moderation, like drawing water from a well."

**The Six Strategies of Tai Gong** – *Six Scrolls*

To have the reputation of seeking the worthy but no reality of employing them...

○ King Wen said: "A ruler strives to employ the worthy but fails to achieve success. Why?" Tai Gong replied: "Employing the worthy is not easy." King Wen asked: "How should one employ the worthy?" Tai Gong said: "Examine their virtue, scrutinize their reputation, select their talents, and test their abilities—thus matching name with reality. A trickle unchecked becomes a river; two leaves unremoved will require an axe. A spark unquenched will grow into a raging fire—what then can be done?"

King Wen asked: "Why do rulers lose the people?" Tai Gong replied: "They are not cautious in their associations. A ruler has six virtues to uphold and three treasures to preserve. The six virtues are benevolence, righteousness, loyalty, trust, courage, and strategy. The three treasures are agriculture, craftsmanship, and commerce. When the six virtues are cultivated, the ruler is secure; when the three treasures are intact, the state prospers. If the ruler’s authority is lent to others, he loses his majesty. Deep and boundless, who knows its source? The world is not the possession of one man—it is the world’s world. To seize the world is like chasing a wild deer, and all under heaven share in dividing its flesh."

○ Tai Gong said: "Fu Xi and Shen Nong taught but did not punish; the Yellow Emperor, Yao, and Shun punished but did not pardon."

○ The sage reveres Heaven, calms Earth, harmonizes people, and respects spirits.

○ When King Wen was in Qi, he summoned Tai Gong and said: "My land is small. What should I do?" Tai Gong replied: "Where there is grain in the world, the worthy eat it; where there are people in the world, the worthy govern them. To humble one man is to exalt ten thousand—only the sage can do this."

○ "Though a hat be worn-out, it is still placed on the head; though shoes be new, they are still trodden upon the ground."

○ King Wu asked Tai Gong: "Are there distinctions in the ranks of officers?" Tai Gong replied: "There are nine grades of men. One who speaks ill and is hated by all, yet rises early and retires late, is a leader of wives and children. One who understands hunger and thirst, and adapts to hardship and ease, is a leader of ten thousand. One who trembles with caution, saying, 'Be prudent for a day,' is a leader of a hundred thousand. One who knows the heavens, comprehends the earth, and governs the four seas as if they were his family is the lord of all under heaven. In military affairs, he does not await the ruler’s command."

○ King Wu asked Tai Gong: "I wish my three armies to love their general as parents, to vie in scaling walls when attacking cities, to vie in advancing when fighting in the field, to rage at the sound of gongs, and to rejoice at the sound of drums. Is this possible?" Tai Gong replied: "A general in winter does not wear furs, in summer does not hold a fan, and in rain does not raise a canopy. When the roads are muddy and cold, he dismounts first to walk. Before the army lights its fires, he does not eat. Soldiers do not delight in death or injury—their general knows their hunger, cold, and toil. The harm of warfare is extreme. To raise an army is like startling a beast; to employ it is like madness. Those who face it are broken; those who approach it perish. Make it swift as thunder, leaving no time to cover the ears."

○ "Those who are poor, resentful, and eager to vent their will are called 'men of certain death.' Those who are eloquent, clever in speech, and skilled in slander and praise are called 'men of cunning and slanderous words.'"

**The Book of Master Zeng** – *Two Scrolls*

The noble person cherishes learning as if in love, seizing the moment to achieve success. He does not shun difficulty nor follow the easy path.

chunks.original_text: 曰一就业，夕自省，可谓守业。 年三十、四十无艺，则无艺矣。 至#2五十不以善闻，则无闻矣。 鄙夫鄙妇相会於墙之阴，可谓密矣，明曰或有知之，故云执仁与义莫不闻也。 ○蓬生麻中，不扶自直； 白沙在涅，与之皆黑。 君子之游，芯乎如入兰芷之室，久而不闻，则与之化矣； 小人之游，戏乎如入鲍鱼之室，久亦不闻而亦化矣。 故君子慎其去就也。 ○与君子游，如曰之长，加益不自知也； 与小人游，如履薄冰，几何而不行陷乎。 ○天圆地方，则是四角不掩也。 闻之夫子曰：天道曰圆，地道曰方。 晏子八卷 景公作台，台成复欲作钟。 晏子谏曰：敛民作钟，民必哀。 敛哀以谋，乐不祥。 ○景公璧妾死，名曰婴子，公守之三日不食，肤着於席而不去。 晏子曰：外有良医，将作鬼神之事。 公信之，屏而沐浴。 晏子令棺入殓死者。 公大怒，晏子曰：已死不复生。 公乃止。 仲尼闻之，曰：星之昭昭，不如日月之谖谖。 ○景公时，雨雪三日，披狐白之裘，坐於堂侧，谓晏子曰：三日雨雪，天下何不寒。 晏子曰：夫贤君饱则知人饥，温则知人寒。 公乃去裘冠，足以修敬。 不务其饰衣，足以掩形。 不务其美，土事不文，木事不镂，足以示民也。 ○景公曰：吾欲霸诸侯，若何。 晏子曰：官未具也。 臣闻仲尼处陋巷，廉隅不正，则原宪侍； 志意不通，则仲由侍； 德不辱，则颜回侍。 今君未有能侍，故未具也。 ○君择臣使之，臣虽贱亦择君事之。 ○一心可以事百君，百心不可以事一君。 事贵人不能过，礼贵人恶之。 ○晏子治阿三年，毁声於国，景公召而问之，对曰：婴举俭罚偷，堕民恶之； 央狱不畏强贵，强贵恶之。 是二邪毁於内，二谗去於外。 臣请改辙更治三年，必有誉也。 景公病水数十日，梦与二日斗而不胜，使召梦者占之。 占者至门，晏子使对曰：公病，阴也。 与二日斗，日，阳也。 不胜，疾将退也o．三日而愈，公赏占梦者。 占梦者辞曰：晏子之力也。 公问晏子，晏子曰：臣若自对，则不信也。 ○景公病疽在背，欲见不得，问国子，国子曰：热如火，色如日，大如未熟李也。 公问晏子，晏子曰：色如苍玉，大如璧。 公曰：不见君子，不知野人之拙也。 ○晏子使楚，楚王令左右缚一人作盗者过，王问：何处人也。 对曰：齐人也。 王视晏子：齐国善盗乎。 晏子曰：橘生江南，江北则作根，地土使然也。 今民生长於齐不盗，入楚则盗，臣不知也。 楚王自取弊耳。 ○晏子使楚，楚王以晏子短，作小门於大门之侧，晏子曰：往诣狗国，从狗门入。 今来使入楚，不可从狗门入也。 遂大门入。 ○楚王问：齐之临淄都无人耶。 对曰：临淄三百闻，张袂成帷，挥汗成雨，比肩继踵，何容无人也。 ○曾子将行，晏子送之，曰：赠人以财不若以言。 ○和氏之璧，井里璞耳，良工修之，则成国宝。 习俗移性，可不慎乎。 晏子殁后十有七年，景公封诸侯，大夫皆称善。 公、曰：自晏子殁后，不复闻不善之事。 弦章对曰：君好之，则臣服之； 君嗜之，则臣食之。

"The Master said: 'At dawn one applies oneself to one's work, and at dusk one examines oneself—this may be called guarding one’s vocation. At thirty or forty, if one has no skill, then one truly has no skill. By fifty, if one has not become known for goodness, then one will have no renown.'

When a coarse man and a coarse woman meet in the shadow of a wall, it may seem secret, but by the next day, someone may know of it. Thus it is said: in holding to benevolence and righteousness, none remain unaware.

○ The bluegreen leek grows amid hemp and stands straight without support; white sand mixed with black dye becomes black with it. When the noble person wanders, it is as if entering a chamber of orchids and angelica—though long within, one no longer perceives their fragrance, for one has been transformed by them. When the petty person wanders, it is as if entering a chamber of salted fish—though long within, one no longer perceives the stench, for one has been transformed by it. Thus the noble person is cautious in his associations.

○ To associate with the noble person is like lengthening the day—one gains without realizing it. To associate with the petty person is like treading on thin ice—how long before one falls through?

○ If heaven were round and earth square, their four corners would not align. I have heard the Master say: the Way of Heaven is called round; the Way of Earth is called square.

**The Book of Master Yan – Eight Scrolls**

Duke Jing built a terrace, and upon its completion wished to cast a bell. Yanzi remonstrated: 'To levy taxes on the people to make a bell will bring them sorrow. To levy sorrow for amusement is inauspicious.'

○ When Duke Jing’s favorite concubine, named Yingzi, died, the Duke mourned her for three days without eating, his flesh clinging to the mat and refusing to leave. Yanzi said: 'There are skilled physicians outside who can perform rites for the spirits.' The Duke believed him and withdrew to bathe. Yanzi then ordered a coffin brought in to enshroud the dead. The Duke grew furious, but Yanzi said: 'The dead do not return to life.' The Duke ceased his mourning.

Confucius heard of this and said: 'The brightness of stars cannot compare to the radiance of the sun and moon.'

○ During Duke Jing’s reign, snow fell for three days. Wearing a white fox-fur robe, he sat by the hall’s side and asked Yanzi: 'Though it has snowed for three days, why is the world not cold?' Yanzi replied: 'A worthy ruler, when sated, knows the people’s hunger; when warm, knows their cold.' The Duke then removed his robe and crown, sufficient to show reverence. Without adornment, his clothes were enough to cover his form. Without embellishment, earthworks were left uncarved, and woodwork unengraved—enough to instruct the people.

○ Duke Jing said: 'I wish to become hegemon over the feudal lords. How may this be done?' Yanzi replied: 'The officials are not yet complete. I have heard that when Confucius dwelt in a humble lane, if his integrity faltered, Yuan Xian attended him; if his will was obstructed, Zilu attended him; if his virtue was not humbled, Yan Hui attended him. Now Your Lordship has no such attendants—thus the officials are not yet complete.'

○ The ruler selects his ministers and employs them; though a minister may be lowly, he too selects his ruler to serve.

○ One mind can serve a hundred rulers, but a hundred minds cannot serve one ruler. In serving the mighty, one cannot exceed them; in ritual, the mighty despise excess.

○ After Yanzi governed the district of A for three years, slanderous reports spread throughout the state. Duke Jing summoned him and questioned him. Yanzi replied: 'I promoted frugality and punished indolence, and the lazy resented me; I did not fear the powerful in settling lawsuits, and the powerful resented me. These two evils slandered me within, while two flatterers drove me out. I beg to change my course and govern for three more years—then I shall surely earn praise.'

Duke Jing suffered from edema for several days. He dreamed of struggling with two suns and failing to prevail. He summoned a dream-interpreter to divine it. When the interpreter arrived at the gate, Yanzi instructed him to say: 'Your Lordship’s illness is yin. The two suns are yang. Not prevailing means the illness will soon recede.' Three days later, the Duke recovered and rewarded the dream-interpreter. The interpreter declined, saying: 'It was Yanzi’s doing.' The Duke questioned Yanzi, who replied: 'Had I spoken myself, you would not have believed me.'

○ Duke Jing suffered from an abscess on his back and could not see it. He asked Guozi, who said: 'It burns like fire, its color like the sun, and its size like an unripe plum.' The Duke then asked Yanzi, who said: 'Its color is like dark jade, and its size like a disc.' The Duke said: 'Without seeing a gentleman, one does not know the clumsiness of a rustic.'

○ When Yanzi was sent as an envoy to Chu, the Chu king ordered his attendants to bind a man and pass him off as a thief. The king asked: 'Where is he from?' The man replied: 'From Qi.' The king looked at Yanzi and said: 'Are the people of Qi skilled at thievery?' Yanzi replied: 'Oranges grown south of the Jiang become trifoliate oranges when planted north of it—this is the work of the soil. Now, people born and raised in Qi do not steal, but upon entering Chu, they do. I do not know why.' The Chu king had only brought disgrace upon himself.

○ When Yanzi was sent to Chu, the Chu king, considering him short, had a small gate made beside the main gate. Yanzi said: 'When one goes to a land of dogs, one enters through the dog gate. Now, as an envoy to Chu, I cannot enter through the dog gate.' He then entered through the main gate.

○ The Chu king asked: 'Is the capital of Linzi in Qi truly devoid of people?' Yanzi replied: 'Linzi has three hundred wards. When sleeves are raised, they form a canopy; when sweat is wiped away, it becomes rain. Shoulder to shoulder, heel to heel—how could there be no people?'

○ As Master Zeng was about to depart, Yanzi saw him off and said: 'To give a man wealth is not as good as giving him words.'

○ The jade of He Shi was but uncut stone from a wellside—when a skilled craftsman refined it, it became a national treasure. Habits and customs transform one’s nature—can one not be cautious?

Seventeen years after Yanzi’s death, Duke Jing enfeoffed the feudal lords, and all the ministers praised him. The Duke said: 'Since Yanzi’s death, I have not heard of any wrongdoing.' Xian Zhang replied: 'When the ruler favors something, his ministers follow it; when the ruler craves something, his ministers consume it.'"
