In *The Ten Scrolls of Zhuangzi*:

When water is not deep, it lacks the strength to bear a great boat.

The Perfect Man has no self;
The Spirit Man has no merit;
The Sage has no name.

The sun and moon have risen, yet the torch still burns—how feeble its light!
The timely rain has fallen, yet one still irrigates—how laborious its benefit!

The nesting pheasant in the deep forest needs but a single branch;
The drinking field-mouse drinks from the river but fills only its belly.

The blind have no part in the spectacle of patterns;
The deaf have no part in the sound of bells and drums.
Yet is it only the body that can be deaf and blind? The mind, too, has its deafness and blindness.
Not knowing the ultimate subtlety of the perfect word, one dismisses it as madness and does not believe—this is the mind’s deafness and blindness.

The body may be made still as withered wood;
The heart may be made quiescent as dead ashes.
It is their silence and formlessness that is sought.

Great wisdom is at ease;
Small wisdom is restless.
In sleep, the spirits intermingle;
In waking, the body opens.

Where does the Dao hide that it has truth and falsehood?
Where do words hide that they have right and wrong?
This one deems right and that one wrong;
That one deems right and this one wrong—
Each holds its own negation within.

What is permissible is permissible to oneself;
What is impermissible is impermissible to oneself.

Beyond the Six Directions, the Sage acknowledges but does not discourse;
Within the Six Directions, the Sage discourses but does not debate.
The *Spring and Autumn* chronicles the world’s affairs, preserving the intent of the former kings—the Sage debates but does not contend, neither pursuing gain nor avoiding harm.

One who dreams of drinking wine may weep upon waking;
One who dreams of weeping may go hunting upon waking.
In the dream itself, one does not know it is a dream.
From this perspective, at the moment of death, one does not know it is death but follows one’s will.
Within the dream, one may even interpret the dream—yet this differs not from waking.
Only upon waking does one know it was a dream.
When all one encounters is sufficient, why fret over life and fear death?

Once, Zhuang Zhou dreamed he was a butterfly, fluttering contentedly as a butterfly, self-so and at ease, unaware he was Zhou.
Suddenly he awoke, and there he was, unmistakably Zhou.
Did Zhou dream he was a butterfly, or did the butterfly dream it was Zhou?

My life has bounds, but knowledge has none.
To follow the boundless with the bounded is perilous.
To seek limitless wisdom with finite nature—how can one not be exhausted?

To flee from Heaven and betray one’s nature is to forget what one has received.
What Heaven bestows as nature, each has its proper measure—neither to be escaped nor exceeded.

To come is to follow the time;
Time arises of itself.
To go is to follow the natural course—
The principle of death is fitting.
Abiding in the timely and following the natural course, sorrow and joy cannot enter.
Sorrow and joy arise from gain and loss.
If one follows what one has received, sorrow and joy have no place to intervene.

---

Yan Hui said: “My family is poor; for months, I have drunk no wine and eaten no meat. Can this be called the fasting of the mind?”
Confucius replied: “That is the fasting for sacrifice, not the fasting of the mind.”
Yan Hui asked: “May I inquire about the fasting of the mind?”
Zhongni said: “Unify your will. Do not listen with the ears but listen with the mind; do not listen with the mind but listen with the *qi*. Listening stops at the ears; the mind stops at the tally. *Qi* is emptiness that awaits things. Only the Dao gathers in emptiness. Emptiness is the fasting of the mind. Empty the mind, and the Dao will gather within.”

---

There are two great precepts under Heaven:
The first is fate;
The second is duty.
A child’s love for a parent is fate—it cannot be untied from the heart.
A minister’s service to a lord is duty—there is no place without a lord, nowhere to escape within Heaven and Earth.

---

Yan He was to become tutor to the crown prince of Duke Ling of Wèi. He asked Lián Bóyù: “If I teach him without method, I endanger the state; if I teach him with method, I endanger myself. How should I proceed?”
“The nature of petty men is such that if you guide them with rules, they resent you; if you indulge their excesses, they bring chaos to the state.”
Bóyù replied: “Excellent question! First, rectify yourself.
In form, do not oppose;
In mind, do not resist.
In form, do not force compliance—compliance means complete conformity.
In mind, do not force agreement—agreement means self-promotion.”

---

Mountain trees invite their own felling;
Fat invites its own burning.
Cinnamon is edible, so it is cut down;
Lacquer is useful, so it is slashed.
All know the usefulness of the useful,
But none know the usefulness of the useless.
The useful serves others’ purposes;
The useless preserves its own life.

---

One forgets what should be forgotten yet clings to what should not—this is called true forgetting.
To cherish life and discard death—thus the virtuous are not forgotten by the world.
Profit is what principle does not abide—thus to forget form is not true forgetting.
To forget virtue while clinging to form—that is true forgetting.

---

The True Man of old slept without dreaming—without intent or thought.

The grandee of Húqiū said to Sūnshū Áo: “There are three things people resent—do you know them? Those of high rank are envied; those in great office are hated by their lord; those with ample emolument are resented.” Sūnshū Áo replied: “The higher my rank, the lower my ambitions; the greater my office, the smaller my aims; the richer my emolument, the broader my generosity. chunks.original_text: 其觉无忧。 当所遇而安。 ○不知悦生，不知恶死，与化为体。 其心志，所居而安，日志。 其容寂，虽行而无伤於静。 赓然似秋，暖然似春。 杀物非为义也，生物非为仁也。 ○役人之役，适人之适。 舍己效人，殉彼伤义。 ○泉涸，鱼相与处於陆，相吻以湿，相濡以沬，不如相忘於江湖。 与其不足而相爱，岂若有余而相忘。 与其誉尧而非桀，不如两忘而化其道。 忘善恶，遗死生，与化一者，安知尧桀所在耶。 夫大块载我以形，劳我以生，佚我以老，息我以死。 ○得者时也，失者顺也。 所遇之时，世谓之得。 时不暂停，顺往而去，世谓之失。 安时处顺，一及乐不能入也。 父母於子，束西南北唯命之从，阴阳於人，不啻为父母也。 自古或有能违父母之命，未有能违阴阳之变而拒昼夜之节也。 ○鱼相忘於江湖，人相忘於道术。 各自足而相忘，天下莫不皆能。 至人常足，故常也。 ○长於上古而不为老。 日新也。
chunks.translated_text:
Their waking knows no care.
They rest content in whatever they encounter.

Unknowing of delight in life,
Unknowing of aversion to death,
They embody transformation.
Their minds, wherever they dwell, are at peace—this is called daily resolve.
Their countenance is serene; though they move, nothing disturbs their stillness.
Cool as autumn, warm as spring.
To kill is not for righteousness;
To give life is not for benevolence.

To serve others’ servitude,
To conform to others’ conformity—
Abandoning the self to imitate others
Is to sacrifice oneself and harm principle.

When the spring dries up, fish find themselves together on dry land,
Wetting each other with their breath,
Moistening each other with their foam.
Better to forget one another in rivers and lakes.
Rather than love each other in scarcity,
How much finer to forget each other in abundance.
Better to forget both Yao’s praise and Jie’s blame
Than to extol one and condemn the other.
Forget good and evil,
Leave behind life and death,
Merge with transformation—
How then could one know where Yao or Jie reside?

The Great Clod burdens me with form,
Wearies me with life,
Eases me with age,
Rests me in death.

To gain is but the season’s doing;
To lose is but compliance.
What one encounters in time is called gain.
Time does not pause for an instant—
To follow its flow is called loss.
At peace with the season, in accord with its course,
Not even joy can enter.

Parents command their children—
East, west, south, or north—
And they obey without question.
Yet yin and yang are no less than parents to humankind.
Since ancient times, some have defied their parents’ commands,
But none have defied the changes of yin and yang
Or resisted the rhythm of day and night.

Fish forget one another in rivers and lakes;
People forget one another in the Dao and its arts.
Each self-sufficient, they forget one another—
None in the world fails to do so.
The Perfected Person is ever sufficient,
Thus ever constant.

Though they have lived since high antiquity,
They are not old—
Each day they are new.

chunks.original_text: 填支体黜，聪明离形，去智同於大通，此谓之坐忘。 至人之用心，若镜不将不迎，应而不藏，故能胜物而无伤。 物来则鉴。 鉴不以心，故虽天下来照而无劳心。 ○见经虽短，续之则忧，鹤腔虽长，断之则悲。 自三代以下，天下莫不以物易其性矣。 小人则以身殉利，士则以身殉名，大夫则以身殉家，圣人则以身殉天下。 此数者事业不同，殉身一也。 臧与谷二人相与牧羊而俱亡羊，问臧奚事则挟策读书，问谷奚事则博塞以游。 二人者事不同，亡羊均也。 伯夷死名於首阳之下，盗路死利於束陵之上。 二人死虽不同，其於残生伤性一也，何必伯夷之是，而盗蹶之非，则天下尽殉也。 彼其所殉仁义也，则俗谓之君子； 其所殉货财也，则俗谓之小人，其所殉一也。 至於残生损性，又恶取君子小人於其问哉。 夫不自见而见彼，不自得而得彼，是得人之得而不自得其得也。 适人之适而不自适其适也，虽盗卫伯夷是同为淫僻。 ○纯朴不残，孰为牺蹲； 白玉不毁，孰取珪璋； 道德不废，安为仁义； 性情不离，安用礼乐。 ○夫残朴以成器，工匠之罪也； 毁道德以成仁义，圣人之过也。 ○蹶之徒问於蹶曰：盗亦有道乎。 蹶曰：夫妄意室中之藏圣也，入先勇也，出后义也，知可否智也，分均仁也。 五者不备而后能成盗者，天下未之有也。 五者所以禁，盗不为盗，资也。 由是观之，善人不得圣人之道不立，蹶不得圣人之道不行。 天下善人少而不善人多，则圣人之利天下者少而害天下者多。 ○绝圣弃智，大盗乃止。 摘玉毁珠，小盗不起。 焚符破玺而民朴鄙，剖斗折衡而民不争。 ○嘉怒相疑，愚智相欺，善否相非，诞信相讥而天下衰矣。 ○至道之精，杳杳冥冥； 至道之极，昏昏默默。 ○慎汝内，全真也。 闭汝外，守其分也。 多智为败。 智无崖，故败也。 ○世俗之人皆喜人之同乎己，而恶人之异於己也。 大人之教，若形之於影，声之於响，有问而应之，尽其所怀。 子贡教汉阴为圃者作桔杆，圃者忿然作色而笑曰：夫有机械者必有机事，有机事者必有机心。 机心存于胸中，则纯白不备； 纯白不备，则神生不定； 神生不定，则道不载。 吾非不知，羞而不为。 事求可，功求成，用力少，见功多者，圣人之道也。 ○三人行而一人惑，所适者犹可致也，惑者少也。 ○二人惑，则劳而不至，惑者多也。 ○视而可见者形与色，听而可闻者名与声。 悲夫世人以形色名声为足以得彼之情。 夫形色名声果不足以得彼之情也。 ○夫播糠朱目，则天地四方易位矣。 蚊虻历肤，则通夕不寐。 外物加之虽小，而伤性已大也。 鹄不日浴而白，乌不日黔而黑。 自然已各足矣。 平易恬檐，则忧患不能入，邪气不能袭。 故其德全而神不亏矣。 ○不为福先，不为祸始，感而后应，无所唱也。 迫而后动，会至乃动。 不得已而后起，故无天灾，无物累，无人非，无鬼责。 其生若浮，其死若休。 喜怒者道之过，好恶者德之失，一而不变，静之至也。 静而一者，不可变也。 不与物交，淡之至也。 物自来耳，无交物之情。 形劳而不休则弊，精用而不已则劳。 ○野语有之曰：众人重利，廉士重名，贤士尚志，圣人贵精。 附之以文，益之以博。 文灭质，博溺心。 古之所谓得志者，非轩冕之谓也。
chunks.translated_text:
To still the limbs, dim the senses, detach from form, and cast off wisdom—merging with the Great Flow—this is called "sitting in forgetfulness."

The Perfected Person’s mind is like a mirror: it neither invites nor resists, responds yet does not retain. Thus it masters things without harm. Things come, and it reflects them. Reflection does not engage the mind, so though the whole world be mirrored, the heart remains unwearied.

A classic text may be brief, yet to extend it brings sorrow; a crane’s legs may be long, yet to shorten them brings grief. Since the Three Dynasties, the world has bartered its nature for things. The petty person sacrifices himself for profit, the scholar for fame, the grandee for his house, the sage for the world. Though their pursuits differ, their self-sacrifice is one.

Zang and Gu herded sheep together and both lost them. Asked what Zang was doing, he held a book and read; asked what Gu was doing, he played at dice. Though their tasks differed, their lost sheep were the same. Boyi died for fame beneath Shouyang, Robber Zhi died for gain upon Dongling. Though their deaths differed, their ruin of life and harm to nature were one. Why must Boyi be right and Robber Zhi wrong? Then the whole world is self-sacrificing. Those who sacrifice for benevolence and righteousness are called gentlemen by custom; those who sacrifice for wealth and property are called petty men. Their sacrifice is the same. As for ruining life and harming nature, how can one distinguish gentleman from petty man between them?

To see others without seeing oneself, to gain from others without gaining for oneself—this is to gain others’ gains while not gaining one’s own. To suit others’ suits without suiting one’s own—though Robber Zhi and Boyi differ, both are excessive and perverse.

If uncarved wood is not marred, who would make sacrificial vessels? If white jade is not shattered, who would fashion scepters? If the Dao and its power are not abandoned, why would one need benevolence and righteousness? If nature and feeling are not estranged, why would one need rites and music?

To carve uncarved wood into vessels is the craftsman’s fault; to ruin the Dao and its power to create benevolence and righteousness is the sage’s error.

Robber Zhi’s followers asked him, “Does theft also have a Dao?” Zhi replied, “How could one presume what lies hidden in a room without sagacity? To enter first is courage; to exit last is righteousness; to know what is possible is wisdom; to divide equally is benevolence. Without these five, no one in the world has ever become a great thief. What prohibits these five makes thieves not thieves—it is their resource. From this we see: the good person cannot stand without the sage’s Dao, and Robber Zhi cannot act without it. Since good people in the world are few and the ungood many, the sage’s benefit to the world is slight, while his harm is great.”

Cut off sagacity, cast aside wisdom, and great thieves will cease. Smash jade, shatter pearls, and petty thieves will not arise. Burn tallies, break seals, and the people will return to simplicity; split bushels, snap scales, and they will not contend.

When joy and anger suspect one another, the foolish and wise deceive one another, the good and bad condemn one another, the truthful and false mock one another—the world declines.

The essence of the supreme Dao is dim and obscure; its utmost is murky and silent.

Guard your inner self to preserve your true nature. Close yourself to the outer to keep to your allotted part. Excessive cunning brings ruin. Wisdom has no bounds, hence its ruin.

The common people all delight in those who agree with them and detest those who differ. The teaching of the great person is like a form giving rise to a shadow, a sound to an echo—questioned, they respond, exhausting what is in their hearts.

When Zigong taught the gardener of Hanyin to make a well-sweep, the gardener flushed with anger and laughed, saying, “Those who have machinery have mechanical affairs; those who have mechanical affairs have mechanical hearts. A mechanical heart in the breast leaves no room for purity; without purity, the spirit is unsettled; with an unsettled spirit, the Dao cannot be borne. I do not claim ignorance—I am ashamed to do this.” What seeks feasibility, what seeks completion, what uses little effort to achieve much—this is the sage’s Dao.

When three walk together and one is confused, the destination may still be reached, for the confused are few. If two are confused, the effort is laborious and the goal unattained, for the confused are many.

What can be seen are forms and colors; what can be heard are names and sounds. Alas, the world takes forms, colors, names, and sounds as sufficient to grasp the truth of things. Yet forms, colors, names, and sounds are truly insufficient to grasp that truth.

Scatter chaff before the eyes, and heaven, earth, and the four directions seem to shift. Mosquitoes and gnats bite the skin, and one cannot sleep all night. Though external things may be small, their harm to nature is great. The swan does not bathe daily yet remains white; the crow does not blacken daily yet remains black. Nature suffices for each. Serene and at ease, cares cannot enter, and noxious qi cannot invade. Thus their virtue is whole and their spirit unharmed.

Do not precede fortune, do not initiate misfortune. Respond only when moved, without leading. Move only when pressed, act only when the moment arrives. Rise only when unavoidable—thus there is no heavenly disaster, no burden from things, no human blame, no ghostly reproach. In life, one floats; in death, one rests. Joy and anger are excesses of the Dao; likes and dislikes are losses of virtue. Unchanging unity is the height of stillness. Still and unified, one cannot be altered. Not engaging with things is the height of indifference. Things come of themselves—there is no impulse to engage them. If the body labors without rest, it wears out; if essence is used without cease, it exhausts.

A rustic saying goes: “The crowd values profit, the incorruptible value fame, the worthy esteem aspiration, the sage treasures essence.” Adorn it with ornament, enrich it with breadth—ornament destroys substance, breadth drowns the heart. What the ancients called “attaining one’s aim” did not refer to carriages and caps.

chunks.original_text: 今之所谓得志者，轩冕之谓也。 轩冕之在身，非性命也。 物之傥来，寄也。 寄之其来不可御，其去不可止，故不为轩冕肆志，不为穷约趋俗。 井蛙不可以语於海者，拘於墟也。 夏虫不可以语於冰者，笃於时也。 曲士不可以语於道者，束於教也。 自细视大者不尽，自大视细者不明。 麒骥辟骊一日而驰千里，捕鼠不如狸狂，言殊技也。 鸦鹊夜撮蚤察毫末，昼出瞋目而不见丘山，言殊性也。 ○道无终始，物有死生。 ○庄子钓於濮水，楚王使大夫二人往先焉，曰：愿以境内累矣。 庄子持竿不顾，曰：吾闻楚有神龟死已三千岁矣，王巾笋而藏之庙堂之上，此龟者宁其死为留骨而贵乎，宁其生而曳尾涂中乎。 惠子曰：子非鱼安和鱼之乐耶。 庄子曰：子非我安知我不知鱼之乐耶。 惠子曰：我非子，固不知子矣。 子固非鱼也，子之不知鱼之乐。 全奚为奚据，奚避奚处，奚就奚去，奚乐奚恶。 择此八者莫足以活身，唯无择而任其所遇乃舍也。 ○髑髅曰：死，无君於上，无臣於下，亦无时之事，从然以天地为春秋，虽南面王乐，不能过也。 庄子不信曰：吾使司命复生汝骨肉肌肤，反汝父母妻子，问里知识，子欲之乎。 髑髅曰：吾安能弃南面王乐而复为人问之劳乎。 ○夫畏途者十杀一人，则父子兄弟相戒以盛，卒徒而后出焉，不亦智乎。 故人之所畏者，衽席之上，饮食之问而不知戒者过也。 十杀一人，人大畏之，至於色欲之害而莫肯畏之，斯愚民也。 ○庄子行於山中，见大木枝叶茂盛，伐木者止其旁而不取，问其故，曰：无所可用。 庄子曰：此木以不材得终其天年。 出山舍故人之家，故人命坚子杀鸦，坚子曰：其一能呜，其一不能呜，请奚杀？ 主人曰：杀不呜者。 明日弟子问庄子，曰：山中之木以不材得终，主人之鸦以不材死，先生将何处焉。 庄子曰：周将处夫材与不材之问，似之而非也，故未免乎异。 直木先伐，甘泉先竭。 ○乌莫知於鹧鹏，其畏人也，袭诸人问。 未有自疏外於人而人存之者，畏人而入於人问，此乌所以称智也。 王孙子－卷 舜让天下於子州支伯，子州支伯曰：余适有幽忧之病，方且治之，未暇治天下也。 春耕种足以劳动，秋收敛足以休息。 然尊生者，虽富贵不以养伤身，虽贫贱不以利累形。 ○帝王之功，圣人之余事也，非所完身养生也。 今世俗之君子多危身弃生以殉物，岂不悲哉。 有人於此以隋侯之珠弹千仞之雀，世必笑之。 是何也。 其以所用者重，所要者轻也。 夫生者岂特隋侯之重哉。 ○列御寇不受郑子阳遗粟，曰：君非自知我也。 以人之言而遗我粟，至其罪我也，又恐以人之言，吾所以不受也。 ○子贡问：原宪先生何病也。 原宪应之曰：吾闻无财之谓贫，学而不能行之谓病。 今宪贫也，非病也。 子贡退，有愧色。 知足者不以利自累，审自得者失之而不惧，行修於内者无位而不作。 穷於道之谓穷，抱仁义之道而遭乱世之患，何穷之有。 智者谋之，武者遂之，仁者居之，古之道也。 ○废上，非义也。 杀民，非仁也。 人比其难，我享其利，非廉也。 ○摇屑鼓舌，擅生是非，好面誉人者，亦好背而毁之也。 ○汤放其主，武王杀纣。 自是之后，以强凌弱，以众暴寡。 汤武以来，皆乱人之徒也。
chunks.translated_text:
What is now called "attaining one’s aim" refers to carriages and caps. Carriages and caps upon the body are not one’s nature or destiny—they are but transient things that come by chance, a temporary lodging. Their coming cannot be warded off, their going cannot be halted. Thus, one should not indulge the will for carriages and caps, nor should one follow the crowd in poverty and constraint.

The well-frog cannot speak of the sea, for it is confined by its pit. The summer insect cannot speak of ice, for it is bound by its season. The narrow scholar cannot speak of the Dao, for he is shackled by his teachings. One who views the great from the small cannot see the whole; one who views the small from the great cannot see clearly.

The thoroughbred and the fine steed gallop a thousand *li* in a day, yet they are no match for the wildcat in catching mice—this speaks of differing skills. The crow and the magpie pluck fleas at night and discern the finest hairs, yet by day they stare blindly and cannot see the hills and mountains—this speaks of differing natures.

The Dao has no end or beginning; things have death and life.

Zhuangzi was fishing at Pu River when the King of Chu sent two ministers to approach him first, saying: "I wish to trouble you with the affairs of the realm." Zhuangzi held his rod and did not turn, saying: "I have heard that in Chu there is a divine tortoise that has been dead for three thousand years. The king keeps it wrapped in silk and stored in a casket in the ancestral temple. Would this tortoise rather have died to leave its bones honored, or lived to drag its tail through the mud?" The ministers said: "It would rather live and drag its tail through the mud." Zhuangzi said: "Then go. I too will drag my tail through the mud."

Huizi said: "You are not a fish—how do you know the joy of fish?" Zhuangzi said: "You are not me—how do you know I do not know the joy of fish?" Huizi said: "I am not you, so of course I do not know you. You are certainly not a fish, so it is clear you do not know the joy of fish." Zhuangzi said: "Let us return to the beginning. You asked how I know the joy of fish—you already knew I knew it when you asked. I know it by the Pu River."

What to choose, what to rely on, what to avoid, what to dwell in, what to pursue, what to abandon, what to delight in, what to detest—choosing among these eight does not suffice to preserve life. Only by making no choice and following what one encounters can one rest.

The skull said: "In death, there is no lord above, no minister below, nor the affairs of time. At ease, one takes heaven and earth as spring and autumn—even the joy of a king facing south cannot surpass it." Zhuangzi did not believe it, saying: "If I had the Controller of Fate restore your flesh and skin, return you to your parents, wife, children, and village acquaintances, would you desire it?" The skull said: "How could I abandon the joy of a king facing south to return to the toil of the human world?"

Those who fear the perilous road—if one in ten is killed, fathers and sons, brothers and kin will warn one another and set out only with a full escort. Is this not wisdom? Yet what people truly fear lies upon their sleeping mats and between their meals, and those who do not guard against it err. If one in ten is killed, people greatly fear it, yet when it comes to the harm of sensual desire, none are willing to fear it—such are the foolish masses.

Zhuangzi was walking in the mountains when he saw a great tree with luxuriant branches and leaves. A woodcutter stood beside it but did not fell it. Asking the reason, he was told: "It is of no use." Zhuangzi said: "This tree, by being useless, has fulfilled its natural lifespan." Leaving the mountains, he lodged at an old friend’s house. The friend ordered his servant to kill a goose, and the servant asked: "One can cackle, the other cannot—which should we kill?" The host said: "Kill the one that cannot cackle." The next day, a disciple asked Zhuangzi: "Yesterday, the tree in the mountains, by being useless, fulfilled its lifespan, while the master’s goose, by being useless, died. Where will you, Master, take your stand?" Zhuangzi said: "I will stand between usefulness and uselessness—though it seems so, it is not, and thus I have not escaped strangeness. Straight trees are felled first; sweet springs are drained first."

No bird is wiser than the quail. Fearing humans, it nests among them. No one who distances themselves from others is preserved by them. Fearing humans and entering their midst—this is why the quail is called wise.

*Wangsunzi, Scroll One*

Shun offered the world to Zizhou Zhibo, who said: "I happen to suffer from a hidden sorrow and am just now treating it. I have no leisure to govern the world." Spring plowing and sowing are enough to labor the body; autumn harvest and gathering are enough to rest. Thus, those who honor life, though rich and noble, do not harm themselves with indulgence; though poor and lowly, do not burden their bodies with profit.

The achievements of emperors and kings are but the leftover affairs of sages, not what preserves the body or nurtures life. Yet today’s worldly gentlemen often endanger their bodies and abandon their lives to pursue things—is this not lamentable? If someone used the Marquis of Sui’s pearl to shoot a sparrow a thousand *ren* high, the world would surely laugh at them. Why? Because what they value is heavy, and what they seek is light. Is life not far weightier than the Marquis of Sui’s pearl?

Lie Yukou refused the gift of grain from Zheng Ziyang, saying: "You do not truly know me. You give me grain based on others’ words, and when you punish me, you will also fear others’ words. That is why I do not accept it."

Zigong asked: "Master Yuanxian, what ails you?" Yuanxian replied: "I have heard that lacking wealth is called poverty, and learning without practice is called ailment. Now I am poor, not ailing." Zigong withdrew with a look of shame.

Those content with what they have are not burdened by profit; those who know themselves deeply are not dismayed by loss; those whose conduct is cultivated within do not act without position. To be poor in the Dao is true poverty; to hold to the Way of benevolence and righteousness yet suffer the calamities of a chaotic age—what poverty is there in that? The wise plan it, the martial carry it out, the benevolent dwell in it—this is the ancient Way.

To abolish superiors is not righteousness. To kill the people is not benevolence. Others face difficulty while I enjoy the benefit—this is not integrity.

Those who chatter and wag their tongues, stirring up right and wrong, and those who flatter others to their faces—such people also slander behind their backs.

Tang exiled his lord; King Wu killed Zhou. From then on, the strong oppressed the weak, and the many bullied the few. Since the time of Tang and Wu, all have been the followers of disorder.

ght of indifference. Things come of themselves—there is no impulse to engage them. If the body labors without rest, it wears out; if essence is used without cease, it exhausts.

A rustic saying goes: “The crowd values profit, the incorruptible value fame, the worthy esteem aspiration, the sage treasures essence.” Adorn it with ornament, enrich it with breadth—ornament destroys substance, breadth drowns the heart. What the ancients called “attaining one’s aim” did not refer to carriages and caps.

chunks.original_text: ○人之情，目欲视色，耳欲听声，口欲察味，志气欲盈。 人上寿百岁，中寿八十，下寿六十，除病瘦死。 申子三卷 刘向云：申子，名不害； 河束人，郑时贱臣，学术以干韩昭侯，秦兵不敢至。 学本黄老，急刻无恩，非霸王之事。 三寸之筐运而天下定，六寸之基正而天下治。 ○拓妻不难破家，乱臣不难破国。 一妻擅夫，众妻皆乱。 一臣专君，草臣皆蔽。 ○智均不相使，力均不相胜。 ○鼓不预五音而为五音主。 ○百世有圣人，犹随踵千里，有贤者是比肩。 慎子十二卷名到学本黄老滕辅生 小人食於力，君子食於道。 ○《诗》，往志也； 《书》，往谐也； 《春秋》，往事也。 ○爱赤子不慢其保，绝险者不慢其御。 ○措钧石使禹察之，不能识也。 悬於权衡，则骛发识矣。 ○两贵不相事，两贱不相使。 ○家富则疏族聚，家贫则兄弟离，非不相爱，利不足相容也。 ○不聪不明不能王，不瞽不聋不能公。 海与山争水，海必得之。 ○有权衡者不可欺以轻重，有尺寸者不可差以长短，有法度者不可巧以诈伪。 ○一兔走，百人追。 积兔於市，过而不顾，非不欲兔，分定不可争也。 ○孝子不生慈父之家，忠臣不生圣君之下。 六亲不和育孝慈，国家昏乱有忠臣。 ○匠人成棺不憎人死，利之所在忘其丑。 ○廊庙之材，非一木之枝； 狐白之裘，非一狐之腋； 藏甲之国，必有兵遁。 有意者必先作具。 ○市人可驱而战，安国之兵不由忿起。 燕丹子三卷 丹者，燕王喜之子，身质於秦始皇之世。 ○丈夫耻於受辱，贞女羞於节亏。 ○血勇怒而面赤？ 脉勇怒而面青，骨勇怒而面白。 田光云：光知刑轲者，神勇也，怒而不变，高行厉天，美声盈耳，荆轲之燕。 谓太子曰：光扬太子，高行厉天，芙声盈耳。 轲出卫都，望无路，历险不以勤，望远不以遐。 今太子礼之以旧故之恩，接之以新人之敬，所以不复让者，信知己故也。 ○风萧萧兮易水寒，壮士一去兮不复还。 轲曰：太子若以燕当秦，犹以羊捕狼。 轲乃请樊於期曰：将军得罪於秦，父母妻子皆见焚。 轲为将军痛之。 今愿得将军之首与燕督亢地图进之，秦王必喜，喜必见轲，轲因左手把其袖，右手堪丁鸩切其胸，数以负燕之罪，责以将军之条。 於期执刀自刎，头坠背后，两目不瞑。 太子闻之，伏尸而哭，函盛於期首与燕督亢地图以献秦，武阳为副。 轲不择日而发。 太子宾客皆素衣冠送之易水之上，轲起为寿歌，高渐离击筑，宋臆和之，为壮声之，发怒冲冠，作哀歌，则士皆流涕，二人皆升车终已不顾也。 刻轲至咸阳，秦王大喜，陛戟见荆轲。 轲捧樊於期首柙并地图以次进，旱臣皆呼万岁，秦武阳大恐，刻轲顾笑武阳，前谢曰：北蕃蛮夷之鄙人未见天子，愿陛下少假借之，使得毕事於前。 秦王曰：轲起督亢图进之。 荆轲发图，图穷而匕首见，因左手把秦王袖，右手堪其胸，数之曰：从我计则生，不从则死。 秦王曰：乞听琴声而死。 召姬人鼓琴，琴声曰：罗谷单衣可掣而绝，八尺屏风可超而越，较辕之剑可负而拔。 轲不解音，秦王从琴声负剑拔之，秦王断轲两手，轲因倚柱而笑，箕踞而骂曰：吾为竖子所欺，事不济也。 鬼谷子五卷乐氏注名台 总按其书云：周时有豪士隐者，居鬼谷，自号鬼谷先生，无乡里族姓名。
chunks.translated_text:
Human nature craves: the eye to see beauty, the ear to hear sound, the mouth to savor taste, and the will and qi to be fulfilled.

The longest lifespan is a hundred years, the middle eighty, the shortest sixty—excluding illness, infirmity, and untimely death.

*Shenzi* in three scrolls. Liu Xiang states: Shenzi, named Buhai, was a native of Hedong and a lowly official in Zheng. He studied techniques to serve Marquis Zhao of Han, and the Qin armies dared not approach. His learning was rooted in the Huang-Lao tradition, yet he was harsh and unyielding, lacking mercy—unfit for the affairs of hegemons or kings.

A three-inch basket, when set in motion, can settle the world; a six-inch plumb line, when aligned, can govern it.

A domineering wife can easily destroy a household; a treacherous minister can easily ruin a state. If one wife monopolizes her husband, all wives fall into chaos. If one minister usurps the ruler, all ministers become obscured.

When wisdom is equal, none can employ another; when strength is equal, none can overcome another.

The drum does not belong to the five notes yet presides over them.

For a hundred generations, sages may follow one after another, yet they trail a thousand li behind; only the worthy stand shoulder to shoulder.

*Shenzi* in twelve scrolls, named Dao, studied the Huang-Lao tradition. Peng Zu was his disciple.

The petty man eats by his labor; the noble man eats by the Dao.

The *Book of Songs* records aspirations; the *Book of Documents*, harmonious governance; the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, past events.

One does not neglect the nurse of an infant; one does not slight the driver on perilous roads.

If you place a hook or stone before Yu, he could not discern it; but suspend it from a balance, and even a hair’s weight becomes clear.

Two nobles do not serve each other; two inferiors do not employ each other.

When a family is wealthy, distant kin gather; when poor, even brothers part—not from lack of love, but because profit cannot accommodate them.

One who is neither sharp nor bright cannot rule as king; one who is neither blind nor deaf cannot govern as a duke.

The sea and the mountain contend for water, but the sea always prevails.

Where there are scales, one cannot be deceived by weight; where there are measures, one cannot be misled by length; where there are laws, one cannot be duped by craft or falsehood.

If one rabbit runs, a hundred men chase it. But when rabbits pile up in the market, passersby do not glance—though they desire the rabbit, its portion is fixed and cannot be contested.

A filial son is not born in the house of a kind father; a loyal minister does not arise under a sagely ruler.

When the six relations are not harmonious, filial piety and kindness are nurtured; when the state is in chaos, loyal ministers appear.

A carpenter who makes coffins does not resent the dead—for where profit lies, shame is forgotten.

The timber for a grand hall does not come from a single tree’s branch; the white fox fur robe is not made from one fox’s armpit; a state that hoards armor will surely see soldiers flee.

One who acts with intent must first prepare the tools.

Market rabble can be driven to war, but the army of a secure state does not arise from anger.

*Yandanzi* in three scrolls. Dan was the son of King Xi of Yan, held hostage in the time of Qin Shi Huang.

A true man feels shame at receiving humiliation; a chaste woman feels disgrace at the loss of her virtue.

Is blood-bravery anger that reddens the face? Is sinew-bravery anger that turns it pale? Is bone-bravery anger that whitens it?

Tian Guang said: I know Jing Ke’s courage—it is spirit-bravery. When enraged, his countenance does not change; his lofty conduct pierces the heavens, his fine reputation fills the ears. Such was Jing Ke in Yan.

He said to the crown prince: Guang praises the prince, whose lofty conduct pierces the heavens, whose fair name fills the ears.

Ke left the capital of Wei, gazing at no path, undeterred by peril, unmoved by distance.

Now the prince honors him with the kindness of old friendship and receives him with the respect due a new guest. That he no longer declines is because he trusts in the prince’s recognition.

The wind howls, the Yi River runs cold;
A stalwart departs, never to return.

Ke said: If the prince relies on Yan to resist Qin, it is like using a sheep to hunt a wolf.

Ke then entreated Fan Wuqi: The general has offended Qin, and your parents, wife, and children have all been burned. Ke grieves for you. Now I wish to present the general’s head and the map of Yan’s Dukang region to the King of Qin. He will surely rejoice and receive me. Then I will seize his sleeve with my left hand and stab his chest with my right, enumerating Yan’s grievances and reproaching him with the general’s terms.

Fan Wuqi grasped his blade and slit his throat; his head fell behind him, his eyes still open.

When the crown prince heard this, he prostrated himself over the body and wept. He placed Wuqi’s head and the map of Dukang in a casket to offer to Qin, with Wu Yang as deputy.

Ke did not choose an auspicious day but set out at once.

The prince’s retainers, all in plain white robes and caps, saw him off at the Yi River. Ke rose to offer a toast and sang; Gao Jianli struck the zither, Song Yi joined in harmony, their voices swelling with valor, stirring fury and bristling hair. When they turned to a mournful tune, the warriors all wept. The two then mounted their chariot and drove away without looking back.

When Jing Ke reached Xianyang, the King of Qin rejoiced greatly and received him with halberds arrayed. Ke presented Fan Wuqi’s head in a box alongside the map, advancing in order. The assembled ministers all cried “Long live the king!” Qin Wu Yang trembled with fear, but Jing Ke glanced at him and smiled, stepping forward to apologize: This rustic from the northern frontier has never seen the Son of Heaven. I beg Your Majesty to pardon him, that he may complete his task before you.

The King of Qin said: Ke, rise and present the Dukang map.

Jing Ke unrolled the map, and as it reached its end, the dagger appeared. He seized the king’s sleeve with his left hand and stabbed his chest with his right, saying: Follow my plan and live; refuse, and die.

The King of Qin said: Let me hear the sound of the zither before I die.

He summoned a concubine to play. The zither’s tune said: The single-layered robe of Luo Valley can be torn asunder; the eight-foot screen can be leapt over; the sword at the chariot’s shaft can be drawn by the back.

Ke did not understand the music, but the King of Qin followed its cue, drew the sword from behind, and severed Ke’s hands. Ke leaned against a pillar and laughed, squatting down to curse: I have been tricked by this wretch! My task has failed!

chunks.original_text: 此苏秦作书记之也。 鬼之言远，犹司马相如假无是公云尔。 ○自古及今，其道一也，变化无穷，各有所归，或阴或阳，或柔或刚，或开或闭，或弛或张。 是以圣人守司其门户，审察其先后。 口者心之门户，智谋皆从之出。 ○或遥闻而相思，或前进而不御。 ○世无常责、事无常师。 ○抱薪赴火，燥者先燃； 平地注水，湿者先濡，此类相应也。 ○智者不用其所短而用愚人之所长也，不用其所拙而用愚人之所工也。 ○墙坏於有隙，木毁於有节。 人动我静，人言我听，能固能去，在我而问。 知性则寡累，知命则不忧。 忧累去则心平，心平而仁义着矣。 以德养民，犹草木之得时； 以仁化人，犹天生草木以雨润泽之。 尹文子二卷刘饮注尹文子 序云：文子出於周之尹，齐宣王时居稷下。 余黄初末始到京师，缪熙伯以此书见示，聊定之。 ○名有三科，一曰命物之名，方圆白黑是也； 二曰毁誉之名，善恶贵贱是也； 三曰况谓之名，贤愚爱僧是也。 ○法有四呈，一曰不变之法，君臣上下是也； 二曰齐等之法，能鄙同异是也； 三曰理众之法，庆赏刑罚是也； 四曰平准之法，律度权量是也。 ○有理而无益於治者，君子不言； 有能而无益於事者，君子不为。

This was recorded by Su Qin.

The term "Guigu" suggests remoteness, much like Sima Xiangru’s feigned "Lord Wu Shi." From ancient times to the present, the Dao remains one, yet its transformations are boundless, each finding its own return—now yin, now yang; now soft, now hard; now opening, now closing; now slack, now taut. Thus, the sage guards and oversees its gates and thresholds, scrutinizing what comes before and after.

The mouth is the gateway of the heart, from which all wisdom and strategies emerge.

Some long for one another from afar; some advance yet remain unchecked.

The world holds no constant duties, nor do affairs have fixed masters.

Carrying firewood into flames, the driest kindles first; pouring water on level ground, the damp is soaked first—such are the resonances of kindred things.

The wise do not employ their own shortcomings but instead utilize what the foolish excel in; they do not rely on their own clumsiness but instead apply what the foolish have mastered.

Walls collapse where cracks appear; wood decays where knots reside.

When others move, I remain still; when others speak, I listen. The power to hold fast or let go lies within me, awaiting inquiry.

To know one’s nature is to be free from entanglements; to know one’s fate is to be free from sorrow. When sorrows and burdens depart, the heart becomes tranquil, and virtue and righteousness manifest.

Nurturing the people with virtue is like plants and trees flourishing in season; transforming others with benevolence is like heaven nourishing grasses and trees with rain.

*Yinwenzi* in two scrolls, annotated by Liu Yin.

The preface states: Wenzi hailed from Yin of Zhou and resided at Jixia during the reign of King Xuan of Qi. In the late Huangchu era, I first arrived in the capital, where Miao Xibo showed me this text, and I took the liberty of editing it.

Names fall into three categories: first, names that designate things, such as square, round, white, and black; second, names of praise or blame, such as good, evil, noble, and base; third, names of analogy and reference, such as worthy, foolish, love, and resentment.

Laws manifest in four forms: first, unchanging laws, such as the order between ruler and subject; second, laws of equality, such as the assessment of ability and mediocrity; third, laws governing the masses, such as rewards, punishments, and penalties; fourth, laws of standardization, such as measures, weights, and balances.

The noble person does not speak of principles that, though sound, bring no benefit to governance; nor does he act on abilities that, though competent, serve no purpose in affairs.

chunks.original_text: 捶不贵独工，贵与众共巧。 今世之人行欲独贤，事欲独能，辩欲出掌，勇欲绝众。 田骈曰：天下之士莫不处其门庭，臣其妻子，必游宦诸侯之朝，名利引之也。 ○彭蒙曰：雉兔在野，众皆逐之，分未定也。 鹦豕满市，莫有志者，分定故也。 ○两智不能相使，两贵不能相临，两辩不能相屈，力均势敌故也。 ○专用聪明则功不成，专用晦昧则事必悖。 一明一晦，众之所载。 ○禄薄者不可与经乱，赏轻者不可与入难，处上者不可不慎。 ○尹文子见宣王，宣王不言而叹。 尹文子曰：何叹。 王曰：吾叹国中寡贤。 尹文子曰：国中悉贤，谁处王下，谁为王使。 人有字长子曰盗，少子曰欧。 盗出行，其父在后追而呼之曰盗，盗吏闻，因而缚之，其父呼欧喻吏，遽而声不转，但言欧欧，吏因而欧之，几至於死。 公孙文子－卷 心者，众智之要，物皆求於心。 修心而不知命，犹无室而归。 ○君子行善必有报，小人行不善必有报。 ○乐者，先王所以饰喜也。 军旅者，先王所以饰怒也。 ○舟从流於河而无维橄，求安不可得也。 ○人有三百六十节当天之数，形体有骨肉如地之厚，有孔窍血脉如川谷也。 多食甘者有益於肉而骨不利，多食苦者有益於骨而筋不利，多食辛者有益於筋而气不利。 陆贾新书二卷太中大夫陆贾也 阳出雷电，阴成雪霜。 善言古者合之於今，能述远者考之於近。 道为智者设，马为御者良，贤为圣者用，辩为智者通。 ○秦以刑罚为巢，故有覆巢破卵之患。 ○文公种米，曾子牧羊。 智者所短，不如愚者所长。 近河之地湿，近山之木长。 山出云而丘阜生气，四渎束流而百川无西。 ○众口毁誉，浮石沈木，草邪相抑，以直为曲。 ○犬不夜吠，鹦不夜呜。 家若无声，官府若无事，亭落若无人，闻里不讼，耆老不愁，君子之治也。 玉斗酌酒，金槐刻镂，所以夸小人非厚己也。 晁错新书三卷 高皇帝不用同姓为亲，故能以诛暴乱。 令之所加莫不从，兵之所诛莫不服。 吕后专制，社稷不倾若发。 《汉书》云如带，《公羊》云如钱。 善为政者，士实於朝野，牛马实於陆，乌兽实於林。 上及飞乌，下及虫鱼，载之如地，包之如海。 陛下之地，束西尽冠盖之民，南北极寒暑之和，匈奴不得当一县。 ○号令不时，命曰伤天； 焚林斩木不时，命曰伤地； 断狱立刑不当，命曰伤人。 贾谊新书八卷 寒者利桓褐，饥者甘糟糠。 秦二世立，天下莫不引领而观其政。 是故劳民易为政也。 ○主之与臣，若日与星； 贵之与贱，若白与黑，如身使臂，臂之使指。 天子如堂，草臣如谐，众庶如地，若经制不定，犹渡江无维橄也，中流遇风波，船必覆矣。 ○采铜者弃其田畴，家铸者损其农事。 ○建武函谷临晋三关以备山束诸侯也，不如定地势，使无可备，天下一通也。 ○与正人居，不能无正人也，犹生长於楚，不能无楚语。 ○志有四兴，朝廷之志清以严，祭祀之志思以和，军旅之志精以厉，丧纪之志忧以愁。 ○言有四术，敬以正朝廷之言，和以序祭祀之言，并声气军旅之言，悲不足丧纪之言。 ○翟王使使至楚，楚王夸使者以章华之台，台甚高三休乃至。 楚王曰：翟国亦有此台乎。 对曰：翟王茅茨不剪，彩橡不刻，犹以为作之者劳，居之者佚。
chunks.translated_text:
The hammer values not solitary skill, but skill shared with the many.

People of this age wish their conduct to stand alone in worthiness, their affairs to stand alone in ability, their eloquence to surpass all, and their courage to outstrip the crowd. Tian Pian said: "There is no scholar in the world who does not dwell at his gate, submit his wife and children, and travel to serve in the courts of the feudal lords—drawn by fame and profit."

Peng Meng said: "When pheasants and hares are in the wild, all pursue them, for their division is not yet settled. When quails and swine fill the market, none covet them, for their division is fixed."

Two of equal wisdom cannot employ each other; two of equal rank cannot overawe each other; two of equal eloquence cannot subdue each other—for their strength and position are matched.

Relying solely on cleverness, no achievement is completed; relying solely on obscurity, affairs must go awry. Only with both clarity and obscurity does the multitude bear its burden.

Those with meager stipends cannot be entrusted with quelling disorder; those with paltry rewards cannot be sent into peril. Those in high position must not be careless.

Yin Wenzi met King Xuan, who sighed without speaking. Yin Wenzi asked, "Why do you sigh?" The king replied, "I sigh that there are so few worthy men in the state." Yin Wenzi said, "If all in the state were worthy, who would remain beneath the king? Who would serve the king?"

A man named his eldest son *Thief* and his youngest *Strike*. When *Thief* went out, his father chased after him, calling, "*Thief!*" A constable heard and bound him. The father called *Strike* to explain to the officer, but in his haste, his words failed him, and he could only cry, "*Strike! Strike!*" The officer then struck him, nearly to death.

**Gongsun Wenzi – Chapter on the Mind**
The mind is the essence of collective wisdom; all things seek the mind. Cultivating the mind without understanding fate is like returning home without a house.

The noble person’s good deeds must have recompense; the petty person’s misdeeds must have recompense.

Music is how the early kings adorned joy; military might is how they adorned wrath.

A boat drifting on the river without mooring or oar cannot find stability.

Humans have three hundred and sixty joints, corresponding to the number of celestial bodies. Their forms have bones and flesh, thick as the earth; their orifices and blood vessels are like rivers and valleys.

Eating too much sweetness benefits the flesh but harms the bones; eating too much bitterness benefits the bones but harms the sinews; eating too much pungency benefits the sinews but harms the qi.

**New Writings of Lu Jia – Two Scrolls**
*By Lu Jia, Grand Master of the Palace*

Yang gives rise to thunder and lightning; yin forms snow and frost.

Those who speak well of the past align it with the present; those who recount the distant examine it in the near.

The Dao is established for the wise; horses are fine for the charioteer; worthies are employed by the sage; eloquence is the conduit of the wise.

Qin made punishment its nest, and so suffered the calamity of a nest overturned and eggs broken.

Duke Wen planted grain; Zengzi herded sheep. The shortcomings of the wise do not match the strengths of the foolish.

Land near rivers is damp; trees near mountains grow tall. Mountains emit clouds, and hills generate qi; the Four Great Rivers channel their flow eastward, so no streams flow west.

With many mouths come slander and praise, floating stones and sinking wood, crooked grass suppressing the straight—what is upright is made crooked.

Dogs do not bark at night; quails do not cry at night. If households are silent, government offices tranquil, villages deserted, neighborhoods free of litigation, and elders without sorrow—that is the governance of the noble person.

Jade ladles pour wine; gold cups are carved—these are to impress the petty man, not to enrich oneself.

**New Writings of Chao Cuo – Three Scrolls**
Emperor Gao did not rely on kinsmen for kinship, and so could punish tyranny and disorder. Where his commands reached, none disobeyed; where his troops struck, none resisted.

When Empress Lü held power, the altars of state did not topple—*as if by a hair* (the *Hanshu* says "like a belt"; the *Gongyang* says "like a coin").

Those who govern well fill the court and countryside with scholars, the land with cattle and horses, and the forests with birds and beasts. Above, even to flying birds, and below, even to insects and fish—they bear them as the earth bears all, encompass them as the sea encompasses all.

Your Majesty’s lands stretch east and west to the limits of cap-and-robe-wearing people, and south and north to the extremes of cold and warmth. The Xiongnu cannot equal a single county.

Decrees issued untimely are called "injuring Heaven"; burning forests and felling trees untimely are called "injuring Earth"; unjust trials and punishments are called "injuring Man."

**New Writings of Jia Yi – Eight Scrolls**
The cold find coarse cloth warm; the hungry find husks and chaff sweet.

When the Second Emperor of Qin ascended, all under heaven craned their necks to observe his governance. Thus, governing a weary people is easy.

The ruler and his ministers are like the sun and stars; the noble and the base are like white and black. The ruler employs his ministers as the body employs the arm, the arm the fingers.

The Son of Heaven is like the hall; his ministers like the steps; the common people like the ground. If the system of governance is not settled, it is like crossing a river without mooring or oar—midstream, when wind and waves arise, the boat must capsize.

Those who mine copper abandon their fields; those who cast metal neglect their farming.

The three passes—Jianwu, Hangu, and Linjin—were built to guard against the feudal lords of the mountains and east. Better to fix the terrain so no defense is needed, and all under heaven flows as one.

Dwelling with upright people, one cannot but become upright—just as growing up in Chu, one cannot but speak the Chu dialect.

There are four awakenings of intent: in court, the intent is purity and solemnity; in sacrifices, reverence and harmony; in military campaigns, focus and intensity; in mourning rites, sorrow and grief.

There are four methods of speech: in court, speech is respectful and proper; in sacrifices, harmonious and ordered; in military matters, voices united in vigor; in mourning rites, sorrowful and insufficient.

The King of Zhai sent an envoy to Chu. The King of Chu boasted of the Terrace of Zhanghua, so high one must rest three times to reach it. The king asked, "Does Zhai have such a terrace?" The envoy replied, "The King of Zhai’s thatch is untrimmed, his painted rafters uncarved—yet he deems the builders laborious and the dwellers idle."

The noble person does not speak of principles that, though sound, bring no benefit to governance; nor does he act on abilities that, though competent, serve no purpose in affairs.

chunks.original_text: 楚王大作。 吕氏春秋二十六卷 靡曼皓齿，郑卫之音，伐命之斧； 肥肉厚酒，烂肠之食。 ○雷则掩耳，电则掩目。 耳闻所恶，不如不闻； 目见所恶，不如无见。 强令之笑则不乐，强令之哭则不悲。 不由中心也。 ○流水不腐，户枢不蠹，动也。 形气亦然。 水泉束流，日夜不休，上不竭，下不满。 ○耳有所闻，不学而不如聋； 目有所见，不学而不如盲。 ○戎人生乎楚，楚人生乎戎，则楚人戎言，戎人楚言。 亡国之主，则可化成贤主也。 ○樱桃之为乌所含，故曰含桃。 ○勇凶德，兵凶器。 ○今有利剑，刺则不及，与恶剑无异也。 水出於山而归於海q○恶山而欲海，高下使然也。 人谓兔丝无根，其根不连，属耳袂苓是也。 磁石召针皆相引，犹圣人南面而立，则天下莫不延颈。 周文王使人相地得枯骨，令吏衣冠葬之，天下闻之曰：文王贤矣，泽及於枯骨。 ○齐人好勇者，其一人居束郭，一人居西郭。 幸而相遇饮酒，曰酒须肉乎，各抽刀自割，相啖遂至於死。 ○石可破不可夺坚，丹可磨不可夺赤，性受於天也。 ○鲁有丑者，其父出见美者商咄，反而告其邻曰：商咄不如吾子也。 是至美不如至恶，爱子不知其丑也。 ○人有臭者，其亲戚兄弟妻妾知识无能与居者，自屏乎海，海上有人悦其臭者昼夜随之不离也。 ○赵襄子攻翟胜，方饮而有忧色，曰：江河之大不过三曰，一朝而下翟胜两城，亡将及我矣。 孔子闻之曰：忧所以昌，喜所以亡。 ○管仲为鲁所缚，槛车载之，使役人送于齐，皆枢歌而引车。 管仲恐鲁悔而止之，又欲速至齐国，谓役人曰：我为汝唱，汝和我也。 役人不倦，取道甚速，管仲可谓能因矣。 因役人用势欲走，乃为歌唱劝令走也。 ○有道之士贵以近知远，以今知古，以所见知所不见。 故审堂下之阴而知日月之行，见瓶水之冰知天下之寒，尝一蛮之肉知一擭之味。 有人方且过江，引婴儿欲投於水，人问其故，对曰：其父善游。 其父虽善游，其子未必能耶。 楚国之政，有似如此。 ○不如吾者吾不与处，与我齐者吾不与处，无益我也。 ○周旦云：君子屈於不知己，而申于知己。 ○穴深一寻，则人臂不及，智亦有不至者。 ○乐羊伐中山归，有责功之色。 魏文侯以谤书两筐示之，乐羊北面再拜曰：一寸之书亦止，何须两筐。 ○人骥俱走，则人不胜骥。 居於车上，则骥不胜人。 犹人主争官，事与骥俱走，无异也。 ○目之见也，藉於照； 心之智也，藉於理。 ○无骨之虫不可令知冰，春生秋死，不知冬冰。 十里之问耳不能闻，帷墙之外目不能见，三亩之问心不能知，而欲束至开悟，南抚多钨，西服寿靡，北怀弥耳，何以得哉。 四极之国名。 ○管夷吾、百里奚，霸王之船骥。 绝江者托於船，致远者托於骥。 楚王问詹何治国之道，对曰：何闻治身不闻治国。 国之本在身也。 詹何，隐者。 ○管仲曰：君子有三色，惧然喜乐者钟鼓之色，愀然清净者绩绖之色，沸然充盈者兵革之色。 ○洧水大，有富人溺者，有人得富者尸，请赎而求金甚多，富人党以告邓析。 析曰：但安之，必无买此者。 得尸者患其不赎，又告邓析。 析曰：但安之，必无人更卖，又必无不赎。 言不欺心，言所以喻心。 言於相离，则不祥也。 以绳墨取木，则宫室不成。
chunks.translated_text:
The King of Chu was greatly pleased.

*Master Lü’s Annals*, Scroll Twenty-Six

Lithe waists and gleaming teeth, the music of Zheng and Wei—these are axes that hew at destiny. Rich meats and thick wine—these are foods that rot the bowels.

At thunder, men cover their ears; at lightning, they shield their eyes. To hear what one loathes is worse than not hearing; to see what one loathes is worse than not seeing. A forced laugh brings no joy; forced tears bring no sorrow. For these do not arise from the heart.

Flowing water does not stagnate; a door’s pivot does not rot—because they move. So too with the body’s qi. A spring’s waters bound forth, day and night unceasing, never exhausting above nor filling below.

Ears that hear yet do not learn are no better than deafness; eyes that see yet do not learn are no better than blindness.

Were a man of Rong born in Chu, or a man of Chu born in Rong, the Chu man would speak the Rong tongue, and the Rong man the Chu tongue. Thus even a ruler who has lost his state may be transformed into a worthy sovereign.

The cherry is so called because crows pluck it—hence "plucked cherry."

Courage is a perilous virtue; weapons are perilous tools.

A fine sword that fails to strike is no different from a poor one. Water flows from mountains to the sea—one may despise the mountains and desire the sea, yet high and low determine the course. Men say dodder has no roots, yet its roots do exist, only unconnected—such is the case with *fuling*.

The lodestone draws the needle; all things attract. So too when a sage faces south and stands, none under heaven do not crane their necks. King Wen of Zhou had men inspect the land, where they found dry bones. He ordered officials in robes and caps to bury them. When the world heard of this, they said: "King Wen is worthy—his virtue extends even to dry bones."

Among the brave men of Qi, one lived in the eastern outskirts, another in the west. By chance they met and drank together. "Does wine need meat?" they asked. Each drew his blade and cut his own flesh, feeding it to the other until both died.

Stone may be shattered but never robbed of its hardness; cinnabar may be ground but never robbed of its redness—for these qualities are received from Heaven.

In Lu there was an ugly man. His father, seeing the handsome Shang Duo, returned and told his neighbor: "Shang Duo is not as fine as my son." This is the height of beauty falling short of the depth of ugliness—for a father’s love blinds him to his child’s flaws.

There was a man who stank. None among his kin, brothers, wives, concubines, or acquaintances could bear to be near him. He exiled himself to the sea, where a man delighted in his stench and followed him day and night without parting.

When Viscount Xiang of Zhao conquered the Di and took two cities, he drank with a troubled countenance. He said: "The great rivers do not rise beyond three days—yet in a single morning I have taken two cities of the Di. Ruin will soon reach me." Confucius heard this and said: "Worry brings prosperity; joy brings ruin."

When Guan Zhong was bound by Lu and sent to Qi in a caged cart, the laborers pulling it sang as they went. Fearing Lu might regret and halt the transfer, yet wishing to reach Qi quickly, Guan Zhong said to the laborers: "Let me sing, and you join in." The laborers did not tire, and the journey was swift. Guan Zhong knew how to make use of things—he harnessed the laborers’ eagerness to flee, singing to urge them onward.

The man of the Dao values drawing the distant from the near, the ancient from the present, the unseen from what is seen. Thus by examining the shade beneath the hall, one knows the movements of sun and moon; seeing ice in a jar’s water, one knows the world’s cold; tasting a single bite of meat, one knows the flavor of the whole pot.

A man was about to cross a river, carrying an infant he meant to cast into the water. When asked why, he replied: "His father is a good swimmer." Though the father swims well, does that mean the child must too? The governance of Chu is much like this.

I do not associate with those inferior to me, nor with those my equal—for they bring me no benefit.

The Duke of Zhou said: "The noble man is constrained by those who do not know him, yet expands in the presence of those who do."

A pit one *xun* deep is beyond the reach of a man’s arm—so too is there knowledge beyond human grasp.

When Yue Yang returned from conquering Zhongshan, his face bore the look of one demanding reward. Marquis Wen of Wei showed him two baskets of slanderous letters. Yue Yang faced north, bowed twice, and said: "Even a single slip of paper would suffice—why two baskets?"

When man and steed race together, the man cannot outrun the steed. But seated in a chariot, the steed cannot outrun the man. So too when a ruler competes for office—it is no different from racing alongside a steed.

The eye’s vision depends on light; the mind’s wisdom depends on principle.

A boneless creature cannot be made to know ice—born in spring, dead by autumn, it knows nothing of winter’s frost. A question ten *li* away cannot be heard; what lies beyond curtains and walls cannot be seen; what occurs within three *mu* the heart cannot know—yet one desires to awaken the east, pacify the southern tribes, subdue the western lands, and embrace the northern peoples. How can this be achieved? These are the names of the four distant states.

Guan Yiwu and Baili Xi were steeds for hegemons and kings. Those who cross rivers rely on boats; those who reach far rely on steeds.

The King of Chu asked Zhan He about the way to govern the state. Zhan He replied: "I have heard of governing the self, not of governing the state—for the state’s root lies in the self." Zhan He was a recluse.

Guan Zhong said: "The noble man has three countenances: the joyful mien of bells and drums, the solemn and pure mien of mourning garments, and the surging and brimming mien of weapons and armor."

When the Wei River flooded, a rich man drowned. Someone recovered his corpse and demanded a great sum for its ransom. The rich man’s kin consulted Deng Xi, who said: "Be at ease—there will be no buyer." The finder, worried the corpse would not be ransomed, again consulted Deng Xi. Deng Xi said: "Be at ease—no one else will sell it, and it will surely be ransomed." Words that do not deceive the heart are words that illuminate the heart. Words that divide kin bring misfortune.

To hew wood by the inked line is to build a palace that will not stand.

The envoy replied, "The King of Zhai’s thatch is untrimmed, his painted rafters uncarved—yet he deems the builders laborious and the dwellers idle."

chunks.original_text: 材难得也。 ○引其纪，万目起； 引其纲，万目张。 治民如此也。 庾积水於千仞之溪，谁能当者。 ○戎夷去齐往鲁，天大寒，与弟子一人宿於郭外，寒转甚，谓其弟子曰：可以衣活我。 我，国士也，天下所惜。 子不肖，不足惜也。 弟子曰：不肖人安能与国士衣乎。 戎夷叹息，乃解衣与弟子。 戎夷至夜半而死，弟子乃活。 ○晏子遭崔杼之患，援绥而乘，其仆将驰，晏子曰：安之。 疾不必生，徐必不死。 鹿生於山，命悬於厨。 今晏命有所悬矣。 ○以龙致雨，以形逐影。 类同则相召，气同则相合，声比则相应。 故鼓宫商应，王德不通，民欲不达，此国之郁也。 树郁则蠹，水郁则汗，国郁则万灾聚矣。 天为高矣，曰月星辰、云气雨露未尝休也。 地为大矣，水泉、草木、毛羽未尝息也。 ○冠所以饰头，衣所以饰身。 今人断首以易冠，杀身以易衣，则不知所为矣。 世之趋利似此，亦不知所为也。 ○黄帝之贵亦死，尧舜之贤亦死，孟贲之勇亦死。 相玉者患石似玉，相剑者患剑似昊干将，贤主患辩者似通人。 亡国之主似智，亡国之臣似忠。 子夏过卫，有读史记者曰：晋师三豕渡河。 子夏曰：非者也，是己亥。 ○得十良马，不如得一伯乐； 得十良剑，不如得一欧冷； 得地千里，不如得一贤人。 ○夏不衣裘，非不爱裘也，暖有余。 冬不用霎，非不爱霎也，清有余。 火烛一隅，则半室无光。 骨节早成，身心不长。 吕不韦，始皇时相国，乃集儒士为十二纪八览六论，曝於咸阳市，有能增损一字与千金，无敢易者。 十二纪之礼，此不抄。 淮南子二十二卷 以汤沃沸，乱乃愈甚，犹鞭噬天＃２捶提马而欲教之，虽伊尹造父不能化，任数者劳而无功。 ○色者白立而五色成，道者一立而万物成。 聋者学歌无以自乐。 夫内心不开而强如聋者，校歌出於口，越而散矣。 ○冰迎春则释为水，水向冬则凝为冰。 ○以道为竿，以德为纶，礼乐为钩，仁义为饵，投之江，浮之海，万物皆得。 ○历阳之都，一夕成湖。 历阳，淮南县也。 有一人告历阳毋＃３曰：见城门有血，则有去无顾。 此＃４后门吏告污血於门限，毋便上北山，县果陷水中，毋遂化作石也。 ○越麒蜀艇不能无水而浮，乌号弓溪子弩不能无弦而射。 ○人主诛暴则多飘风，法苛则多虫螟，杀不辜则多赤地，令不时则多淫雨。 ○南方有不死之草，北方有不释之冰。 ○食水者善浮而耐寒，鱼属也； 食土者无心而惠，蚯蚓是也； 食木者多力而愚，麋鹿是也； 食桑者有丝而蛾，蚕属也； 食肉者勇敢而悍，虎豹是也； 食气者神明而寿，龟蛇之类、王乔赤松是也； 食谷者智慧而夭，人是也。 ○昼生者类父，莫生者似母。 ○勇士一人，为三军雄。 ○圣人若镜，不将不迎，应而不藏。 ○乞火不若取燧，寄汲不如凿井。 譬羿请不死之药於西王母＃５，垣娥窃而食之，不知不死之药所由生也。 ○生有七尺之形，死为一棺之土，安知喜僧利害耶。 天地虽大可以短长知之，星月之行可以律历知之。 ○仓颉作字，天雨粟，鬼夜哭。 仓颉，黄帝史臣也。 造文字，则诈伪生，故鬼哭也。 ○今执政者薄德，增刑有似执弹而欲来乌，柙税而欲狎犬。 柙税，挟杖也。 0假舆马者足不劳而致千里，乘舟橄者不假游而绝江海。
chunks.translated_text:
Talented individuals are rare.

Pull its guiding cord, and ten thousand eyes arise; pull its main rope, and ten thousand eyes align. Governing the people is like this. A reservoir gathers water in a thousand-fathom gorge—who can withstand it?

When the Rong Yi tribesman left Qi for Lu, the weather turned bitterly cold. He and one disciple lodged outside the city walls. As the cold grew more severe, he said to his disciple: "You may save my life with your clothes. I am a man of the realm, one the world would grieve to lose. You are unworthy—your loss would not be mourned." The disciple replied: "How could an unworthy man give his clothes to a man of the realm?" Rong Yi sighed, then removed his garments and gave them to the disciple. By midnight, Rong Yi had died, but the disciple survived.

When Yanzi faced danger from Cui Zhu, he grasped the carriage strap and mounted. His driver urged the horses to speed, but Yanzi said: "Be at ease. Haste does not ensure survival, nor does slowness ensure death. A deer born in the mountains may yet hang in the kitchen. Now my fate hangs somewhere as well."

To summon rain with a dragon, to chase a shadow with its form—like calls to like, qi aligns with qi, and sound responds to sound. Thus, when the gong note is struck, the shang note answers. If the ruler’s virtue does not flow, the people’s desires cannot reach him—this is the stagnation of the state. A stagnant tree rots, stagnant water festers, and a stagnant state gathers every disaster. Though heaven is high, the sun, moon, stars, clouds, rain, and dew never rest. Though earth is vast, its springs, grasses, trees, and creatures never cease.

A cap adorns the head, and robes adorn the body. Yet if one severs the head for a cap or slays the body for robes, one knows not what one does. The world’s pursuit of profit is likewise senseless.

The noble Yellow Emperor died, the worthy Yao and Shun died, the valiant Meng Ben died. Those who appraise jade fear stones that resemble jade; those who appraise swords fear blades like Wu and Gan Jiang; a worthy ruler fears eloquent men who seem wise. A doomed ruler may seem wise, and a doomed minister may seem loyal.

When Zixia passed through Wei, he heard someone reading from the historical records: "The Jin army’s three pigs crossed the river." Zixia said: "That is incorrect—it was the day *ji-hai*."

To gain ten fine horses is not as good as gaining one Bo Le; to gain ten fine swords is not as good as gaining one Ou Leng; to gain a thousand *li* of land is not as good as gaining one worthy man.

In summer, one does not wear furs—not from lack of love for furs, but because warmth is already sufficient. In winter, one does not use a fan—not from lack of love for the fan, but because coolness is already sufficient. A torch illuminates one corner, leaving half the room in darkness. If the bones harden early, the body and mind will not grow.

Lü Buwei, Chancellor under the First Emperor, assembled scholars to compile the *Twelve Records*, *Eight Surveys*, and *Six Discourses*. Displayed in the Xianyang marketplace, it was said that anyone who could add or remove a single word would be rewarded with a thousand gold—yet none dared alter it. The rituals of the *Twelve Records* are not transcribed here.

The *Huainanzi* in twenty-two scrolls states: Pouring boiling water on boiling water only makes the chaos worse, just as whipping the sky or striking a horse will not teach it—even Yi Yin or Zao Fu could not transform it. Those who rely on schemes labor in vain.

White stands alone, yet the five colors arise from it; the Dao stands alone, yet the ten thousand things arise from it. A deaf man learns songs but cannot enjoy them. One whose heart is closed yet forces himself to mimic the deaf emits songs from his mouth, only for them to scatter like mist.

Ice meets spring and melts into water; water faces winter and freezes into ice.

Use the Dao as the fishing rod, virtue as the line, ritual and music as the hook, benevolence and righteousness as the bait. Cast it into the river, float it in the sea, and the ten thousand things will be caught.

The city of Liyang became a lake in a single night. Liyang was a county in Huainan. Someone warned the magistrate of Liyang: "If you see blood on the city gate, flee without looking back." Later, a gatekeeper reported blood on the threshold. The magistrate fled to the northern mountains, and the city sank beneath the waters—he himself turned to stone.

A Yue canoe or Shu raft cannot float without water; the Wu Hao bow or Xizi crossbow cannot shoot without a string.

When the ruler punishes the violent, many whirlwinds arise; when laws are harsh, many pests appear; when the innocent are killed, the land turns red; when decrees are untimely, excessive rains fall.

In the south grows the herb of immortality; in the north lies ice that never melts.

Those who drink water are skilled at floating and endure the cold—they are fish. Those who eat earth have no hearts yet are kind—they are earthworms. Those who eat wood are strong yet foolish—they are deer. Those who eat mulberry leaves produce silk—they are silkworms. Those who eat meat are brave and fierce—they are tigers and leopards. Those who consume qi are spiritually enlightened and long-lived—they are turtles, snakes, Wang Qiao, and Chi Song. Those who eat grain are wise yet short-lived—they are humans.

Those born by day resemble their fathers; those born at night resemble their mothers.

A single brave warrior is the hero of three armies.

The sage is like a mirror: neither advancing nor retreating, responding yet not storing.

Begging for fire is not as good as taking flint; borrowing water is not as good as digging a well. Like Yi, who sought the elixir of immortality from the Queen Mother of the West, Chang’e stole and consumed it—yet she did not know from whence the elixir of immortality came.

In life, one has a seven-foot form; in death, one becomes a clod of earth in a coffin. How can one know the joys and sorrows, the gains and losses? Though heaven and earth are vast, their dimensions can be measured; the movements of the stars and moon can be known through calendars and calculations.

When Cang Jie created writing, grain rained from the sky, and ghosts wept at night. Cang Jie was the historian of the Yellow Emperor. Once writing was invented, deceit and falsehood arose—hence the ghosts wept.

Today’s rulers, with meager virtue, increase punishments, like holding a sling to lure birds or carrying a staff to tame dogs. A caged dog, though restrained, is not truly tamed.

Those who ride carriages and horses travel a thousand *li* without wearying their feet; those who board boats and oars cross rivers and seas without swimming.

one recovered his corpse and demanded a great sum for its ransom. The rich man’s kin consulted Deng Xi, who said: "Be at ease—there will be no buyer." The finder, worried the corpse would not be ransomed, again consulted Deng Xi. Deng Xi said: "Be at ease—no one else will sell it, and it will surely be ransomed." Words that do not deceive the heart are words that illuminate the heart. Words that divide kin bring misfortune.

To hew wood by the inked line is to build a palace that will not stand.

chunks.original_text: 譬智不任已才力，木击折轴，水戾破舟，不怨木石而罪巧拙。 何也。 智有不周。 ○债少者易偿，职寡者易守。 ○风疾而波兴，木茂而乌集，相生之势。 ○文王智而好问，故圣； 武王勇而好问，胜。 ○力胜其任，则举之者不重； 能其事，则为之者不难。 ○天下之物莫凶於溪毒，良医藏之，有所用也。 草莽犹不可弃，况复人乎。 溪毒，附子也。 0十围之木能持千钧之屋，五寸之挞能制门阖，非材有巨细，所居要耳。 使孔墨为天下，天下尽儒墨，得其要也。
chunks.translated_text:
Just as intelligence fails to match one’s own abilities—wood strikes and the axle snaps, water rages and the boat shatters—one does not blame the wood or stone but faults the skill or clumsiness. Why? Because intelligence has its limits.

A small debt is easily repaid; a light duty is easily kept. A swift wind stirs waves; lush trees draw flocks of birds—such is the momentum of mutual generation.

King Wen was wise yet fond of inquiry, hence his sagacity; King Wu was brave yet fond of inquiry, hence his victory.

When strength exceeds the task, the bearer feels no weight; when ability matches the work, the doer finds no difficulty.

Of all things under heaven, none is more perilous than *xidu*; yet a skilled physician stores it, for it has its use. *Xidu* is *fuzi*. Even worthless weeds must not be discarded—how much less a person?

A tree ten spans in girth can support a house of a thousand *jun*; a bolt five inches long can secure a gate’s opening and closing. Not that the material differs in size, but that its position is crucial.

Were Confucius and Mozi to govern the world, the world would become wholly Confucian or Mohist—such is the power of grasping the essential.

chunks.original_text: ○圣人之道若中衢置坛，过者斟酌，虽多少不同而各得其宜也。 衢，六通，蹲，酒缚。 ○三月婴儿未知利害，而慈母爱焉，情也。 ○慈父爱子，圣王养民，若火自热，若冰自寒，性使然也。 及其用力，赖其功，如失火舟中矣。 同心救火也。 ○车无三寸辖则不可驰，户无五寸挞则不可闭。 故君子所须要也。 ○治国者若张琴瑟，大弦组，小弦绝。 ○治国者若设网，引其纲，万目张。 ○多欲亏义、多忧害智，多惧妨勇。 ○虎豹以文彩射，谖狄以捷来刺。 故子路以勇死，长幼以智困。 吹灰而欲无咪，涉水而欲无濡，不可得也。 ○广厦宏屋，连阖通房，人所安也，乌入之而忧。 深林药，人入而畏，乌入之则安。 深溪峭，峻木寻枝，缓狄所乐，人则栗也。 ○翻基丸於地，圆者走泽，方者处高。 ○戴哀者闻歌而泣，戴乐者见哭而笑，强哭者虽戚不哀，强欢者虽笑不乐。 ○刍狗土龙始成，则衣以绮绣，及其用毕，则弃之土壤。 刍狗事以谢过，土龙事以请雨，察道通物，名异得道一也。 犹屠牛而烹其肉，或甘剂万方，本一牛也。 ○伐豫章，或为棺椁，或为梁柱，亦一木也。 ○萧条者形之君，寂寞者音之主。 ○客有见子贱，贱曰：客独有三过：望我而笑，是慢也； 交浅而言深，是患也； 语不称名，是反也。 客一体耳，或为君子，或为小人，此视之异也。 待腰裹飞兔而驾之，则世莫有乘者； 待毛墙西施而配之，则终身无家矣； 待古英俊而用之，则无人矣。 骥千里一日而通，驾驽马十驾旬日亦至，犹人才不足专恃。 乌穷则啄，兽穷则触，人穷则诈。 峻刑严法，不可以禁奸。 ○道德之论，譬如日月，江南河北不能易其指，驰骛千里不能改其处。 ○趣舍礼裕，犹宅之居也，东家谓之西，西家谓之束，扣门求火无不与者，饶足也。 故林中不货薪，湖上不斋鱼者，有余也。 ○不乘人之利，不迫人之险。 ○叔向云墨者曰：鸠欲见秦惠王，三年不得见。 一至楚，楚王悦之。 物固有近而之远，远之而近。 故一之以袅。 大丈夫行不可掩。 ○未得兽者唯恐创少，已得唯恐创多。 ○古人婚礼不称主人，必称父母兄弟。 舜不告瞽叟而娶，非礼。 文王立伯邑可，非制。 礼三十而家，文王十六而生，非法。 ○治国有常，利民为政，本教有经，令行为上。 苟利其心，不必法古； 苟周於事，不必循常。 法度制令，各因其宜，变古未可非，循俗不足多。 百川异源皆归於海，百家异业皆务於治。 ○盲者行於道，人谓左则左，谓右则右，遇君子则得其平易，遇小人则陷於沟壑。 ○束面而望不见西墙，南向而视不睹北方，唯无向者无所不通。 ○父溺则揽父发而拯之，非敢骄侮，以救死也。 至赏不费，至刑不滥。 ○乘船遇风，波至而恐死，自投於水中，非不贵生畏死，惑於畏死而反忘生也。 ○人之嗜欲者亦复如此。 ○溜水足以溢壶梳，江河不能满漏卮。 ○醉者赴淮，以为寻常之沟； 倪入城门，以为七尺之闺，酒浊其神也。 马兔人於难者，死，葬之以盖，蒙牛有德於人，葬之以大车。 ○用兵之道，示之以柔，乘之以刚； 示之以弱，乘之以强。 若欲西者示之以束，使知吾所出而不知吾所入，若鬼无迹，若水无创，若电之激，不可备也。 高城深池，矢石如雨，广泽平原，白刃交接，士卒争先者，为其赏信罚明也。
chunks.translated_text:
The Dao of the sage is like setting up an altar at a crossroads—passersby draw from it as they will, each taking what suits them, though the amounts differ.

A crossroads is where six roads meet; *dūn* means "to squat," *jiǔfù* refers to a wine vessel.

A three-month-old infant knows nothing of profit or harm, yet a loving mother cherishes it—such is the nature of affection.

A kind father loves his child, a sage king nurtures his people, as fire is naturally hot, as ice is naturally cold—this is the way of their nature. But when it comes to exerting effort, one relies on its results, like fighting a fire aboard a boat. All hearts unite to save it.

A chariot without a three-inch linchpin cannot be driven; a door without a five-inch bolt cannot be secured. Thus, the noble person values what is essential.

Governing a state is like tuning a zither or lute: if the thick strings are slack, the thin strings will snap.

Governing a state is like setting a net: pull the main rope, and all the meshes open.

Excessive desires harm righteousness; excessive worries impair wisdom; excessive fear undermines courage.

Tigers and leopards are hunted for their patterned hides; the *Xuāndí* are lured by their agility to be stabbed. Thus, Zilu died for his bravery, while the wise and foolish alike may be trapped by their own cunning. One who blows away dust yet wishes not to be speckled, or wades through water yet wishes not to get wet—this cannot be.

Grand mansions with connected halls and chambers are where people find comfort, yet birds entering them grow anxious. Dense forests and thickets are where people feel fear, yet birds find safety there. Deep ravines and towering trees with sprawling branches are where the *Huándí* delight, yet people shudder at the sight.

When a round pellet is rolled on the ground, the spherical one rolls into the marsh, while the square one rests on high ground.

One in mourning hears music and weeps; one in joy sees tears and laughs. Those who force themselves to weep may appear sorrowful yet feel no grief; those who force themselves to laugh may smile yet feel no joy.

Straw dogs and clay dragons, when first made, are dressed in fine silks and brocades; once their use is done, they are discarded in the dirt. Straw dogs are used in rituals to atone for faults; clay dragons are used to pray for rain. Though their names differ, they share the same principle—just as a butchered ox may be cooked in countless ways, yet it remains one ox.

When a *yúzhāng* tree is felled, some parts become coffins, others beams and pillars—yet it is the same wood.

Desolation is the ruler of form; silence is the master of sound.

A guest once visited Zijian, who said: "You alone commit three faults: smiling when you see me is insolence; speaking intimately despite our shallow acquaintance is recklessness; and not addressing me by name is perversity." The same person may be a gentleman or a petty man—it depends on how one views them.

If one waits for a flying hare to harness and ride, no one in the world will ever mount a chariot. If one waits for Mao Qiang or Xi Shi to marry, one will remain single for life. If one waits for ancient worthies to employ, no one will ever be used. A swift steed covers a thousand *li* in a day, but a mediocre horse, driven ten times over ten days, will also arrive—thus, talent alone cannot be relied upon.

When a bird is cornered, it pecks; when a beast is cornered, it gores; when a person is cornered, they deceive.

Harsh punishments and strict laws cannot suppress treachery.

Discourse on the Dao and virtue is like the sun and moon: south of the Yangtze or north of the Yellow River, their course cannot be altered; racing a thousand *li* cannot change their place.

Preferences and aversions within the bounds of propriety are like the dwellings of a house: the eastern neighbor calls it west, the western neighbor calls it east. Yet when one knocks at the door to borrow fire, none refuse—such is the abundance of generosity. Thus, in the forest, firewood is not sold; by the lake, fish are not hoarded—because there is enough.

One does not exploit another’s advantage nor press another’s peril.

Shu Xiang said to a Mohist: "Jiu wished to see King Hui of Qin but was denied for three years. Once he reached Chu, the king of Chu delighted in him." Some things are naturally near yet seem far, while others are far yet feel near. Thus, one must be flexible.

A true man’s conduct cannot be concealed.

Before catching the beast, one fears too few wounds; after catching it, one fears too many.

In ancient marriage rites, the host was never named—only the parents and brothers were mentioned. Shun did not inform Gusou before marrying, which was against ritual. King Wen established Boyi Ke, which was not the proper system. The rites prescribe marriage at thirty, yet King Wen fathered a child at sixteen—this was not the law.

Governing a state has its constants: benefiting the people is the essence of governance; teaching has its principles, with effective commands as the priority. If it benefits the people’s hearts, there is no need to follow antiquity; if it suits the matter at hand, there is no need to adhere to convention. Laws and decrees are made according to what is fitting. Changing the ancient is not necessarily wrong; following custom is not necessarily praiseworthy.

A hundred rivers flow from different sources yet all return to the sea; a hundred schools pursue different paths yet all aim for order.

A blind man walks along the road: if told to go left, he goes left; if told to go right, he goes right. If he meets a noble person, he finds level ground; if he meets a petty man, he falls into a ditch.

One who faces east cannot see the western wall; one who faces south cannot see the northern direction—only one without fixed direction sees all.

If a father is drowning, one grasps his hair to save him—not out of disrespect, but to rescue him from death.

The highest reward costs nothing; the most severe punishment is not excessive.

When sailing and encountering wind, waves rise and one fears death, leaping into the water—not because life is not precious or death not feared, but because the fear of death drives one to forget life.

Those who indulge in desires are the same.

A trickle of water can fill a comb’s case; the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers cannot fill a leaking goblet.

A drunkard stumbles into the Huai, mistaking it for a shallow ditch; a hunchback enters a city gate, thinking it a seven-foot doorway—wine has clouded their minds.

When a horse or hare falls into danger, they die and are buried with a mat; when an ox has served people well, it is buried with a great cart.

The way of warfare is to appear soft yet strike with hardness; to appear weak yet strike with strength. If you wish to go west, show them east, so they know where you emerge but not where you enter—like a ghost leaving no trace, like water leaving no wound, like lightning’s flash, impossible to guard against.

Behind high walls and deep moats, arrows and stones rain down; on broad marshes and open plains, blades clash—yet soldiers vie to advance because rewards are certain and punishments clear.

A tree ten spans in girth can support a house of a thousand *jun*; a bolt five inches long can secure a gate’s opening and closing. Not that the material differs in size, but that its position is crucial.

Were Confucius and Mozi to govern the world, the world would become wholly Confucian or Mohist—such is the power of grasping the essential.

chunks.original_text: 暑不张盖，寒不披裘，古之善将也。 军通井而后饮，军食而后食，所以同饥渴也。 矢石所及之处，所以同安危也。 天下莫相憎於胶漆，胶漆相贼； 胶漆相抱，不得还其本也。 天下莫相爱於冰炭，冰炭相思。 冰得炭则解，故得归其本也。 ○兰生幽谷，不为莫服而不芳； 舟在江河，不为莫乘而不浮。 人有嫁其女而教之曰：慎无为善。 女问其故，曰：善尚不为，况不善乎。 ○拘团圄者患日长，当死市者患日短。 ○嫁女於消渴者，夫死则言女妨。 ○狐白之裘，天子披之。 在狐计者，不如走泽。 ○先缄而后缕，可以成帷； 先缕而后缄，不可以成衣。 因媒而嫁，不因媒而成； 顾人而交，不因人而亲。 披羊裘而赁顾，其事过也； 衣貉裘而负笼，甚可怪也。 ○君子不容非类，日月不应非气。 ○非礼而礼，譬躲而追狂人，盗而与乞者窃问写法律，蹲踞诵论诗书。 ○马似鹿者千金，天下无千金之鹿。 ○画孟贲之目大而不可不畏，画西施之面美而不可不悦。 ○同污无异泥。 ○众曲不容直，众枉不容正。 故人众则食狼，狼众则食人。 ○郢人买屋楝，与人车毂，大虽可而长不足。 ○孕妇见兔，则子缺唇。 ○文公弃衽席，咎犯辞归。 晋文公弃席之黑者，捐故旧也。 故咎犯辞去，知天将赦而多杀人。 或知天赦多活人，人望欲同，刑罚异也。 ○侏儒问天高於长人，长人曰：吾不知也。 曰：尔去天近於我也。 问事当问近者。 ○自卖其母而请买者曰：此母老矣。 望善饴之。 此大不义而欲为小义。 狂人伤人莫之怨，婴疾无心也。 ○佳人不同体，美人不同面，而皆悦於目； 梨橘枣栗不同味，皆训於口。 ○一棋不足以见智，一弦不足以见悲。 遗腹不思父，无爱心也。 ○汤沐具而蚁虱相吊，大厦成而弯雀相贺。 ○钓者静之，网者动之，罩者抑之，肾者举之，为道异，得鱼一。 ○田中之水流入海，附耳之语闻千里。 ○中夏用霎至冬不去，举衣过水至陆不下，此不知变也。 ○靥脯在颊则好，在颜则丑。 绣为被则宜，为冠则秽。 山云蒸柱础润，狭苓抽兔丝死。 ○兔丝无根而生，蛇无足而行，鱼无耳而听，蝉无口而呜。 鹤千岁亦极其乐，朝生暮死亦尽其乐。 ○明珠，蚌之病也，我之利也。 ○百星之明，不如一月之光； 十牖之开，不如一户之明。 ○披蓑救火，凿续止水，乃益多也。 ○鸿鹄在卯也，一指蔑之则破； 及其羽翅成也，背负青天，膺磨赤霄，哺且子不能得也。 ○戟以攻城，镜以照形。 官人得戟则以刈葵，盲人得镜则以盖卮。 ○尧八眉。 眉理八字也。 人有烹狙召邻，邻者以为狗羹，食甚美，后闻其狙，据地吐之，未始知味也。 ○那邓有吹者，托名李奇，人争学之，后知其非，皆弃其曲，未始知音者。 李奇，赵之善音者。 ○原蚕一岁，再熟非不利也。 王法禁之，为其残叶。 离稻熟，农夫耨之，不以小利伤大获也。 稻米落地而生，曰离稻。 O屠者食蕾羹，为车者多步行，陶人用缺盆，匠人居狭庐。 舟覆乃见善游，马奔乃见良驭。 ○林木茂而斧斤入，质的张而弓矢集。 意林卷之二竟 ＃１本句文渊阁本作『孔子劲能举国门之关，而不肯以力闻』。 ＃２『天』文渊阁本作『狗』。 ＃３『毋』文渊阁本作『母』。 下同。 ＃４『此』原作『比』，据文渊阁本改。

In scorching heat, they do not unfurl parasols; in bitter cold, they do not don furs—such were the great generals of old. Troops dig wells before they drink; commanders eat only after their men have been fed, thus sharing hunger and thirst. Where arrows and stones fall, they share peril and safety alike.

Nothing in the world clings as fiercely as glue and lacquer, yet glue and lacquer corrode each other; once entwined, they cannot return to their original state. Nothing in the world is as opposed as ice and charcoal, yet ice longs for charcoal. When ice meets charcoal, it melts—thus it returns to its original nature.

Orchids bloom in secluded valleys, not ceasing their fragrance for lack of admirers; boats float on rivers and lakes, not refusing to sail for lack of passengers. A man marrying off his daughter instructs her: "Beware of doing good." When she asks why, he replies: "If even good is not to be done, how much less evil?"

Prisoners in fetters lament the length of days; those condemned to the execution ground lament their brevity.

A girl married to a man with wasting thirst—when her husband dies, they say she brought misfortune. A robe of white fox fur is worn by the Son of Heaven. Yet to the fox, a marsh is better than a tally.

First bind the threads, then weave the hemp, and you may make a curtain; first weave the hemp, then bind the threads, and you cannot make a garment. Marriages arranged through matchmakers may not succeed; friendships formed through personal regard endure. To don a sheepskin and hire oneself out as a laborer is excessive; to wear a raccoon-dog fur while carrying a basket is most strange.

The noble person admits no unworthy kind; the sun and moon respond only to proper qi.

To perform rites improperly is like chasing a madman while fleeing, or a thief asking a beggar to copy laws. To squat and recite the *Odes* and *Documents*—

A horse resembling a deer is worth a thousand gold pieces; yet there is no deer worth a thousand gold. Paint Meng Ben’s eyes large, and one cannot help but fear him; paint Xi Shi’s face fair, and one cannot help but delight in her.

Fouled by the same filth, no mud differs. A lone straight line is not tolerated among many crooked ones; a lone upright is not tolerated among many bent. Thus, when people are many, they devour wolves; when wolves are many, they devour people.

A man of Ying buys roof beams and trades a chariot hub with another—though the size is sufficient, the length falls short.

A pregnant woman who sees a hare will bear a child with a cleft lip.

Duke Wen discarded his sleeping mat; Jiu Fan resigned and left. When Duke Wen of Jin cast aside the blackened mat, he was casting off the old. Thus Jiu Fan departed, knowing Heaven would grant amnesty and many would be executed. Some knew Heaven’s amnesty would spare many lives, yet people’s hopes aligned while punishments differed.

A dwarf asked a tall man: "Is the sky higher for you than for me?" The tall man replied: "I do not know." The dwarf said: "You are closer to the sky than I." To ask about matters, one should ask those nearest.

A man selling his own mother tells the buyer: "This mother is old." He hopes for kind treatment—this is great unrighteousness seeking to appear as small righteousness. A madman who harms others is resented by none, for his illness has robbed him of reason.

Beautiful women do not share the same form, nor do lovely women share the same face, yet all please the eye. Pears, oranges, jujubes, and chestnuts do not share the same taste, yet all delight the palate.

A single move in chess does not reveal wisdom; a single string does not convey sorrow. A posthumous child does not long for his father, for he has no love in his heart.

When bathing tools are prepared, ants and lice commiserate; when a grand mansion is completed, swallows and sparrows congratulate.

The angler stills the water; the netter stirs it; the trapper presses down; the spearer lifts up—though their methods differ, they all catch fish.

Water from the fields flows into the sea; whispers in the ear are heard a thousand *li* away.

In mid-summer, one wears garments fit for winter and does not remove them; crossing water, one lifts one’s robes, yet on land does not lower them—this is not knowing how to adapt.

Dried meat on the cheek is pleasing; on the forehead, it is ugly. Embroidery suits a quilt; on a hat, it is foul.

Mountain clouds rise, and pillars grow damp; dodder withers when *fuling* sprouts. Dodder grows without roots; snakes slither without feet; fish hear without ears; cicadas sing without mouths.

A crane lives a thousand years and exhausts its joy; a mayfly lives but a day and exhausts its joy.

A luminous pearl is the clam’s affliction, yet my gain. The brightness of a hundred stars does not equal the light of a single moon; the opening of ten windows does not equal the brightness of one door.

To don a straw raincoat to fight a fire, or to dig a channel to stop water, only increases the trouble.

When the swan goose is in the egg, a single finger can crush it; when its wings are fully grown, it soars on its back through the azure sky, its breast brushing the red clouds—even its parents cannot catch it.

Halberds are for storming cities; mirrors are for reflecting forms. Yet an official who obtains a halberd uses it to cut greens, and a blind man who obtains a mirror uses it to cover his wine cup.

Yao had eight brows—his brows bore eight lines.

A man cooked a macaque and invited his neighbor. The neighbor thought it dog stew and ate with great relish. Later, hearing it was macaque, he spat it out onto the ground, never having known its true taste.

In Na and Deng there was a flutist who falsely claimed to be Li Qi. People rushed to learn from him, but when they discovered the truth, they abandoned his melodies—never having known true music. Li Qi was a master of music from Zhao.

Silkworms that produce cocoons twice a year are no less profitable, yet royal law forbids it, for they strip the leaves bare. When *li* rice ripens, farmers weed it, not letting small gains harm the greater harvest. *Li* rice grows from fallen grains.

Butchers eat leek stew; cartwrights walk much; potters use cracked basins; carpenters live in cramped huts. Only when a boat capsizes does one see the good swimmer; only when a horse bolts does one see the skilled driver.

Where forests grow lush, axes and hatchets enter; where targets are set up, arrows and bows gather.

*Yi Lin*, Scroll Two, End.

chunks.original_text: ＃５『母』原作『毋』，据文渊阁本改。 意林卷之三 扶风马总元会编 盐铁论十卷 并是文学，与大夫相难。 ○善克者不战，善战者不师，善师者不阵。 ○工不出则物用乏，商不出则宝货绝。 ○川原不能实漏卮，山海不能赡溢欲。 ○宅近市则家富，富在术数，不在力耕。 ○善歌者使人续其声，善作者使人治其功。 ○孔子能方不能圆，故饥於黎丘。 ○茂林之下无丰草，大块之间无美苗。 ○行远者假於车，济海者因於舟，成名者因於资，欧冶能因国君。 铜铁作金炉大锺，而不能自作壶鼎盘孟。 ○香饵非不美，龟龙闻而深藏，鸾凤见而高逝。 玉屑满筐，不成其宝。 仲尼之门，七十子去父母捐家，负荷而随，孔子不耕而学，其乱愈滋，犹玉屑满筐也。 若能安国利人，宁须文辞者哉。 ○有粟而不能食，无益於饥； 观贤而不能用，无益於利。 ○歌者不期於利声而贵於中节，论者不期於丽辞而务在事实。 ○公卿者，四海之仪表，神化之丹青，上有辅明主之任，下有随圣化之治。 ○诸生抱枯竹守空言，不知趋舍之宜、时世之变。 ○林中多疾风，富贵多谀言。 ○古者君子思德，小人思利； 今人坚额健舌，代以致业。 ○九层之台倾，公输子不能正； 大朝一邪，伊望不能复。 吏道杂而不选。 ○富贵以财买官，垂青绶，环银龟，擅杀生之柄，专万民之命，乘肩驱良，列骑成行者，不知负檐步行之劳。 中国与边境，犹支体与腹心，肌肤寒於外，腹心疾於内，以仁义阻之，道德塞之，贤人守之，则莫能入也。 秦法繁於秋茶，罔密於凝脂，然而上下相遁，奸伪并生。 厩焚，孔子问人，不问马，贱畜贵人也。 秦法盗马者死，盗牛者刑，苛也。 说苑二十卷刘向 束风则靡而西，西风则靡而束。
