It is said: "A scholar is not a jade." Those who praise him speak only of his value, yet the mouths of those who praise are like hearts of love and hate.

○ Excessive wisdom drains the blood and qi, like a lamp’s flame to its tallow—if the wick is large, the light is bright, but the tallow is consumed; if the wick is small, the light is dim, but the tallow endures, and thus may last long.

○ One who speaks boldly but gazes timidly is a hypocrite. One whose breath is urgent and voice heavy is a steadfast person.

○ When Meng Tian built the Great Wall, the people could not bear their suffering, and white bones piled like mountains. Then a song arose:
*"Bear a son—take care not to raise him;
Bear a daughter—swaddle her to serve.
Have you not seen beneath the Great Wall,
Where white bones stand as pillars?"*
Those who forge gold are alchemists who take plant ash and smelt it with metal. Thus, as the plant ash burns, the gold falls away.

*The Supreme Mystery Classic* in fourteen scrolls, by Yang Quan of Liang, styled Deyuan:
Anger is like the fierce winter; joy, like the gentle spring.

○ The luan, the crane, and the phoenix—noble birds of lofty lineage—conceal their brilliance in the forest and do not feed on filth.

○ Inwardly pure yet outwardly tarnished, clad in tattered robes yet bearing jade within.

○ For every ten *li*, nine are pits—oxen and horses rise and fall.

○ Heaven’s qi turns left, the stars move right; yin and yang revolve in cycles, returning to meet one another.

○ The overbearing perish; the obstinate break; the fiercely strong stumble; the greatly sharp dulls.

○ Rushing qi becomes wind; surging qi becomes rain; turbid mist becomes snow; clear dew becomes frost.

*The Scripture of Transformation and Purity* in ten scrolls:
The turbid do not trust the clarity born of the deep but willingly bathe in filth.

○ In action, swift as a tiger’s pounce; in stillness, hidden as a scale-clad creature.

Like that, resplendent; like this, vast and boundless.

○ Those about to take flight fold their wings; those about to surge crouch low; those about to strike retract their claws; those about to speak close their mouths; those about to refine first return to simplicity.

*Zouzi* in one scroll:
To know a person, observe their friends.
Luxuriant weeds in the field leave no place for good seedlings to set their roots;
Flatterers in the court leave no room for the loyal and upright to stand.

○ Do not enter a house with few doors at night; do not brush dust from your meal—these are ways to avoid suspicion.

*On Success and Failure* in three scrolls, by Sun Yu, styled Zhongshu:
Water’s nature is to flow, yet without guidance, it does not course; human nature is to be wise, yet without teaching, it does not flourish.
Learning is like planting—without it, one withers.

○ Secrecy is the juncture of heaven and earth, the pivot of success and failure. Thus, if yin and yang are not kept secret, the summer cannot complete the year; if a house’s eaves are not sealed, even nine stories cannot shelter a body.

*Comprehensive Discourse on Past and Present* in three scrolls, by Wang Ying:
Kunlun’s southeast spans five thousand *li*—this is called the Divine Continent, the dwelling of emperors and the birthplace of sages.

○ Cang Jie created writing: when form is established, it is called *wen*; when sound is complete, it is called *zi*. *Zi* derives from the blossoming and breeding of forms, and when inscribed on bamboo and silk, it is called *shu*.

*The Central Treatise* in six scrolls, by Xu Weichang, with annotations by Ren:
To stand and ponder the distant is not as good as hastening forward to reach it; to crane one’s neck after flying things is not as good as cultivating wings to surely seize them; to live alone and wish for wisdom is not as good as accumulating learning to surely attain it.
The noble person does not worry that his years are waning but that his resolve may falter.
The Dao in relation to humanity is most simple, yet when submerged, it is not spoken of—this is as different from Sima Qian as a leopard is from a horse.

○ One’s passage through the world is like playing chess: if one does not exhaust the Dao, who is without a fatal move? It is merely a matter of misfortune.

*Tangzi* in ten scrolls, by Tang Pang, styled Huijian, born in the second year of the Taiyuan era of Wu:
A boat following the river travels swiftly; a person following the road does not lose their way.

○ A great tree of a hundred *xun* has deep roots; the vast sea of ten thousand *ren* is formed by many streams; profound wisdom and penetrating insight are the work of accumulated learning.

The noble person crowns himself with the Dao and rides in a carriage of the Dao. Without the Dao as his crown, he does not dare to go forth; without the Dao as his carriage, he cannot take a step.

One who has a father yet cannot be filial, a brother yet cannot be respectful, yet lectures others on the duties of father and son, elder and younger—this is like bending a bow to shoot oneself.

○ If human nature possesses even one act of filial piety, then nothing is left unembraced, just as when a tree’s root is planted, a hundred branches grow.

Someone asked: "Between Duke Huan of Qi and Duke Wen of Jin, who was superior?"
Tangzi replied: "In terms of merit, Huan is the elder brother and Wen the younger; in terms of virtue, Wen is the elder brother and Huan the younger."

○ The Great Jin, responding to the mandate of the times, swept all before it like thunder crushing the withered, a thousand *jun* pressing upon an egg—nothing remained.

○ People often suffer from seeing a hundred paces ahead yet not knowing their own brows and cheeks; those who know their brows and cheeks cannot see a hundred paces.

The noble person guards authenticity and wields trust; when the times do not permit it, though he may endure the shame of slander and the filth of hidden defamation, it is but a scratch upon his body.

Eagles in their prime take flight; phoenixes roam afar. When petty men form ranks, the noble person retreats into seclusion.

A saying goes: "No matter how much rouge and powder, they cannot adorn an ugly face; no matter how radiant the ointment, it cannot moisten grass."

○ The ancients were short-sighted in seeing themselves, so they used mirrors to observe their forms; the heart is short-sighted in governing itself, so it uses ritual to guard against transgression.

The noble person does not alter his conduct because of darkness, nor change his countenance because of night.

○ One who possesses a name that towers above the world must bear the burden of defying convention; one who has integrity that transcends the ordinary must endure the calamity of slander and scorn.

White bones resemble ivory; fish eyes resemble pearls—from afar, none can distinguish them.

○ Fortune and misfortune turn into one another; benefit and harm give rise to each other, like a wheel rolling a ball—its signs are unseen, its beginnings unfelt.

○ A good general is like a mountain, like an abyss—people do not know his sorrow, nor do they know his joy.

○ A general must not leave the drums and banners, for they are the army’s ears and eyes.

○ Sudden glory is not dwelled in by the wise.

One who hoards wealth and does not give is called a "money slave."

○ Those who assist in strife are harmed; those who meddle in affairs perish.

*Qinzi* in two scrolls.

Seeking to make white stand out against snow or to race light beneath the sun—this cannot be done.

○ Yan Yanxian once asked: "There is a flavor as rich as wine yet does not intoxicate; its taste resembles millet, yet drinking it brings drunkenness—why is this?" Master Qin replied: "Intoxication lies with the petty man, not with the noble one."

I desire splendor within though plain without, not embroidery outside with hemp within—just as a speaker would sooner exhaust words than道理.

○ What is distant and hard to know is Heaven; what is near and hard to know is man.

○ By means of the axe one obtains the handle; by means of the handle one achieves its use.

Plant a single grain, and a thousand myriad grains flourish; plant a single act of kindness, and the beauty of a hundred deeds is complete.

○ A needle, though small, sinks in water; a feather, though large, floats in water—such is their inherent nature.

*Meizi*, one scroll.

Yi Yin, Lü Wang, Fu Yue, Jizi, Boyi and Shuqi, Liu Hui, Yan Yuan, Zhuang Zhou, and Ruan Ji—had they exchanged places, they could have done what they could not do.

Ruan Ji fulfilled filial piety toward his parents, remained loyal without forgetting his lord, preserved clarity without neglecting himself, displayed wisdom without meddling in affairs, and feigned foolishness without disrupting governance.

Since the time of Zhuang Zhou, among the great worthies of the age, none has been his equal—such was Master Ruan.

According to his writings, he was a man of the Jin.

*Wulilun*, sixteen scrolls.

He who seeks to stabilize the world yet employs petty men is like one who hunts elk while setting snares for rabbits—it cannot be done.

○ Anger scorches like fire on clothing—its damage is great. When the rice in a pot of wrath boils over, one overturns and discards it—loss outweighs gain.

○ As the saying goes: "If those above are not upright, those below will be in disarray."

In ancient times, rulers did not deceive their people: they pared down the rich and powerful to nourish the poor and weak. How is this different from starving the plow-ox to ride the horse, or feeding the barking dog while whetting a lead blade instead of *Ganjiang*?

○ The *Analects* is the ultimate teaching of the sage and the great transformation of the king. The "Xiangdang" chapter contains the rituals of court and the ceremonies of diplomatic reception. The "Yaoyue" chapter records the affairs of abdication and succession.

The literary brilliance in a person is like the flowering splendor of grass.

○ The *Giving Court Gentleman* debated with Gao Tanglong and Qin Lang over the south-pointing carriage. The two claimed: "Such a carriage never existed in antiquity—it is but an empty record." The Master replied: "To dispute over empty words is not as good as testing their effect." He spoke of this to Emperor Ming. The emperor ordered the carriage made, and it was successfully completed.

○ Master Fan Che resided within the capital city, where he possessed land for a garden but suffered from lack of water for irrigation. He thus devised the *fan che* (chain-pump), which a child could operate, increasing efficiency a hundredfold.

Heaven and earth complete a year: spring precedes autumn. The governance of a ruler: ritual precedes punishment. To treat an infant’s illness yet refuse moxibustion, only to administer other remedies until death—this is no different than taking the wrong medicine. Today, those who abolish corporal punishment multiply, yet such abolition is like substituting one drug for another. Though corporal punishment severs a limb, the person may still live and bear children. When Zhang Cang abolished corporal punishment, tens of thousands were executed each year; when Zhong Xian restored it, two thousand lives were saved annually.

○ The term "corporal punishment" is akin to birds and beasts being placed upon the cutting board as meat.

○ If a beloved son were to face the death penalty, his compassionate father would surely beg to substitute it with corporal punishment—exchanging death for life if possible. Can a ruler of the Dao fail to extend this mercy to the people? When a snake bites one’s hand, a strong man severs his wrist, knowing that though the limb is lost, life remains.

○ Cao Yi said: "One tames a spirited colt with reins and binds a fierce horse with a frayed rope." Today, governing the people with lenient punishments is no different than killing them.

○ All know that Guanzi borrowed the ears of the realm, yet none realize that Yao first borrowed the hearts of the people before employing their eyes and ears.

○ Long ago, in the lands between Yan and Zhao, three brothers shared one wife, who bore four children. Later, they disputed in court. Minister Yan Shou memorialized: "Beasts bear young and follow their mothers; the children should be returned to her, while the three men should be executed in the marketplace."

○ Plugging an ant’s hole may stem the flow of a river; securing a chariot’s linchpin may prevent its overturning. Those who establish laws and decrees should likewise grasp the essentials.

○ The *Rites* states: "For a stepfather, one wears *qicui* mourning."

○ Master Fu said: "A mother who abandons her own father to remarry another man severs ties with her brother’s father more severely than if both had cut off all relations with Heaven."

○ Moreover, the *Regulations on Mourning* were likely not composed by Zhou or Kong but fabricated by vulgar scholars after the Qin’s burning of the books.

○ Those who recklessly advance are like eggs hurled at stone; those who flee punishment are like men rushing into a pit.

○ Clamorous as spring blossoms bursting forth, fragrant as autumn orchids flourishing together.

○ A gourd hanging from a tree is not the tree’s fruit; a fur coat worn on the back is not the skin’s own hair—these are resemblances, not realities.

○ The ninth precept speaks of nourishing one’s parents, saying, "Let them hunger." How can one claim they are well-fed if they are often starved? This is surely not filial. A horse fed grain for ten days and starved for one remains robust, with no harm to its well-being—yet one cannot equate this with starving a mother for a single day.

○ At the end of the Han, a man named Guan Qiuyang fled with his younger brother and a companion. When snow fell and their provisions ran out, he said to his brother: "If we do not eat now, the three of us will die together." They killed the companion, obtained food, and reached shelter. Later, an amnesty pardoned their crime.

chunks.original_text: 此人可谓善士乎。 孔文举曰：管秋阳爱先人遗体，食伴无嫌也。 荀侍中难曰：秋阳贪生，杀生岂不罪邪。 文举曰：此伴非会友也。 若管仲啖鲍叔，贡禹食王阳，此则不可。 向所杀者犹乌兽而能言耳。 今有犬啮一狸，狸啮一鹦鹊，何足怪也。 昔重耳恋齐女而欲食狐偃，叔敖怒楚师而欲食五参，贤哲之忿犹欲啖人，而况遭穷者乎。 ○见虎一毛不知其斑，道家笑儒者之拘，儒者嗤道家之放，皆不见本也。 止响以声，逐影以形，奸争流荡，不知所止也。 ○傅子曰：云孟轲、荀卿若在孔门，非唯游夏而已，乃冉闵之徒也。 ○积薪若山，纵火其下，火未及燃，一杯之水尚可灭也。 及至火猛风起，虽倾河海不能救也。 ○秦昭王是积薪而纵火其下，始皇燃而方炽，二世起风而怒也。 秦人视山束之民犹猛虎之睨草羊，何隔惮哉。 ○范蠡，字少伯，楚三户人也，使起灭吴已后，乘轻舟游五湖。 王令人写其状，恒朝礼之，列仙云徐人也。 ○傅氏之先出自陶唐傅说之后。 ○玄字休弈，子哉字长虞，《晋书》有传。 ○楚汉之际，有好事者作世本，上录黄帝，下逮汉末，班固《汉书》因父得成。 大孝养志，其次养形。 养志者尽其和，养形者不失其敬。 割地利己，天下俨之； 推心及物，天下归之。 以信接人，天下信之； 不以信接人，妻子疑之。 见疑妻子，难以事君。 君子修身，居位非利名也，在乎仁义。 ○人皆知涤其器，莫知洗其心。 君子审其宗而后学，明其道而后行。 或云玄衡以善诗至宰相，张禹以善论作帝师，岂非儒学之荣乎。 ○傅子曰：学以道达荣，不以位显。 吾观班固《汉书》论国体则饰主阙而抑忠臣，叔世教则贵取容而贱直节，述时务则谨辞章而略事实，非良史也。 墨子兼爱，是废亲也； 知丧，是忘忧也。 ○汉太宗除肉刑，匹夫之仁也，非天下之仁也。 忍残人之体而忍杀人，故曰匹夫。 伊尹耕於有莘，孰知非夏之野人。 吕○不宝香便尚钓於渭滨，孰知非殷之渔者。 遇汤武、文王，然后知其非也。 面岐路者有行迷之虑，仰高山者有飞天之志。 或乘马乘车而俱至秦者，所谓形异而实同也。 ○若谓黄帝后方有舟机，庖羲之时长江大河何所用之。 经巨海者终年不‘见其涯，测虞渊者终世不知其底，故近者不可以度远也。 ○汉世贱辖车，而今贵之。 ○青与赤谓之文，赤与白谓之章，白与黑谓之龄，黑与青谓之敝，五彩谓之绣。 ○始皇冢令匠人作机弩，有人穿者即射之，以人鱼膏作烛。 ○逐兔之犬终朝寻兔，不失其迩，虽见麋鹿不暇顾也。 ○汉高祖度阔而网疏，故后世推诚而简直； 光武教一而网密，故后世守常而礼义； 魏武札乱以尚猛，天下修法而贵理。 ○形自正不求影之直而影自直，声之平不求响之和而响自和，德之崇不求名之远而名自远。 ○西国胡言：苏合香是兽。 中国兽便而臭，忽闻西极兽便而，则不信矣。 ○必得昆山之玉而后，则剎璞无夜光之美。 必须南国之珠而后珍，则隋侯无明月之称，始皇远游并海而不免平台之变，及葬骊山，寻见发掘。 今有铅锡之蜓，虽欧冶百炼，犹不如瓦刀。 有驽胎之马，虽造父驾之，终不及飞兔，绝景质钝故也。 土不可作铁而可以作瓦。 ○相者曰：三亭九候定於一尺之面，愚智勇怯形於一寸之目。
chunks.translated_text:
Could this man be called a virtuous scholar? Kong Wenju said: "Guan Qiuyang cherished the body bequeathed by his ancestors; eating the companion incurred no blame." The Attendant-in-Ordinary Xun countered: "Qiuyang coveted life—how could killing not be a crime?" Wenju replied: "This companion was no sworn friend. Had Guan Zhong eaten Bao Shu or Gong Yu consumed Wang Yang, that would have been impermissible. The one they killed was but a talking beast. Now, if a dog bites a wildcat and the wildcat bites a parrot, what is there to marvel at? In former times, Chong'er clung to the Qi woman and wished to devour Hu Yan; Shu Ao raged at the Chu army and wished to eat Wu Can. Even the wrath of worthies and sages would drive them to consume men—how much more those reduced to extremity?"

○ Seeing but a single stripe, one does not know the tiger’s full pattern. Daoists mock the Confucians’ restraint; Confucians sneer at the Daoists’ abandon—neither perceives the root. Chasing echoes by sound, pursuing shadows by form, contention and dissipation surge without cease.

○ Master Fu said: "Had Meng Ke and Xun Qing been among Confucius’ disciples, they would not have been mere You and Xia, but rather the likes of Ran Min."

○ A pile of firewood stacked like a mountain, set alight at its base—before the flames rise, a single cup of water may yet extinguish them. But when fire rages and wind howls, even pouring forth rivers and seas cannot save it.

○ King Zhao of Qin was the stacked firewood; the First Emperor kindled the blaze; the Second Emperor fanned the gale. The people of Qin regarded the folk of Shandong as a tiger eyes a sheep in the grass—what barrier or fear could there be?

○ Fan Li, styled Shaobo, was a man of the Three Hu of Chu. After his role in the destruction of Wu, he boarded a light boat and roamed the Five Lakes. The king had his likeness painted and daily paid homage to it, ranking him among the immortals of Xuren.

○ The ancestors of the Fu clan descended from Fu Yue, minister to Emperor Yao of the Tang.

○ Xuan, styled Xiuyi, and his son Zai, styled Changyu, have biographies in *The History of the Jin*.

○ During the transition from Chu to Han, an enthusiast compiled the *Generational Origins*, tracing from the Yellow Emperor to the end of the Han. Ban Gu’s *History of the Han* was completed thanks to his father’s work.

○ The highest filial piety nourishes the will; the next nourishes the body. To nourish the will is to fulfill harmony; to nourish the body is not to lose reverence. Seizing land for oneself, the world stands in awe; extending one’s heart to others, the world returns to one. Treating others with sincerity, the world trusts one; without sincerity, even wife and children doubt. If wife and children doubt, how can one serve a lord? The noble person cultivates the self; holding office is not for profit or fame, but for benevolence and righteousness.

○ All know to cleanse their vessels, but none think to wash their hearts. The noble person examines the root before studying, clarifies the Way before acting.

○ Some say Xuan Heng rose to prime minister through fine poetry, and Zhang Yu became the emperor’s teacher through eloquent discourse—was this not the glory of Confucian learning?

○ Master Fu said: "Learning brings honor through the Way, not through rank. I observe Ban Gu’s *History of the Han*: in discussing statecraft, he adorns the ruler’s flaws and suppresses loyal ministers; in expounding degenerate teachings, he values conformity and scorns integrity; in addressing current affairs, he refines rhetoric and neglects facts—he is no true historian."

○ Mozi’s universal love is the abandonment of kinship; his doctrine of mourning is the forgetting of sorrow.

○ Emperor Taizong of Han abolished mutilating punishments—this was the benevolence of a common man, not the benevolence of the world. To endure maiming another’s body yet endure killing them is what is called the benevolence of a common man.

○ Yi Yin tilled the fields of Youxin—who knew he was not a rustic of Xia? Lü Shang did not treasure incense but fished by the Wei—who knew he was not a fisherman of Yin? Only upon meeting Tang, Wu, and King Wen did their true nature become known.

○ One standing at a forked road fears losing the way; one gazing at a high mountain harbors the ambition to soar to the heavens. Some ride horses or chariots to reach Qin—this is what is meant by differing forms but identical substance.

○ If one claims that boats and machines arose only after the Yellow Emperor, what did Fuxi use to cross the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers? Those who traverse vast seas may pass years without seeing their shores; those who plumb the depths of Yu Yuan may live lifetimes without knowing its bottom—thus the near cannot measure the far.

○ In the Han, linchpin carts were despised; now they are prized.

○ Blue and red are called *wen*; red and white, *zhang*; white and black, *ling*; black and blue, *bi*; the five colors together are called *embroidery*.

○ The First Emperor ordered artisans to install crossbow mechanisms in his tomb—anyone who tunneled in would be shot. He used human fat and fish oil to make candles.

○ A hound chasing a hare spends the whole day tracking it, never losing its scent; though it sees a deer, it has no time to glance.

○ Emperor Gaozu of Han was broad-minded and his governance loose, so later generations valued sincerity and simplicity; Emperor Guangwu of Han was meticulous and his governance tight, so later generations upheld convention and propriety; Cao Cao of Wei valued severity amid chaos, so the world refined laws and prized order.

○ When the body is upright, one does not seek the shadow’s straightness—yet the shadow is straight. When the sound is level, one does not seek the echo’s harmony—yet the echo is harmonious. When virtue is lofty, one does not seek fame’s reach—yet fame spreads far.

○ In the western lands, the Hu say: "Storax is an animal." In China, animal excrement stinks; suddenly hearing that western animal excrement is fragrant, one does not believe it.

○ If one insists on Kunshan jade before carving, then uncut jade will never reveal its night-shining beauty. If one demands southern pearls before valuing them, then the Marquis of Sui’s pearl will never earn its "bright moon" renown. The First Emperor’s distant travels along the sea did not spare him the disaster at Pingtai; his burial at Mount Li was soon followed by grave robbers.

○ Now, with lead and tin ore, even if Ou Ye smelts it a hundred times, it will not surpass a clay knife. With a horse of inferior stock, even if Zaofu drives it, it will never match the Flying Hare or the Swift Shadow—its nature is dull and slow. Earth cannot become iron but can become tile.

○ The physiognomist says: "The three pavilions and nine pulses are determined in a face of one foot; foolishness, wisdom, courage, and timidity are revealed in eyes of one inch."

lial. A horse fed grain for ten days and starved for one remains robust, with no harm to its well-being—yet one cannot equate this with starving a mother for a single day.

○ At the end of the Han, a man named Guan Qiuyang fled with his younger brother and a companion. When snow fell and their provisions ran out, he said to his brother: "If we do not eat now, the three of us will die together." They killed the companion, obtained food, and reached shelter. Later, an amnesty pardoned their crime.

chunks.original_text: 天仓金匮以别贫富贵贱。 ○光武凤翔於南阳，燕雀化作鹤鹤。 二汉之臣，焕烂如三辰之附长天，长平之卒，磊落如秋草之中繁霜，势使然也。 ○长人数丈，身横九亩，两头异颈，四臂共骨。 老人生角，男女变化，何益於贤愚耶。 ○岂有太一之君坐於庶人之座，魁呈之神存於匹妇之室。 ○傅子曰：诸葛亮诚一时之异人也，治国有分，御军有法，积功兴业，事得其机，入无遗刃，出有余粮，知蜀本弱而危，故持重以镇之若．。 姜维欲速立其功，勇而无央也。 ○马先生绫机，先生名钧，字衡。 天下之名巧也。 绫机本五十综，五十蓑，六十综，六十签，先生乃易二蓑，奇文异变，因感而作，自能成阴阳无穷也。 指南车见《周官》，亦见《鬼谷子》。 先生作辩。 上下者莫正乎位，兴国家者莫贵乎人，统内外者莫齐乎分，宣德教者莫明乎学。 秉纲而目自张，执本而末自从。 善赏者赏一善而天下之善皆劝，善罚者罚一恶而天下之恶皆除矣。 世质则官少，时文则吏多。 有虞氏官五十，夏后官一百，殷有二百，周有三百。 国典之坠，犹位丧也。 位之不建，名理废也。 ○以誉取人，则权势移於下而朋党之交用。 以功进士，则有德者未必授而凡下之人或见任也。 君子内洗其心，以虚受人，外设法度，立不易方。 今人称古多贤，患世无人，退不三思，坐语一世，岂不惑邪。 ○人之性如水焉，置之圆则圆，置之方则方，澄之停而清，动之则流而浊。 先王知中流之易扰乱，故随而教之，谓其偏好者，故立一定之法。 龙舟整橄，王良不能执也； 骥绿齐行，越人不敢御也，各有所能。 构大厦者先择匠而后拣材，治国家者先择佐而后定民。 ○人之学，如渴而饮河海，大饮则大盈，小饮则小盈，大观则大见，小观则小见。 ○金以利用，钱以轻流，此二物饥不可食。 ○入粟补吏是卖官也，罪人以赎是纵恶也。 ○世富钱流，则禁盗铸钱； 世贫钱滞，则禁盗坏钱。 ○天子之害，莫害於女饰，盈一头之饰，盈千金之价，婢妾之服亦重四海之珍。 ○公卿大夫刻石作碑，镌石作虎。 碑虎崇伪，陈於三衢，妨功丧德，异端并起，撞亡秦之锺，作郑卫之乐，欲以兴治，岂不难哉。 ○赏不避疏贱，罚不避亲贵。 贵有常名而贱不得冒，尊有定位而卑不敢逾。 经之以道德，纬之以仁义，织之以礼法。 既成而后用之，谓有孝廉秀才之贡，或千里望风承声而举。 故任实者渐消，积虚者日长。 ○闻一善言，见一善事，行之唯恐不及。 闻一恶言，见一恶事，远之唯恐不远。 ○悬千金於市，市人不敢取者，分定也。 委一钱於路，童儿争之者，分未定也。 ○三皇贵道而尚德，五帝先仁而后义，三王先义而后乱。 ○鸿毛一羽在水而没者，无势也； 黄金万钧在舟而浮者，托舟之势也。 ○拟金人铭，作口铭曰：神以感通，心由口宣。 福生有兆，祸来有端，情莫多妄，口莫多言。 蚁孔溃河，淄川倾山。 病从口入，患自口出。 存亡之机，开阖之术，口与心谋。 安危之源，枢机之发，荣辱随焉。 夫有公心，必有公道。 ○爱己者不能不爱，憎己者不能不憎。 民富则安乡重家，敬上而从教； 贫则危乡轻家，相聚而犯上。 饥寒切身而不行非者，寡矣。 我欲战而彼不欲战者，我鼓而进之，若山崩河溢，当其冲者摧，值其锋者破，所谓疾雷不暇掩耳，则又谁御之。
chunks.translated_text:
The celestial granaries and golden treasuries distinguish poverty from wealth, lowliness from nobility.

○ Emperor Guangwu soared like a phoenix over Nanyang, while swallows and sparrows transformed into quails. The ministers of the two Han dynasties shone resplendent as the Three Luminaries adorning the vast sky; the soldiers of Changping stood as numerous as autumn grasses beneath heavy frost—such was the force of circumstance.

○ Some giants stand several *zhang* tall, their bodies spanning nine *mu*, two heads upon separate necks, four arms sharing the same bones. Old men growing horns, men and women transforming—what bearing do these have on wisdom or folly?

○ How could the Supreme Unity’s sovereign sit upon a commoner’s seat, or the majestic deity of the Dipper dwell in a humble woman’s chamber?

○ Master Fu said: "Zhuge Liang was truly a man of extraordinary talent in his time. In governing the state, he had his principles; in commanding the army, he had his methods. Through accumulating merit and advancing his cause, he seized the opportune moment. Entering enemy territory, no blade was left unused; departing, provisions remained in surplus. He knew Shu was inherently weak and precarious, thus he exercised restraint to stabilize it. Jiang Wei, however, sought to swiftly establish his achievements—bold yet reckless."

○ Master Ma’s drawloom—Master Ma, named Jun, styled Heng—was the most ingenious craftsman under heaven. The drawloom originally had fifty heddles and fifty treadles, or sixty heddles and sixty treadles. Master Ma reduced it to two treadles, producing intricate patterns and extraordinary variations. Inspired, he created designs that could generate endless yin-yang transformations. The south-pointing chariot is recorded in the *Rites of Zhou* and also appears in the *Guiguzi*. Master Ma refined its mechanism.

○ In governance, nothing corrects position like proper rank; nothing uplifts a state like its people; nothing unifies internal and external affairs like clear divisions; nothing clarifies moral instruction like learning. Grasp the warp, and the weft aligns itself; hold the root, and the branches naturally follow. A wise rewarder, by rewarding one good deed, encourages all good deeds under heaven; a wise punisher, by punishing one evil, eradicates all evil under heaven.

○ In simpler times, officials were few; in refined eras, clerks multiplied. The Youyu dynasty had fifty offices, the Xia a hundred, the Yin two hundred, and the Zhou three hundred. The decline of state canons is like the loss of rank; without rank established, the principles of names and reason collapse.

○ If one selects people by reputation, power shifts downward, and cliques thrive. If one promotes scholars by merit, the virtuous may go unappointed while the mediocre are entrusted with office.

○ The noble person inwardly purifies their heart to receive others with emptiness, while outwardly establishing laws and unchanging principles. Today, people praise antiquity for its many worthies, lamenting the lack of talent in the present age. Yet they do not reflect thrice before speaking of the world—how can this not be delusion?

○ Human nature is like water: placed in a round vessel, it becomes round; placed in a square vessel, it becomes square. When stilled, it clears; when stirred, it muddies. The former kings knew the midstream was easily disturbed, so they guided and instructed, setting fixed laws for those with partial preferences.

○ A dragon boat with its oars aligned—even Wang Liang could not steer it. A team of swift horses moving in unison—even a Yue man dare not rein them. Each has its own ability.

○ Those building a great hall first choose the craftsman, then select the materials; those governing a state first choose their aides, then settle the people.

○ Learning is like thirst driving one to drink from rivers and seas: drinking deeply, one is deeply filled; drinking lightly, one is lightly filled. Observing broadly, one sees broadly; observing narrowly, one sees narrowly.

○ Gold is used for its utility, coin for its light circulation—yet neither can be eaten in famine.

○ Granting official positions in exchange for grain is selling office; allowing criminals to redeem their crimes is indulging evil.

○ When wealth flows through the world, counterfeit coinage is forbidden; when poverty stagnates it, the destruction of coinage is forbidden.

○ No harm befalls the Son of Heaven greater than the adornments of women. A single headpiece may cost a thousand gold, while the garments of maidservants rival the rarest treasures of the four seas.

○ Dukes, ministers, and grandees carve stone into steles and engrave it into tigers. These steles and stone tigers, erected with false grandeur along the three thoroughfares, obstruct merit and corrupt virtue. Heterodoxies arise, the bells of Qin’s downfall are struck, and the licentious music of Zheng and Wei is played—how can governance possibly thrive?

○ Rewards do not avoid the distant and lowly; punishments do not spare the close and noble. The noble have their constant names, which the lowly cannot usurp; the exalted have their fixed positions, which the humble dare not overstep. Weave governance with the warp of Dao and virtue, the weft of benevolence and righteousness, interlacing with ritual and law. Only after completion is it put to use—hence the tribute of Filial and Incorrupt, of Cultivated Talent, where from a thousand *li* away, people gaze in admiration and respond to its reputation. Thus, those who rely on substance gradually diminish, while those who accumulate emptiness grow daily.

○ Hearing one good word or witnessing one good deed, one pursues it fearing they may fall short. Hearing one evil word or witnessing one evil deed, one distances themselves fearing they may not be far enough.

○ A thousand gold hung in the marketplace—no one dares take it, for its portion is fixed. A single coin left on the road—children scramble for it, for its portion is undetermined.

○ The Three Sovereigns valued the Dao and exalted virtue; the Five Emperors prioritized benevolence, then righteousness; the Three Kings prioritized righteousness, then order.

○ A single goose feather sinks in water because it lacks force; a million *jun* of gold floats in a boat because it relies on the boat’s force.

○ Inscribing the Golden Man’s admonition, one composes the *Mouth Inscription*:
The spirit communicates through resonance, the heart expresses through the mouth.
Fortune arises with omens, misfortune comes with signs.
The mind must not be deceitful, the mouth must not be loquacious.
An ant’s hole can breach a river; a trickle can topple a mountain.
Illness enters through the mouth; calamity emerges from it.
The mechanism of survival and ruin, the art of opening and closing—mouth and heart conspire.
The source of safety and danger, the trigger of the pivot—honor and disgrace follow.
With a public heart, there must be a public Dao.

○ Those who love themselves cannot help but love others; those who hate themselves cannot help but hate others.

○ When the people are wealthy, they settle in their villages and value their homes, respect their superiors, and follow instruction. When impoverished, they endanger their villages and scorn their homes, gathering to defy their rulers. Few are those who, pressed by hunger and cold, do not commit wrongdoing.

○ If I wish to fight but the enemy does not, when I drum and advance, it is like a mountain collapsing or a river flooding. Those in its path are crushed; those struck by its force are shattered. This is what is meant by "thunder too swift to cover one’s ears"—who then can resist it?

○ Now, with lead and tin ore, even if Ou Ye smelts it a hundred times, it will not surpass a clay knife. With a horse of inferior stock, even if Zaofu drives it, it will never match the Flying Hare or the Swift Shadow—its nature is dull and slow. Earth cannot become iron but can become tile.

○ The physiognomist says: "The three pavilions and nine pulses are determined in a face of one foot; foolishness, wisdom, courage, and timidity are revealed in eyes of one inch."

chunks.original_text: 昊起吮疮者之脓，积恩以感下也。 《史记》云：昊起吮臃，昼战目相见，夜战耳相闻，得利同势，失利相救。 陆田者命悬於天，人力虽修，水旱不时，则一年之功弃矣。 水田制之由人，人力苟修，则地利可尽。 ○傅子曰：圣人之道如天地，诸子之异如四时。 四时相反，天地合而通焉。 且易不同，采金攻玉，涉艰难也。 路不险，则无以知马之良，任不重，则无以知人之材。 君子相见，非但兴善，将以攻恶。 恶不废，则善不兴。 疗暑莫如亲水，救寒莫如重裘，止谤莫如修身。 善钓者不易渊而钓，君子不邻席而追道。 ○小人耻其面不如子都，君子耻其行不如舜禹。 故小人贵明鉴，君子尚至言。 ○射以平志，御以和心，书以缀事，数以理烦。 ○利如激风之至，暴雨之集，不论是非，不议直曲，期於不穷，激放必胜。 辩者，别也，言其善分别事类，非谓言辞捷给而凌善人也。 ○圣人蹈机掘杼，识成天地，使万物顺焉，人伦正焉。 登高而建旗，则所示者广； 顺风而奋铎，则所闻者远，非旌色益明，铎声远长，所托得地，而况富贵施政令乎。 ○良农不患坛场之不修而患风雨之不节，君子不患道德之不建而患其时之不至。 ○圣人之世不交游也，周道衰而交游兴。 古之交也近，今之交也远。 古之交也求贤，今之交也为名。 取不由乡党，考行不本闺闽，多助者则称贤才，少爱者则谓不肖。 ○马必待乘而后致远，医必待使而后愈疾，贤者待用而后兴理。 意林卷之五竟 ＃１『难致之功」原缺，据文渊阁本增补。 ＃２『若」原缺，上原有『之」，不通，据文渊阁本增改。
chunks.translated_text:
The Lord of Wu licked the pus from his soldiers’ wounds, accumulating kindness to move his subordinates. As the *Records of the Grand Historian* states: "The Lord of Wu sucked their sores; in daytime battles, they saw one another face to face, and in night battles, they heard one another’s voices. When victorious, they shared the spoils; when defeated, they rescued one another."

Dry-field farming depends on Heaven—though human effort is diligently applied, if floods or droughts come unseasonably, a year’s labor is lost. Wet-field farming is controlled by man; if human effort is properly applied, the land’s potential may be fully realized.

○ Master Fu said: "The Dao of the sage is like Heaven and Earth; the divergences of the various masters are like the four seasons. Though the four seasons oppose one another, Heaven and Earth harmonize and unite. Moreover, the *Changes* differ in approach—mining gold or carving jade requires enduring hardship. If a road is not perilous, one cannot know the excellence of a horse; if a task is not weighty, one cannot know a man’s talent."

When gentlemen meet, they do not merely encourage goodness—they also attack evil. If evil is not abolished, goodness cannot arise. To cure heat, nothing compares to drawing near water; to relieve cold, nothing compares to donning thick furs; to silence slander, nothing compares to cultivating oneself. A skilled angler does not change his deep pool to fish; a gentleman does not shift his seat to pursue the Dao.

○ The petty man feels shame if his face does not resemble Zidu’s; the gentleman feels shame if his conduct does not resemble Shun and Yu’s. Thus, the petty man values a clear mirror, while the gentleman esteems profound words.

○ Archery serves to steady the will; charioteering, to harmonize the heart; writing, to record events; calculation, to order complexity.

○ Profit arrives like a sudden gale or a violent downpour—indifferent to right or wrong, heedless of straight or crooked, it seeks only to avoid exhaustion, and in its impetuous release, victory is assured.

To be discerning is to distinguish—it means skillfully differentiating matters and categories, not merely outstripping others in glib speech.

○ The sage treads upon the loom’s shuttle and grasps its mechanism, comprehending the completion of Heaven and Earth, causing the myriad things to follow their course and human relations to be rectified. Raising a banner upon high makes its signal widely visible; shaking a bell in the wind makes its sound carry far—not because the banner’s colors grow brighter or the bell’s tone lengthens, but because their position is well-chosen. How much more so with the rich and noble issuing decrees!

○ A good farmer does not fret over an unkempt threshing ground but worries over untimely winds and rains; a gentleman does not fret over the failure to establish his virtue but worries over the untimeliness of his era.

○ In the age of the sages, there was no socializing; the Way of Zhou declined, and socializing flourished. In ancient times, associations were close; today, they are distant. In ancient times, associations sought worthies; today, they seek reputation. Appointments bypass the village and clan; conduct is not examined at the inner gate. Those with many supporters are called worthy talents; those with few admirers are deemed unworthy.

○ A horse must be ridden before it can travel far; a physician must be employed before he can cure illness; the worthy must be put to use before they can bring order. *Forest of Meanings*, Scroll Five, ends.
